Still, this style is an acquired taste and might appeal more to those with adventurous palates.  Its taken me a few years to come around to liking this style of beer.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2013 
37,5 cl bottle, BBE 2012 (according to cork)
Wonderful, fresh aroma with farmhouse, earthy notes and sour apples with some hints of sugar. Very dry palate. Flavour has sour apples, some earthy notes and hints of sugar. Unfortunately some harsh sourness does also appear. Good, refreshing and enjoyable gueuze!
A nice gueuze. One of my favourites. Lovely acidity. the copper colour is filled with strains of champagnelike bubbles. Outstanding freshness

Pours slightly hazy yellowish orange, bottle BX2011 thanks to Caleb! Aroma has notes of lemon, wheat, grass, lots of bleu cheese-y funk, horseblanket, some pear and other fruit, touch of lacto sour.  Taste is sour, delicious, and balanced, with notes of funky sweat, bleu cheese and horse, barnyard, leathery shoe, with some nice lemon, fruit, finishing dry, sour and more funky.  How gueuzes should aspire, perfect elements.

Aroma of sour apple, lemongrass, pear and musty damp basement. Appearance is constantly carbonated gold body with thin white head. Flavor has very fresh fruits up front, including apple, pear and lemon with a musty, sour finish. Palate is bubbly. Very, very nice. I wish I had this everyday.
Meraviglia divina, bevuto come aperitivo è qualcosa di fantastico, in bocca è onnipotente, ti pulisce il palato, ti aggrada, ti meraviglia, e non ti stanca mai, gran lambic...

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2012 @ the hotel in Amsterdam, pours orange with a nice head, powerful aroma of wood, barnyard, wine, brett, leather and smoked meat, flavor is sour with pickles, wine, vinegar, lemon and wood, medium to full bodied, great
9/4/9/4/16[4.2]

At the sour tasting, part b, thanks lee, pours an hazy yellow to orange with a nice head, sour aroma, vinous and floral notes, some leaves and delicate sweetness, flavor is dry with lemon acidity. Someleaves and unripe fruit, vinegar and wine, full bodied, amazing. 9/4/9/5/17[4.4]

At the sour tasting, thanks Amir, pours slightly hazy yellow with a small head, aroma is mainly acidic with some barnyard, leather, mold, fresh leaves and wood, flavor is sour, with some sourness burn, lemon, fresh leaves and some pickle water, full bodied, amazing

Bottle; pour is murky gold with a modest white head that retains on the average side. The nose is barnyard, hay, citrus zest, and mild hops. This is just a fantastic brew. The funk blends perfectly with the sweet breads, citrus, and wild yeasts ; clearly a fantastic gueuze

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2011 F - 2011 vintage. 375ml corked and caged bottle poured into a palm tulip at fridge temperature. Allowed to warm up for a half hour. A - Cloudy golden color. Nice fluffy head that dies down to one finger. S - Sour apples, lemon, and musky brett. Funky and dry. T - Really dominant sour apples, lemons and malt. Finish is tart and sour. Crisp and bubbly mouth feel. Not as dry as I would have liked. Still well balanced and pretty tasty. 
O - Not the best gueze Ive had. This is a fresh bottle so I may grab another bottle to sit on for a year or so.

Pours an almost glowing yellow with a fine, fairly big white head. Nose is sour/tart with some sweet peach and pear quality and a touch of grape-like aroma. Flavor is also fairly sour with a good dose of lemons, oranges, pear, and even some brown sugar ahead of a nice does of tart, carbonation-driven finish. Alcohol is not noticable. A good lambic.

Pours an orangeish brown color with a white fizzy head.  Had this drink with a delicious swordfish steak and some ears of corn all grilled!  Has a nice sour smells with some sugar.  I am starting to like sour beers more and more thus I am super excited for this one.  Nice fizzy bubbles rise to the surface when I grab the glass.  Mmmm.  Taste is great!  Nice sour blast of pear and apple hit my mouth with some slight sweetness as well.  I think I taste a bit of grapes too!  A very good drink that I will enjoy thoroughly with my meal.

A wonderful gueuze.  Im currently drinking a fresh bottle, and its comparable to any of the vaunted examples of the style.  The aroma is subtle and complex.  There are notes of green apples, lemons, barnyard funk, hay, sourdough, sour cherries and grass.  The taste still has some light malt sweetness, but it finishes light, dry and medium sour.  The aftertaste is sour and funky.  Its a very easy beer to drink, but youll want to savor it.  Delicious.

Sampler at CBF 2011-05-26. Hazy, yellow-golden with a white film. Sour, vinous, vinegar, berries and apples on the nose. Sour, bitter, fruity, earthy, malty and leathery flavors. Medium body. Astringent. Crispy dry finish leaving a velvet-like mouth. Fantastic!

75cl bottle. Great color, pale yellow on the sides of the glass, light amber in the middle. strong carbonation sustaining the thick cotton head. smells like a sour ale and cider. lots of granny smith apple and bartlett pear. very very dry. much more bitter than anything else. ends with a flavor like a tart and acidic underripe pear.
CBF; nice sour aroma,hot yellow color, hazy, medium sourness, medium body, soft carbonation, nice sour finish.
Bottle shared at De Molen.  Golden orange hazy pour with fast dispersing white head.  Brett funk in aroma with light fruits and citrus.  Sour flavor with cooking apples.  Very nice

Sampled at CBF 2011. Orange coloured and unclear. Has a white head, fully diminishing. Acid aroma, clear fruity, sugars too. Flavo is mainly acidic, faint sweet too and a light bitter finish. Sprakling. Dry.
Bottle. Hazy orange colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of sour fruit, apples, lemon and orange.

I poured it into my Bruery tulip carefully as there was a good amount of sediment on the bottom.  Ill save that for later.  It was a slightly cloudy orangish color that starts collecting a large bubbly head.  But before I can even finish saying large bubbly head it disappears into a thin white line across the top of the brew.

The aroma is very forward but not harsh in the slightest bit.  Apple cider vinegar is the primary scent I pick up with a backing of sour funk and lemon.

I was a bit surprised by the taste.  Of course it is funky and sour but I get a distinct hay taste in there along with sour apple.  It has some wood like qualities in the back and then there is an almost medicine like after taste to it.  I cant really decide whether the wood makes it pleasant or the medicine taste makes it a bit off putting.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2014 Rerate, 750 ml green "champagne" bottle, Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5%. Deep golden to orange colour, moderate white head. Sourer and even more complex flavour than noted upon first sample. Tart finish, some bitterness. Original rating: At Copenhagen Beer Festival. Hazy golden colour, sparkling. Decent aroma of brettanomyces (sour fruit, farmhouse, horse blanket), but not extreme. The medium sour flavour has also the typical brettanomyces character, but fairly well balanced and not too extreme. Should work well as a beginners gueuze.
light head, grey yellow. Dry fruity nose with some apple, nice. medium body and fine length, taste is sour and fruity with some apple and a dry exit. Overall a very fruity beer

Certainly the best beer available on a store shelf in my area, Ive had some bottles of this that are easy 5.0s and others that fall closer to a 4.5; Im guessing that one day I will just give this a 5.0 as it deserves.  Nose is grapefruit, lactic tartness, some brett funk, and a bit of white grape.  Taste follows and is the perfect level of tartness.  Really just an incredibly easy drinker with unbelievable flavor.
Bottle. Hazy golden, orange colour with a small white head. Some brett, fruits, apples and oranges in the aroma. Flavour is quite sour, brettanomyces, apples, oranges, grapefruit and some malt.
Bottle. Hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is oak, some spice, vinegar, apple and floral notes. Taste with tannin and balanced dry after-taste.
Pours a frothy beige head with a murky deep golden-amber body.  Aromas and flavors are lemon, dough, green apple, sour.  Finish is dry and tart.  Amazing.  Why is this not what "beer" is...

375ml bottle. Poured with a relatively tight & mostly lasting creamy beige head. A slight haze to an otherwise bright and effervescent orange body. Funky & oaky aroma with green apple, lemon, cherry, barnyard straw, cat pee and hints of orange. Lots of green apple, white wine and lemon on the tongue with a funky woodiness giving good tannin structure. Hugely sour & really dry on the palate. Full carbonation dries it out even more on the tongue. Lingering, mouth puckering sourness, crisp and bright medium bodied profile to the mouthfeel. Finishes with a bitter apple skin and lime combination.

Bottle, 375 ml. Slightly hazy yellow pour with a relatively small white head of short duration. Aroma of apple cider vinegar and acidic white wine. The taste is very tart and really follow your nose. Dry mouthfeel and a long dry and tart aftertaste. Maybe you can get to keep the beer was recommenced, if you practice long enough. Right now I can not reconcile myself with the taste

Tasted on 5/10/11 from a 375mL corked and caged bottle purchased at Armanetti.  Pours clear light amber with a thick white head that slowly recedes to a thin but even blanket of lace.  The nose is super sour with tons of lemon and other citrus, funky with a good dose of barnyard, lightly malty with a hint of cereal and bread, and also displays the barrel aroma with faint hints of vanilla and cinnamon.  The flavor is citrus sour up front, moving to the malty flavors of bread and cereal, funky barnyard, white wine vinegar, along with vanilla, cinnamon, and tannin from the oak.  The body is light with a slightly oily texture, just above average carbonation, and a super long citrus, white wine vinegar, vanilla, cinnamon, and tannic finish.

Bottle sampled at the 2nd Annual Sour Town tasting on 4/23/11. Pours clear gold with a thin white head. Sour lemon nose with some peppery character and a whole lot of sourness happening. Maltiness and pepperiness actually hit the tongue first, but the sourness comes fast and furious and lasts all the way through.

Bottle at Helsinki Beer Festival 2011. Poured brown in colour with thin bubbly white head. Sour and winelike aroma. Strange rubber in aroma as well.  Flavour is filled with vinegar and sourness. Sticks in the mouth.

Bouteille 37,5 cl de www.erzbierschof.ch. Bière orangée ambrée claire, mousse blanche stable, pétillement fin et abondant. Nez de pomme, acide, soufre, bois, note fumée et levure. La bouche est ronde et acide à la fois, extraordinairement fruitée, pomme-cidre brut, bois et texture moussue. A la fois sèche et surette jusquen finale. Merveille déquilibre et de naturel.

2001 Bottle at Butters Slutfest: Sour apple core aroma. Hazy amber. Brief apple, then a punch or ruby red grapefruit. Powerfully sour, challenging the saliva glands. Nice character, and fantastically enjoyable. One of the best gueuzes Ive ever had, but lacking in funkiness.
Sampled at Slutfest 2.0. Very tart and classic guezy.  Lightly cheese and enamel peeler.  Stinky gym socks nose.  Some rose and lilac character.  More complex than some. Very good.

head: thin, creamy 
colour: egg yellow 
smell: branyard, grapes, mandarines, soury/sweet, bit of cheesy/dairy
taste: very tipical gueuzey start , sour, vinegar, citric, bitter, yeast, orange/grapefruit peels, grape peels, end is dry and fruity , good one !!

Pours only a shade darker than straw with a small white head.  Nose is clearly indicative of sourness, but with a bit of Belgian yeast.  Flavor is sour green apple and slightly candied.  Nice gueuze, but Im not falling all over myself here.
Hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is very sour, acidic and fruity. Flavor is very sour and acidic. Very dry and acidic finish. Refreshing and with high drinkability. Excellent! 181010
Shared after a long ACBF 2011. Nice sour notes and funk. I am beginning to like sour beers!

The beer pours a murky gold with a light white head that doesnt rises very much. What does come has good retention and lacing. 

The aroma is medium in strength light, light horse blanket skunk mostly. Its nice, gives you the funk youre looking for but not overpowering in doing so.

The taste is exactly as you would expect after the aroma. If gives you what youre looking for but doesnt knock you on your ass. The taste is horse blanket but it is so smooth I cant believe I can just crush this. 

The feel is very nice, lasting flavor leaves a dry feeling.

This is very drinkable.

Overall, this is great. Easily the best and most drinkable gueze out there.

Serving: 375 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a hazy amber color with a very active white head.  The nose is appropriately funky with a light sweetness and a cider vinegar note.  The flavor is tart, but not overwhelmingly so.  There are notes of vinegar, apple cider, lemon, and a slight sweetness.  Light in body with lots of fine carbonation leading to a clean, slightly tart finish.  Definitely a fine, easy to drink gueuze.

37,5cl bottle. Pours a cloudy orange color with a foamy white head. Good lacing. Aroma is mostly sweet-sour with oak, hay and horse blanket qualities. Taste is sweet/sour, almost lemon peel. Grassy earthy notes. Some bittering hops. Medium bodied and lots of carbonation. Very balanced and drinkable.

Pours a nearly clear amber gold with a tall, creamy white head. Aroma is dry wood, banana bread, hints of rhubarb and a touch of rich sweet candy sugar. Flavor is sour fruits, herbal tea, buttery oak, sweet tarts, green apple straw and a touch of tart cherry skins. Palate is light, perfectly carbonated and nicely dry throughout. Fantastic beer, sour, lightly funky, refreshing and complex.

Had this bottle allready for about a year. Got as a present probably. Sorry for some people who hate to see me rating gueuze beers... Orange coloured beer with a small head, should be a big bigger, but it holds ok at the glass. The smell is sour fruits, light wooden and spiced. The taste is sour, light sweetened, lots of fruits, slightly spiced and wooden. Drinkeable, even without being my typ of beer. I can understand people enjoy this one, but not enough gas, to sour, and for me this dont really taste like beer.

Very elegant and refined. Pours hazy orange with a large head that fades. Soft but pleasing aroma of apples, lemon tartness and a very faint lambic funk. Complex flavour that is fresh and lively, apples, tartness, gentle funk, long very dry finish. Soft and rounded overall. Wonderful,

Bottle, 375 ml. Slightly hazy, light amber, a high, fizzy, lively head with medium sized bubbles. Looks nice. Smells of apple cider vinegar, lemons, wet cellar. Light body, with a very fresh, smooth, sourness, sour green apples. Soft carbonation. A very refreshing, balanced gueuze. I really like this one.
Bottle from Bier Tempel Brugge. Yeasty flowery aroma. Hazy golden colour with thin head. Very sour fruity yeasty flavour. Bitter aftertaste. Not for me I am afraid.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Central: hazy, golden yellow, with a rather small white head, smells funky with citric fruits, tastes citric, sour green apples, sour grapes, white pepper, sour cider, mildly acidic, dry finish, moderately sour, tart, minor barnyard funk, very balanced, extremely delicious, very drinkable //////////// Had some bottles recently that were very disappointing. Which was odd, had it several times since first tasting note, always very satisfactory. Should try again one of these days & take new notes. Keeping old score for now.

Bottle from Nelson Wines. It pours a hazy golden amber with a large off-white and very lively carbonation (the cork almost knocked a hole in my roof!). The nose is straw, farmyard, egg, yeast, sourness, vinous and grapefruit. The taste is lemon sherbet, lime, white grape and grapefruit with a very long dry, tart finish. There is a little underlying sweetness that balances the sourness. Top quality geuze that is really easy to drink.

375 ml green corked and caged bottle. 2011 vintage.

It pours a clear honey color, darker than most Gueuzes I have seen. The head is foamy and white and actually sticks around for a bit.

The smell is initially skunky. This is extremely odd because I have never smelled a skunky gueuze and it is an extremely fresh bottle. Once that dissipates it smells like young gueuze which it probably is with 2011 on the cork. It has fruity aromas in place of the funk and only a mild lemon acidity. The grain can also be picked up.

The flavor is also very mild, but delicious. It has a very nice sourness to it but also a bit of malt balance. The flavor has some herbal notes but is primarily lemony and acidic with a hint of sugar.

It is an interesting one. I have an older vintage in the cellar which i will give a long age and then try this one again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-02-2011 06:09:55

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 Golden yellow with an almost pink tinge. Fine lively bubbles and small white head. Freshly cut grain, apple harvest and barnyard in the nose. Medium body with tart, fresh and almost salty taste. Citrus, vinegar, fermented apple cider. Dry long finish.

375 ml bottle. From bierkompass.de.
Hazy amber colour with tiny white head.
Aroma: red berries, strong sourness, earth and leather.
Flavour: sourness, berries and  some balancing sweetness.
Flavour is milder than aroma.
Well balanced.

Bottle, thanks to Phaleslu. Hazed gold with some sediment floating around, thin head. Aroma is awesome, fruity, acidic, some herb, horse blanket. Taste is also amazing, sour but not as brutal as some others, again some herby bitter finish. Very juicy, lemony, incredibly refreshing. High carbonation.

375ml Bottle from De Bierkoning. Slightly hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma of light sweet wheat, floral, funk, tart, green apples, lemon, champagne, grapes. Flavour is light sweet, malty, but mostly tart/sour fruity, lemon and grape sourness, light sweet and sour finish. Light bodied, thin. This is just about tolerable for me considering sourness. This was suggested to me as a good entry-sour, which it is. But still no favorite.
UPDATED: JUN 1, 2011 Pours clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sour and fruity. Taste is medium sour and light sweet. with a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2012 Bottle 375ml @ home
Pours cloudy deep golden with a off-white head. Aroma is sour with notes of tart, horse blanket and barnyard. Taste is light sweet and medium sour with a long sour and dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle 375ml
Pours clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sour and fruity. Taste is medium sour and light sweet. with a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft. [6 3 6 3 12 2/22/2011]

Bottle. Golden, hazy, small and short head. Moderate, malty  wheaty, dryish and fruity aroma, citrus and green apples. Body is medium, dry and very sour flavor, citrus and green apples. Finish is average, dry and very sour, citrus and green apples. Nice gueuze, aroma and flavor are not in balance lacks fruitiness in the flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2014 Pours a hazy amber with a white head. Aroma is very rural with stable notes, green apples, lemon peel, dry white wine, brett, funk, grapefruit, sour berries, tartness and wild yeast. Taste of grapefruit, lime, citrus, some wild funky yeast, tart, brett, rurally feel to it here aswell, stable, hay, sour berries, green apples, So sick balance and so easy to drink. I could drink this stuff all day.

Poured a slightly hazy yellowish-honey color with almost no head.  Very nice aroma of tart yeast notes with fruit.  A slightly funky lemon hint as well.  Taste is slightly sweet at first with some fruit.  The flavor then transitions into a sour yeasty finish with some nice hops to balance everything out.  Sour apples, wood, and lemon are also present.  The hops have a slight hay taste.  The body is slightly creamy and this creamy sour taste lingers for quite a while.  Overall very flavorful and well blended.  A very good lambic.

Poured into a tulip.

4.0 A: Lightly hazed peachy orange color. Two fingers of creamy off-white head. Much of the head fell quickly, but the remaining quarter inch was a bit more stubborn and leaves a quarter inch of lacing.

4.0 S: Decent amount of barnyard funk, cidery, and sour lemon. Hay, some apple fruitiness, slight acidity. Not powerful enough for my preferences, but amazingly no tannin astringency at all.

4.5 T: Taste is much better and lives up to expectations. Surprisingly sour considering the nose is rather tame. Plenty of lactic acid, acetic acid to a lower degree, barnyard funk, musty basement. Lemony sourness, apple cider, and hay. Some astringency in here, but very little and much lower than anything else Ive had of the style. Dry throughout.

4.0 M: Light to lighter medium body. Good active carbonation. Smooth for a sour due to the lack of astringency. Could be a bit creamier though.

5.0 D: Definitely a solid gueuze. This is definitely there to help you get a sour fix. Well balanced flavor profile, great taste, and everything else is pleasant. By the end of the bottle I wanted more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-08-2010 03:21:01

Bottle 16 Tons. Clear orange pour with a mostly indistinct head. Smells of lemon, orange, some funk, a little leather, other fruit and vinous notes. Very inviting aroma. Tastes of sour apples, grapes, peaches, oranges with a little leather and just the right amount of funk. The first beer of this style I ever tried, and it definitely did not disappoint.

Bottle. Pours a nice cloudy golden orange color with a small white head. Aroma is quite tart smelling, with notes of green apple, white grapes, hay, brettanomyces and is fairly fruity. Flavor is also quite tart with notes of lemon, green apple, the brettanomyces, wood, white grapes, hay and some funk. The body is medium with a very dry mouthfeel. Overall a really nice Gueuze, that isnt overpoweringly tart.

Arvosteltu niin korkealle Ratebeerissä, että odotukset ovat korkealla. Pullo poksahtaa auki. Jännitys tiivistyy. Lasiin kaatuu sameaa, oranssia nestettä. Päälle muodostuu valkoinen vaahto, joka melko nopeasti häviää lähes täydellisesti. Vain ihan ohut kerros jää piilottamaan aromit alleen. Tuoksussa on rajusti hedelmiä ja happoisuutta. Tuoksu, jollaisen saattaisi kokea kävellessään puutarhassa sitruunaa syödessään antaa odottaa jotakin kirpeää. Odotus palkitaan kirpeällä, hedelmäisellä, hieman hiivaisella ja uskomattoman happamalla maulla. Söinkö äsken sata sitruunaa?

0,375 l bottle as a gift.
Hazy golden beer with a superb creamy-foamy white head. Sourish-tart aroma with tannin of oaks, a powerful Brettanomyces character, fruits like grapefruit, orange peel, lemon, grassy hop. Thick body with the tartness of the style. Green apple, woods, tartness of Brettanomyces again, fruits. If the beer gets warmer it will be richer...Tropical fruits, grapefruit and lime. And a powerful bit of the hops in the finish. Yumm!
Bottle at Hotel enjoyed in the spa. Lovely horsey nose. Not overpoweringly funky. Vanilla from barrel and a nice pronunced lemon presence. Very regal and about as close to champagne as beer will get.

(375ml bottle courtesy of rayl101!).  Pours golden with white head and monster lacing.  Active carbonation.  Aroma is of a smoky funk.  Taste is sour.  Medium bodied with thin texture.  Finish is smooth.
Loved this beer. Great gold color with large white head. Lemon, yeast, lime, biscuit....wonderful. Taste is the same with a good bit of vinegar puckering in there as well.

Medium size bottle from Binnys. Golden topped with a nice lasting white head. Aroma is lemon/lime, yeast, vinegar and hay. Tart and salty with lemon, vinegar and yeast, coats your mouth and leaves you wanting more. Great palate for a geuze, thick and syrupy.

Tasted from a 375 mL bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Creamy yellow head with a yellow-orange appearance.  Quite sour with a bit of lemon aroma.  Great Gueuze aroma.  Big sour Gueuze flavor thats quite citrusy.  Different and a little foreign from other Gueuze beers but very interesting and definitely worth a taste.  I think funky is a good description.  On a side note, my cat, Lenin, grabbed my glass of Girardin Black and licked it for 15 straight seconds.  Thus it is Feline approved!
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2011 Hazy orange golden beer with ok white head.Smell Avocado,grapefruit,sour,honey,autumn rain,Roquefort.Taste sour,sour and sour.Earthy,bisquit,lemon.grapefruit,leaves bitter,dry,

Bottle thanks to papsoe. Pours a wonderful slightly hazy deep orange with a smallish cream coloured head. Minimal lacing but great looking beer. Aromas are pretty much as expected light vinegar courness and plenty of earthy funk. Also a slight sweetness which probably wasnt expected. Brilliant. Flavours show the sourness once again but probably miss most of the funk. The sweetness is there though especially at the beginning. Finish is very dry as expected. Medium mouthfeel with lively carbonation. Great beer.
Aroma is sour with some blu cheese and mild ginger.  Flavor is Lemon and yeast with some cheese and sour cherry.  Really a fantastic beer!

Pours deep orange amber with a decent  head leaving some lacing. High carbonation. Aroma is sour, sweet and fruity, great indeed. Flavor is balanced acidy with nice fruityness and crispy of the high carbonation. Very acidy sour palate. Finishes freshly sour and a bit hoppy.

Bottle thx to tkrjukoff cons 2010-11-28 Sätila
AP: bronze, lemon sorbe colored fizzy head
AR: stable, fizzyness
F: fizzyness, dryness, greata bitterness, appel tartiness, with sugar sweetness, sour dryness in finish

Picked up a bottle of this at the Sahara Mart on 3rd Street in Bloomington, IN. Got the bottle in late August 2009.

Pours a pale yellow gold with a nice white head. The immediate aroma is an earthy funkiness, barnyard, and quite a bit of acidic tartness. The taste follows in the same direction, with a bit of citrus, and a moutherpuckering sour flavor. A little bit of pale malt eventually comes through toward the end, but this one is sour through and through. Falling only behind Duck Duck Gooze and La Folie in terms of sour drinkability for me.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009

37.5 cl. bottle. Shared with Gabe. Pours a medium long lasting , white head, with slight lacing, over a cloudy, yellow (SRM 5) body....nose is barnyard, Belgian funk, grapefruit, lemon, lime, very light cheese, mildew....taste sour start, grapefruit, apple, pear, soft lactic finish, with light pucker on the finish....mouth feel is light with carbonation making a creamy sensation. This is extremely complex with layers of aroma and flavor and a wonderful mouth feel. BJCP 9/2/16/4/8

I am still baffled by Belgiums use of green bottles, but thats a tangent for another day. Orange amber and gold along the bottom, my glass glows a gentle haze of white and straw. Her little white head soon wanders to far-off pastures with only lace to remind me of her passing. Typically though, gueuze doesnt showcase voluptuous heads; their acidic nature tends to kill that off rather quickly which is quite alright. Her nose? Sour, earth, and funk. Tart peach and apricot skins with an underbelly of leather, wood, and funk. Joining the tart peach and apricot skins are unripe kiwi and green pineapple ready and raring to pucker the day away. Mwahahahahaha! One more long snuff of tangelo skins, pith, and saddlebags glistening with a fresh helping of orange oil and its off to supping gueuzevana I quaff. I love it when the sides of my cheeks shiver and tingle under the playful touch of tartness. Taking a moment to savor the aromaI then move onto flavor exploration. Kiwi, pineapple, and apricot skins are bright atop my tongue while leather with orange oil essence lurks underneath. Each quaffs pierces my tongue with flavor. After the apricot, kiwi, tangerine, and pineapple work their unripe tart skinly magic, leather, wood, and funk come in to soothe and satisfy. A slow gentle dryness is the only presence of pith while grass hits last for a brief tickle in the back of my throat. A few more quaffs and I surrender pen and paper to pure unbridled tasting indulgence.


Sour beers, whether lambics, gueuze, or something somewhere inbetween are amazingly complex and often delicate beers that have so much to offer once one opens their mind to the tart tingly pleasures within. I understand now how the Girardin Gueuze Black Label has been a benchmark of its style. May it never ever change. At least, not a lot; blending is a fickle art after all.

2006 Bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Hazy orange-brown pour. Intense aroma with a great balance of horseblanket and tart cranberry and lemon. Beautiful notes of old cheese, cranberry, lemon, and cherry with a touch of nail polish. Acetic with a strongly lingering tartness along with some old cheese. Superb.
Nose of pee, sweat, some soap, later fruit notes, feel is sparky and broad, carb is heavy, taste is elegant apricot, sweet, malt notes, sour freshness on weak yeast

37,5cl bottle from Bierkompass. Poured almost clear orange color with a nice white head. Quite sour grapefruity aroma. Flavor is similar, sour citrus fruit and some notes I think I can describe as earthy/cellar notes. End is very dry.
Nice gueze, not as complex as I hade thought.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2012 37,5 cl bottle, pours dark golden with a nice head, aroma of grapefruit, green apples, yeast, barnyard and malt, taste is pretty much the same, decent tartness, nice lingering finish, refreshing and very nice overall.

Rate # 225. 375ml Bottle. My 1st Old Gueuze - I am blown away. Everything about this was beautiful. Poured a dense cloudy / foggy straw with mellow orange tints, the head was a little fizzy but solid and lingered around most of my glass. Aroma was very complex, a tight layered web that was hard to pick apart: woody, lemon zest (maybe citrus zest as well), big passing tart notes, notes of earth, barnyard. The taste follows the aroma but maybe with some fruit coming into the mix. Medium body. Overall: excellent.

Something I dont like about these Girardin Gueuzes is that their bottles arent dated - any of these beers that -could- be aged, should be dated! Maybe this stuff ages well? Who knows, unless I purposely get the bottling date Ill never know! Pours with a very nice layer of solid head and orange foggy body. Aroma of sourness, sour barley and hay, some wood notes. The taste is a very light gueuze - on the sour end with a very tart finish, very lemony with again a leather or wood aspect to keep the flavour in check. Id call this a "classic" gueuze, something you could use as a benchmark.

375 ml bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu.
Pours a hazy orange colour with a small white head. Tart on the nose with grapefruit, lemon and barnyard. Very good tartness on the flavour too. Grapefruit and lemon dominate the taste with . A bit swift taste. Light bodied, smooth mouthfeel and pleasant carbonation. Dry finish. Nice gueuze.

9/6/10.  Bottle.  Cloudy light orange pour with a fluffy off-white head.  Funky aroma like a barn mixed with sour lemon, acid, and vinegar.  The flavor is very sour upfront, like puckering lemon, followed by awesome barn funkiness and dry grains.  Simply delicious!

Bottle. Pours a slighlty hazy amber orange color with a light wispy head. Sour tart aroma with slight acetone notes. Some funky barnyard notes as well with lemon zest. Tart, slightly mouthpuckering...oh yeah, this is tasty. Tart grape flavors. Light mouthfeel. Some lingering barnyard funkiness at the end. Overall a very, very tasty beer.
Bottle at Akkurat. Short off white foam. Aroma of old popcorn. Sour dry taste but no as complex as some other Gueuze Ive tried.

Light gold with a loose white head. Vibrant tart fruity aroma with amazing complexity--animal funk, sour berries, bright fruit. Bracingly tart flavors with the aromatics showing up as elements of the flavor as well. Light body holds everything together very well and conveys all of the layers of complexity superbly. Classic.

From a 375mL bottle.  Pour is hazy golden orange with a nice frothy white head.  Aroma is lemon acidity, some nice funk, and wheat.  Flavor is strong lemon, green apple, somewhat mineral-like, with a touch of wheat.  Not as sour as the cantillion gueuze, but still it has a great deal of lemon acidity.  Wonderful example of the style.

375ml bottle.  Pours a very hazy orange with a slight white head.  Holy shit! One hell of an aroma on this sour.  Massive funk with notes of hay, lemongrass, barnyard, and pure sour yeast.  A lighter body gueuze with a high level of carbonation lends well to a very crisp, yet highly acidic taste and mouthfeel.  Finish is dry and clean without killing the palate.  Sour, tartness, and funk are all equally represented in this fine beer.

Bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours a murky gold/orange with frothy white head.  Aroma of barnyard funk, lemon, wheat, and huge sourness.  Taste is very sour, mildly sweet.  Mouthfeel is crisp and carbonated, and the sourness gets you in the back of the mouth.  Nice gueuze!

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2011 75cl bottle vintage 1997. This came from the cellar of an old lady who lived a short walk away from the brewery. According to Paul Girardin, when the lady passed away her collection came up for sale and it consisted of hundreds of bottles of Girardin Black label. She drunk 3 bottles a day! This beer was perfect with 14 years of age on it. It was musty, funky and had lots of blue cheese on the aroma. The palate was still highly carbonated and there was a lasting head. The flavour was very complex with only the slightest hint of age. Lots of biscuit and citrus with some mouldy cheese and dust. Really good

Bottle. Hazy orange pour, thin white head. Aroma of brett, sour fruits, basement and barnyard. Flavor is sour yet complex, with fruits, some medicinal hint, blue cheese and bitter grapefruit in the finish. Watery texture and average carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2012 Got to have the 99 at Akkurat in the 75cl bottle, pure heaven and beats out all but the 50th Anniversary from the big geueze contenders. Slightly pale golden orange with very little white head.  Nose is rich and sweet.  Light dusty funk, touch of cheese rind and dry cobwebbs, nice sweet peach and light tangerine. Light funk, cheese is faint, some cellary musk, cobwebs, and dry paper.  The fruits are integrated in very well, sweet fruits, peach, tangerine with a nice sharp sourness.  Light body, hints of oiliness, coats the mouth, strong carbonation on a dry finish.  Most sour out of the millennium and 3F 50th.  Less funky than the 50th, amazing stuff and deep complexity.


Big thanks to Kevin for sharing this one! Second time trying this out in a few months and seemingly different.

A-golden yellow, hazy, pure white head.

S-nose has a good earthy funk to it, light musk and barnyard, soft lemon with light acidity in the nose.

T-sweeter than most gueuze, earthy musk, notes of dry cellar, the sweetness balances, light peaches with notes of lemon.  the sour is moderate and the acidity is there but low.  Tasty stuff!

M-smooth soft feel, a little grainy but mostly smooth.  lightly syrupy with a medium body and good crisp semi dry finish.

D-this has a great balance, lighter funk and moderate to strong sweetness with a strong complexity and decent thick body.

******

A-dark golden color, very hazy, tight creamy white head with a nice lace left on the glass

S-earth and bready malts are right up front. There is a barnyard musky funk that follows with notes of tart cherries in the back

T-this is quite tart and sour but not astringent at all. It has a fair bit of funk and musk, lots of earthy notes. Tart cherries at the finish

M-this has a medium body that is very smooth and creamy on the palate. Lots of carbonation giving it a prickly finish on the back of the throat.

D-this is very tasty but it is so tart and sour. The flavors are very good and blend together very nicely. Nothing is too strong to keep a nice complex balance.

Bottle @ home. Instant brett and green apple aroma when cork is removed, excited foam shows itself just above the opening, with a weird orange mush on top.
Cloudy orange pour, medium sized off white (a bit orange) head.
Aroma is funky and tart with cherry, apple, and well, brett.
Flavour is quite intense sourness with lots of funky and tart fruits.
Medium carbonation. Lingers on for ages. Nice geuze.

Bottle.

A - Glowing hazy golden orange with a large, billowy, foamy, sticky white head. Good retention settling into a thick, sticky layer of lace.
 
S - Tart and funky barnyard aromas come out pretty strong on the first smell, but not overpowering. Some musty fruit smell with apples and citrus, both lemon and some orange. A touch of yeast and hay aroma also present. A touch of sweetness, but tart/sour/funk dominates that.
 
T - Good amount of sour green apple, lemon, and orange citrus. Hints of grape. A funky, barnyard, hay taste comes out a bit more mid sip. A woodiness also starts to peak out a bit as well. Musty fruit flavors come on strong mid sip and last to the finish. A bit of sweetness comes out toward the end. This has a sour and tartness, but it isnt puckering or as strong as others in the style or other similar styles.

M - Lighter side of medium body with a lot of carbonation. Zesty, tingly feel with a strong drying finish.

D - Has a good balance of sour, tar, funk, and sweetness that makes it easy to drink. Great flavors that make me want to keep drinking it.

Notes: Very good gueuze. Not quite as sour/tart as others, but it still showcases those flavors. Overall a very good beer that could be a good introduction into sours for someone.

375ml bottle into Lost Abbey Rastal Teku.

A - Pours a hazy golden/orangish with a white frothy head. Theres a good amount of retention and a nice cap left behind after the initial pour. Some lacing is evident along the sides of the glass as the head disipiates.

S - Smells, well, funky. Sour/tart funk, barnyard notes, and citrus/floral hints. Without getting overly fancy, its a funk bomb of Gueuze goodness.

T - A nice amount of floral and sour/tart notes. Lots of funk, which is what I was really expecting. There a nice touch of floral that I wasnt expecting and gives this beer some finesse as opposed to just a huge sour bomb.

M - Light, crisp, and clean. Good carbonation that leads to a semi-dry finish. 

D - One of the best this style has to offer, IMO. This is only my first experience with this beer but Im sure this will become a staple in my cellar since I can now purchase locally. 

I drank this after drinking DDG earlier, and I must say, theyre pretty darn close. $$$-wise, this is a bargain compared to DDG.

bottle printed ref A x 2010 on the cork. pour has a brassy golden color with a coating of off white head that came back with a swirl. aroma has dry white grape, lemon, sharp tartness, mellow yeasty funk, pear sweetness, and a bit of wood. mouth feel is light with little carbonation and it just keeps getting more dry and sour. flavor has quite the smack of dry sour. lemon, sour grapefruit, a mingle of yeasty funk and green apple. boy this is unrelenting in the pucker department but there are these odd hits of sweetness that really twisted my tasters. I really enjoyed this and it kept me interested to the last drop.

As the first gueuze I have ever had, I am saddened to learn that this is one of the best. With a ph of 3, it is very sour, almost vinegary. Reminiscent of a type of lemon champagne, except that it smells worse. Surprisingly, I found myself finishing my glass, as well as the ones around me. This may have been to my love of any beer, not particularly this one. An interesting choice, but I would rather stick to more conventional brews.

Hazy orange, fizzy head.  Aroma is definite gueuze with a sour berry or sour pear hint to it.  Taste is lemony tart.  Crisp, but with some vinegar hints to it.  The finish is dry - almost like theres tannins in it.  A great gueuze - we need more of these in Texas.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 Bouteille de 375 ml. Arômes de cidre (pommes caramélisées) et de levures sauvages. Robe dorée et limpide, peu de mousse malgré leffervescence assez active. Très délicate et équilibrée, la bière montre un fort côté de pommes sûres, qui apparaissent même caramélisées par moment. Les brettanomyces apportent des touches fruitées, de cuir et dherbe humide. Finale bien sèche et légèrement acide (par rapport à dautres gueuzes plus costaudes). Du grand art !

This one smelled like absolute shit, but had a very different/interesting taste to it. It took me a little while to warm up to it, but it became very enjoyable. The tart, sweet flavors and the bitter finish were all awesome.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2011 (33ml corked bottle @ the Ealing beer festival with chriso) I  appreciated this more than their white bottle. The White equivalent was a bit tame and mellow.  This offering is textbook , with the   typical tart Gueuze uncompramising nature  .... some funky , sweaty  musty chesse too, finishes bone  dry. . The bottle couldda be a little colder I  remember. Quality ..
Bottle at Monks. Tons of horse blanket and barnyard in the nose. Body is dry, very dry, with vinegar and some wine like fruit. Maybe currant.
Hazy orange/golden with small off-white head. Flavour is sour, tart and wood.

Bottle. Really a whole lot more sour than the white label; absolutely no sweetness to it.  Lightly hazy yellow-oragne hue with great retention on a pure white head.  Aroma of funk, sourness, and earthy really is prominent and great; sour in a moreish way, but the barnyard and leather come in as well.  Very puckering finish.  This is just an outstanding brew, and wonderful drinking.  Great stuff, and just sets the bar for me.
Pours a orange with a nice white head.  Aroma is lemon funk oak barn. Flavor is lemons sour acid funk oak sawdust leather. Mmmm awesome sour.

with a small white head on it. The aroma really fills the area as soon as the bottle is opened. Very lemony, sour, and barnyardy. Flavor is much the same, with a good pucker to it and good helping of wet, grassy hay and earth. A little fruity in character with a touch of white grape. Lots of carbonation. Very nice to sip.

Rating #381, bottle from Fish and Beer  

This is going to be exciting, as it is my first gueuze. I have heard that it is really a love or hate beer style, but lets see. Until now, there has only been one beer style I didnt appreciate, and that is Berliner Weisse. Well, the appearance of this gueuze isnt frightening me. Were talking dark yellow beer here, and a cloudy one. The head was airy at first, but seems to have settled in a more dense condition and about my little finger in thickness. I am not used to rate gueuzes as this is my first one, but I have to admit that I am not impressed by the aroma. Most of all it reminds me of a yeasty white wine, and has the exact same kind of sourness. Some mild grainy hops are present too. I am really lost about how to rate this taste. Still, it reminds me very much of white wine, but of course it keeps some beer elements. Most present are lemon with leather, woody and basement-like flavors, alltogether with the overshadowing sourishness. Mild hopped and sour finish. Sour and bitter aftertaste. Ok flavor all in all. Creamy and soft, but rather thin and VERY dry. Exciting beer, but not one I am wild about.   If this is how gueuzes are supposed to taste, as I believe it is when looking at the score, there will probably be a long time before I buy a gueuze again. Not because this is a bad beer, but because it reminds me too much of white wine. And the case is not that I dont like white wine, but if I wish to drink something that tastes like white wine, I will buy a white wine, and not a beer "copy" of the drink. Another thing is, that I appreciate the wonders of beer as complex American Strong Ales, creamy Belgian Abbey Ales and fantasticly evil Imperial Stouts much more than I can ever do wine or beer that tastes like wine.

Bottled 375ml. -Trade with shrubber85 (thanks Roger!). Nice hazy orange coloured, small to medium sized white head, strong sour nose. Strong sour, yeasty and woody taste with notes of grapefruit. Pleasant sour finish and lingering aftertaste.

Bottle from a trade with shrubber85 (huge thanks!), shared with ogivlado. Poured a murky, lovely dark orange  with a thick tiny white head.Pungent acidic nose, orange, malt, something funky. 
Acidic taste, herbal, some sweet malt. Nice funky notes going bitter, corky. Dunno, not as balanced as some, but quite 
nice. Expected just a bit more.

37,5 cl bottle from Bieropholie, shared with Phil, served cold in a tulip glass. At least a couple of years old. 23MA10.
App.:  Cloudy orange-amber with a large, light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Strong funk, barnyard, horse blanket, rubber, bitter herbs, some fruitiness, pretty typical, I guess.
  
Palate:  Medium-ish body, moderate to low effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Strong mustiness, rubber, solvent, sour fruits; not ridiculously sour with some bitterness.

Cant blame me for trying, but I still dont like hardcore Lambics!

Hazy golden with a thin head, very gueuze... lemon, funk, brett aroma... lively bubbly, medium body, medium mouthfeel... lemon, funk, lively, funky, leather, amazing... this is what a gueuze should taste like... wow...

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2012 Unknown 2008 vintage, opened May 2009.
A: Hazy peach-champagne colored body. Light, bubbly head. Decent retention and lacing.
S: Tart. Sour. Champagne like character marked by lemon, peach, white grape, and pear tones.
T: Sour up front with a nice tart kick in the end. Like the nose, this is champagne like in its profile but has the addition of some light fruits like peach, pear and white grapes. The acidic lemon flavor comes and goes throughout.
M: Generously carbonated, light body. Crisp finish.
O: Way back when, this was my first foray into the world of Gueuzes. I continue to enjoy it as Ive developed my palate and appreciation for the style.. I find this beer to be easy to consume despite the overall tart and sour nature of the beer. A good place to start for those looking to explore the style.

Bottle. Pours golden amber with a white head. Sour/tart/musty bretty aroma with some rhubarb and woody notes. The flavor has brett and a lactic sourness, followed by a quick musty/dusty note, and some woody notes. Nice.

Pours a slightly hazy gold color with a nice off white head.  Aroma of yeast, malts, wood, straw, cheese and earth notes.  Flavors is very acid lemons, malts and yeast, hints of straws and grass, wood and spices.
Good carbonation, mostly bitter tart, with long acid taste. Powerfull tastes and very complex and still quite refreshing.

Pours a hazy, light orange/amber colour, with a minimum of white, frothy foam. Aroma of flowers, lemon, corn, earth, barnyarrd, yeast and a tiny bit of hops. Taste is lightly sweet at first, but quickly turns heavily sour, and a little bitter. Notes of apple cider, vinegar, pine, grass and citrus. Pleasant palate, quite fresh and lively. Medium-full body, medium carbonation, medium-long duration. Very refreshing!

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2013 750 ml bottle. A hazy dark blonde beer, with a large, frothy/fizzy, half diminishing white head. The aroma is lightly malty (grain/bread), moderately yeasty (barnyard, cheese, wet earth), with notes of citrus, wet dog and apples. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately to heavily acidic. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, dry and long finish with light to moderate bitterness. The least sour of the great gueuzes, but it doesnt mean anything. New intense notes at every sniff and sip, mixed with a huge drinkability. This one could easily be the gateway sour for the Lambic novice.

A: pale golden color with nice frothy white head. not too much head retention but good lacing. Not much uniformity to the bubbles that stick to the side of the glass while tipping it.

S: Tart apples and lemons coupled with belgian yeast and an underlying funk

T: Much more sour than a lambic but smoother and drier than an oud bruin. Lots of tart citrus flavors with some underlying berry funkiness.

M: Clean finish but leaves your mouth dry and begging for more. Not as carbonated as I expected but a good amount of carbonation.

D: This is my first Gueze and I believe I spoiled myself with a very nice selection. Its exactly what I was expecting. An overly sour lambic style taste sans any fruit. Very nice!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-21-2008

Bubbly golden pour, thin white head which quickly dissipates into one lace spot, from the 500ml bottle shared at Hamiltons Tavern: Theres a suggestion of lactic notes in the aroma, as well as some Chardonnay and other vinous qualities, sour grapes, green apple peel, some citrus orange notes, raspberry, and an overall sense of thick under-ripened/ripened fruity esters. But shift those aside and you get some nice earthy horse blanket oozing through. Sublime tastes of tart citrus, thick oak, grapes, blackberries, thin apple, and nuances of starchy veggies, mostly carrots and celery hearts. A seemingly endless list of adjectives can describe this unexampled ale, but Ill start with these words: earthy, musky, thickly pulpy, and starchy. Im finish my drink almost confused, but I mean that sincerely, for one things for sure- this gueuze clearly paves the path of its own style. Drinkability: Its "Je Ne Sais Quois" I dont know what, unforeseeable, really fantastic. Pairing: Raw sea urchin sashimi. Rebuy: Hells yeah. #452 on 16052010, DG.
Pour golden color with a white head. Nose is barnyard funk, sour, and some oak. Taste is sour, lemon citrus, oak, fucky as well. Puckers your mouth at first, in a good way. Nice finish to it as well.

Bottle from dkachur...thanks Dan! - Pours a light amber with nice rising bubbles and a foamy white head. Musty and oaky on the nose, with some citrus rind, subtle animal poop, and funk. Dry and tart in the mouth, with lemon, white grapes, tons of grapefruit, rind, and mustiness. Tart, mouth-puckering finish, with soft carbonation and a smooth body. Wow...I can see why this is considered world-class stuff.

Heady sour aromas of cherry, plum, brown bread and flowers.  Full palate with a super-long finish.  A bit drying.  Awfully sour to my taste, to the extent that it covers up the nice malt and yeast notes in the nose.

Pours a hazy golden orange color and tropped by a small, bubbly white head that quickly receds and leaves a sudsy wash on the glass. The aroma is funky, sour, and musty with notes of soured apricots, lemons, old wood, funk, and a musty barnyard like yeast all showing strong. The flavor follows and is quite sour with lemons and apricots up front and then followed by the funky, barnyard yeast, earthy notes, and old wood. Meidum bodied with good carbonation and just the right amount of sourness all the way through to the dry finish. This is a great example of a gueze.
Almost like drinking champagne without the carbonation. Very tart and easy to drink. Lovely! Rated 12/10/04

Bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar ($9).  Lively thump while popping the cork.  Head quickly dies down.   Golden orange color.  Fast, sparse bubbles.  Smells of cheese, funk, rind, tart, and sour.  Pleasant, round tart flavor narrowing down to a spiky finish.  Chewy sour as it warms,  Absolute joy to sip.

Thanks Aaron for sharing this!

A- Body is a foggy golden yellow hue that pours with 1-2 finger foamy white head. Cloudiness in the body is somewhat dynamic. Great head retention but no lacing left in the glass.

S- Nose is very good, complex and balanced. Some scents that are detectable include lemon, vinegar, a slight acidic sourness,vanilla, a hint of oak, and yeast.

T- Lots of lemon upfront as well as an acidic tartness comes through initially as well as a touch of vinegar. What lingers on the palate is some tartness, as well as a touch of vanilla and wood.

P-Mouthfeel is relatively light, smooth and creamy with medium carbonation.

O- This is an awesome gueze. The sourness is there and its pretty big but its kept in check by the complexity and other characters in the brew. Wonderfully put together and a great beer overall.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-22-2010 13:54:16
Given all the hype, I definitely need to try it again.  I prefer some other sours to this, but Ill give it a second shot.

2009 Bottle - Thanks MrChopin!! - Pours a beautiful, hazy orange with a small off white head...aroma is so very inviting, lemon, apricot, oaky and earthy...flavour is similar, tight footy funk, white wine vinegar, salt, sour fruit, lemon...how do you compete with this beer? So accessible, and beautiful in every way...

Pours a slightly hazy, highly carbonated, orange-amber w/ an initial voluminous off-white head that dissipated relatively quickly. Aroma is musty & vinous w/ some citrus & wood-like notes. Light, effervescent feel. Flavour is tart & acidic w/ a dry, almost leathery finish.

Bottle. Ive now had this on a few occasions. Unclear golden with a huge frothy white head. Nose is horse blanket, funk, citrus and earthy notes. The flavour is tart citrus, oak, earth, musky, funk and you name it its here. Superbly balanced. This is the ultimate thirst quencher...breakfast, lunch or dinner it dont matter. Amazing stuff. Not much else I can add to describe a classic beer and style.
Golden with a white head. Really sour aroma with notes of dust. Champagne-ish palate. Really sour and surprisingly bitter.

Aroma of barnyard, lemon, cherry, peach, maybe some sour apple. Flavor quite tart and sour (solidly but not abrasively so), slightly but not overwhelmingly funky. Tart grapes in the finish. Enveloping tickling tartness, yet stellar drinkability at once. Great stuff.

With great thanks to HogTownHarry for sharing this. Appearance: Dirty brown, lots of flecks floating around, big frothy head. Aroma: Simply delicious sourness, yeast and tons of lemon. Flavour: Super sour, superb! Lots of lemon, really dry, just an absolute pleasure to drink, definitely a desert island beer.

Bottle, $10.99. Pours clear gold, with a beautiful white head. Beautiful is a word that I would like to use throughout this review, ideally.  Aroma is incredible blend of spritzy lemon, yuzu, blonde leather and deep funkiness.  Palate is clean, effervescent, with a dry finish.  Flavor starts on firm tartness and hay, rides a wave a barnyard notes into a lemony-citrusy finish.  Oh, what maturity. A complex and beautifully balanced gueuze, tops my list for the category and very nearly overall.

Here we go, beer #1 of 1001.  On my epic journey through the new book, 1001 Beers You Must Taste Before You Die.  I picked this up just yesterday at Hi Time, not knowing it was so highly rated, and Im glad I did.  The beer has ample carbonation as the cork easily pops out and the beer almost fizzes over out of my glass.  The head does not care to stick around though and quickly dissipates.  All that is left is a thin ring of white bubbles around the edge.  The coloring is a beautiful golden orange with small, fizzy bubbles.Aromas of flowers, apples, and citrus.  Smells absolutely amazing.  Taste is sweet initially with a sour finish - hints of citrus, apples, salt, and bitterness.  Finishes bitter, a hint of vinegar, with a refreshing aftertaste.  I could drink this every day for the rest of my life and be happy.  A fantastic start to my journey.

375mL bottle, rated 2/11/10.  White head, transparent amber color, champagne bubbles.   Sweet citrus aroma, with orange peel and slightly musty sour notes.  Initially tastes like orange juice, but as the carbonation fades, a delicious balance between bitter and sour flavors comes out.  Smooth finish, with a gentle fade into orange peel flavor.  A very gentle gueuze.

Thanks to exiled for sharing this beer.

The beer pours a hazy brownish-orange color with a white head. The aroma is tartness with some sugar and not much funk. The flavor is tart lemon, oak, vanilla with some citrus and little to no funk. The beer is very, very dry and very juicy tasting. It finishes very tart. Low-medium carbonation and a thin mouthfeel.

37.5cL btl. pours a hazy straw color with white head. aroma is tart with apple and a touch of vinegar. mouthful is puckering with a crisp tart refreshing goodness. mouth waters for a bit after the finish. what a refreshing beverage! i gotta get more gueuze in my life!!
Bottle.Hazy yellow with white head.Aroma of citrus and earth,crispy with note of acid and hay,mild bitter and dry mouthfeels,well balanced and refreshing with dry finish.
hazy yellow with thick head. lightly tart nose with lemon, wet hay, horse blanket. drinks light and fruity with citrus and grape, crisp earthy notes. finishes dry and tart with just a touch of sweet.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2010 Bottled 375ml. Vintage 2003. Courtesy of bierkoning. Mindblowingly fantastic, complex and delicious. Nuff said. Big thanks! Rerate: Staying with the initial rating. Incredibly, indefinitely wonderful.
Bottle from shrubber 85. Hazy straw color. Cider vinegar aroma. Thin acidic body. Musty acidic flavor. This was probably wasted on me, as its not one of my favorite styles.
Champagne aroma. Bright orange in colour. Slight sour flavour, short dry finish. Very refreshing.

Bottle.  Clowdy orange gold with nice white head.  Sweaty leather, oak, grass, and grapefruit.  Medium sourness, grapefruit, touch of saltiness and sweetness, and a nice carbonation.  Overall, a nice gueuze.
Pours cloudy amber with a large white head. Aroma is horseblanket, leather, fruity and grapefruit. Flavour is sweet at first, horseblanket, grapefruit. Dry aftertaste.

Bottle @ Oud Pruim, Beersel. Qutie clear orange beer with a thin but creamy head. Nice sparkling. Tha aroma is very sharp, acidic, oaky and a bit lemony. The taste is very dry, acidic and sour. Blows your gums away still tasting well matured and refreshing. Complex palate is sharp and spritzy at first developing really mellow woodness in the finish. About medium bodied. Noble drink.

Bottle.  Pour is slightly cloudy copper with almost no head.  Aroma is quite sweet with funky notes and a touch of vinegar.  Probably the sweetest smelling gueuze that I have ever smelled.  Also mildly fruity with notes of green grape and peach.  Flavor is also sweet with notes of funky gueuze, blueberry, raspberry, and light malt.  Interesting and tasty.  Very easy to drink and quite tasty.

37.5 cl bottle. Pours hazy pale orange. Sour wet horse nose. Cowshed smell. Also citrusfruit aromas & peaches. Great taste, not that sour after all.
Very good geuze.

Rating Nr. 1000!  A big thank to my girlfriend, without her patience this number of ratings would not have been possible! 
Bottle. The aroma is sour, strong aroma of yeast, weak fruity smell. A very refreshing aroma. The head is rather small, white and creamy-fizzy with a normal duration. The body is clear and orange. The gueuze is very dry and sour in the mouth, very refreshing and great tasting, very hard to describe. The body is light to medium strong, very dry and with a lot of carbonation. The finish is very astringent. A really great beer!

2009 bottle poured into a tulip glass... pours a deep golden with a big 3 finger white head.... quarter inch creamy white head throughout.  huge sour notes fill the nose... lovely acidic qualities.  some tart apple notes...  a bit of barnyard funk to it - but not much.  medium body with more tartness and apple / white grape notes throughout.  dry acetic finish.  amazing beer - a true Gueuze and a pleasure to drink.

A: A vigorous pour reveals a hazy orange beer with a fluffy white head.

S: The smell is absolutely great. Green apples, acidic and acetic, a lot of funk, and some vinous character.

T: A lot of tartness, as one would expect. The fruit components are sour, green apples and white grapes. Some funk, but not quite as much as I would have expected.

M: The beer has a medium body, lively carbonation and a crisp, dry, finish.

D: I love wild beers, and this one certainly lived up to my expectations. Its unfortunate we have to pay so much for these great beers here in the US, because I would love to drink them more often.
Appearance is gold with small white head. Aroma of tart and funk with hints of fruit. Flavor is souer and funky without being to extreme. Overall a really great beer.

375 ml caged and corked bottle.  Served in a tulip, the beer pours a slightly hazy gold/orange color with about an inch off-white head.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  Aroma is tart/sour apples, vinegar, lemon peel and some funk.  The taste is similar to the aroma, it tastes like tart green apples, lemon, funk, and a bit of yeast and peaches.  Nice lingering tart finish, too.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, it has good carbonation and finishes dry.  Drinkability is good, its smooth and enjoyable to drink.  Overall I think this is a very good gueuze, Ill definitely pick this up again the next time I find a bottle.

Bottle, pours hazy gold w/voluminous pristine white head, aroma is vinegar, hay, and general barnyard, flavor is sour and tangy with some grassy notes, super dry finish, tons of funk in the aroma and flavor, excellent example of the style

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2011 375 mL bottle.  Pours a hazy deep gold with a big white head.  Big acidic and acetic aroma with a fair amount of funk, lemon, tart raspberry.  Flavor is equally big, with acetic, sour lime and lemon up front, backed up by varying levels of funkiness, white wine, saltiness.  All bone dry and delicious.Rerate 1/13/11: Picked up one of these to rerate, and wow, was that a good choice.  Bone dry and delicious indeed.  Absolutely phenomenal.  Original rating was a ridiculously low 4.3.
Bottle. Very fine beer, i cant say any new things about it so i wont, it is time to enjoy.

A tarty fruity zingy well balanced beer of dried fruits and sour notes.. A good beer for sure. Poured from 33cl into beermerchants glass. Lovely head. Very cloudy in the glass. Well balanced. Could do with better aroma however prefer the 3 Fontenien. Just love this as a classic style. I want it on tap mind.

Bottle from Theatre of Wine, Greenwich. Cloudy golden pour with an off white head. Excellent carbonation. All those lovely gueuze aromas are in there- green apples,cheese,lemon, lime. Plenty of barnyard funkiness. Man alive! That flavour! Full frontal assault of crisp green apples, lemon zest, lactic acid, limes. So distinctive. Palate bursting bitter-sweet mouthfeel. A splendid lemon zest bitter finish. Forgive my French and apologies to all the ladies out there but this is fookin marvelous!!

Bottle thanks to probstk. Massive gusher, half my living room floor is coated with gueuze. Apple and peach aromas, beautiful gueuze aromas. Taste is a beautiful balance of sourness and natural sweetness, lots of apples. I like this one a lot.
Light cloudy orange color, fluffy head. Aroma is sour smelling, flavor is a jaw-clenching sour grapes flavor. Bottle at Knightly Spirits, Orlando.

Nice funky aroma and it pours bright but dark golden with a huge head. The flavor starts out medium funk and then hits hard and sour. It is very smooth for being so sour when it settles so nicely on the palate.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2010 I think I found my new love. This is a new experience for me kind of like when you had your first IPA or Imp. Stout. This was an unclear orange color beer with a nice white head. The aroma had sour fermented fruit, apples, mint, eucalyptus, funky barnyardness. The aroma is amazingly complex. The taste was very sour, overripe light colored fruits with an interesting taste of fruit skins, funkiness, & very mouth puckering. Every drink I taste something different and is so complex it is hard to put a finger on everything I am tasting. Every time I see this beer I will buy as many as possible at that given time. Should be in the Top 50.

Courtesy of Tony @ OTH.
Pours cloudy golden, light white head.
Aroma mild vinegar, acidic - mild tartness.
Flavor, tingly wood tartness, yeasty, low-med carbonation, light sweetness, sourness is mild and ends with a gentle vinegary mouthfeel.

Poured orange and mostly clear with a short white fizzy head.  Plenty of active carbonation.  The aroma was citrus, yeast, cheese and mild funk.  The flavor was an almost perfect blend of citrus, yeast and funk and sourness.  Thin body and easy drinking.  Very clean and refreshing.  My description of this beer isnt quite doing it justice, but I loved it.

Poured into a snifter with a golden/amber with a thin white head.  Musty funk aroma with citrus and barn/wet blanket smells.  Taste is SOUR.  Brett bomb here with some citrus, mild carbonation, and just straight sour palate.  Sour and smooth because of the little carbonation.  Great brew.  My first rated gueuze! What a great lambik to start with!

Golden orange with small amber hues. The liquid is actually quite clear. A surprisingly big head develops. The head is ivory-colored, shows good retention and leaves big lacings as it dissipates and finally settles into a nice lid of foam.

A nice smell with a good mixture of tart fruity aromas (mostly lemon) and ripe fermenting apples, with big additional notes of horse blanket and a general funkiness. Some puckering vinegar, white bread, spices and grassy notes as well.

A great taste with a strong acidity. The sourness really grabs hold of you as it makes the cheeks feel like theyre making out with a nine volt battery. Musty apples and a note of white bread in the mouth, coupled with yeast and earth. Heres not a lot of sweetness to balance the massive acidity. However, delightful, at least semi-sweet, flavors of lemon develops and get accentuated as well as turning really sour towards the finish. The funkiness is restrained, but some notes of horse blanket and barnyard is noticeable, and the funk actually gets more pronounced as the beer warms up. The finish is incredibly long with a forever lasting sourness that is right on the edge of becoming too assertive. Notes of lemon pits and minerals are the only things that manages to break through the fantastic acidity.

Medium body, effervescent character. The beer gets a slightly sharp edge due to the lively carbonation. The finish is not overly dry, but after a while the mouth gets really dry from this one.

A high quality gueuze. Complex and sophisticated, yet with plenty of that unique spontaneous edginess. Its delightfully sour (it could even give some of the beers from Cantillon a go regarding levels of acidity) but it never goes out of hand. I would also like to especially emphasize how great the finish in this one is, really magnificent.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

375ml Bottle.  Nice pop on the cork with CO2 vapors pouring out.  Fizzy pour that is reminiscent of champagne.  Golden straw color with a quickly dissipating head.  Nose is slightly tart, dry and earthy with a bit of bitter grapefruit.  Flavor is well balanced with some sweetness and a late blooming pervasive sourness.  Definitely has lots of Brett character that gives the typical barnyard funk of old blankets, stale straw and mildewed cheese.  Carbonation level is pretty high and helps the complex flavors burst on the tongue.  I love the way the sourness creeps up on you.  A definite winner that is surprisingly easy to drink.

Bottle.  Pours a lightly hazy caramel hued golden orange with a thin white head.  Monstrous funk and vinegar, hay, brett, light sweet caramel.  Medium bodied, smooth and silky.  Leathery brett, dry and funky, big blue cheese sourness.  Finishes up with a long lingering funk and a touch of sweetness.  Loads of brett.  Delicious.

Very nice poor into a tulip glass. It was very golden with minimal head and was very balanced between sweet and sour. It is my favorite Lambic- Gueze to date. It smells very fruity and reminiscent of a cold cider. It was very easy and settling and a joy to drink. The beer is very sweet and has a very nice acidity level with a very refreshing finish. This beer style is slowly becoming my favorite due to the explosive taste and sour finishes. It is a very refreshing low ABV beer that is a must have when available.

375 mL bottle courtesy of tarheels86. Thanks! Pours a hazy orange color with a medium fizzy head. Fair head retention and lacing. Clean, smooth and tart aroma with some barnyard mustiness, citrus and mild tannic funk. Taste is smooth at first with some mild funk and big citrus that builds. Very big citrusy lemon with a bit of sweetness lending itself to a lemonhead candy vibe. Something slightly vegetal at the very beginning. Medium bodied. Very smooth and well balanced. Very tasty.

Bottle from Knightly.  Funky aroma with whiffs of cherry, barnyard, horseblankets.  Overall a musty scent which is nice.  Bright orange-gold color with a huge fluffy off-white head.  A ton of lacing left behind that scatters all over the glass.  This is tart, sour and a bit sharp which leaves a nice mild tingle on the senses.  Flavors are lots of funk, with peaches, cherries and grapefruit.  The sweetness of the beer is countered nicely by a dry numbing.  Insanely drinkable while still being intense.  I dig this and Im starting to dig the style a lot more too.

Pours out a murky straw color with a moderate off white fluffy head. Aroma is of citrus, some funk, barnyard and some hay. Notes of citrus, some funky sour notes, and slight underlying citrus sweetness in there. Another solid beer from a style Im starting to appreciate more and more.

Pours out a yellow orange.  Aroma is rich and rather sour with almost a musty smell that complements notes of sour citrus, hay and horse blanket.  Rather effervescent with a nice complex and sour flavor.  Slightly woody and earthy with a comfortable citrus character.  The sour flavor continues in a nice finish that is a little aggressive but quite enjoyable.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a billowing fizzy head. 
Nose is strong of the pedio and lacto souring, lemon, and peach.
Taste is pretty puckeringly sour. Hints of fruit, lemon, green apple, not too dry either. Truly a world class lambic.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2010 (gr-btl bk-lbl(unfiltered), 375ml, $8, 5%)

hzy-cpr/or, ^eff, mold-wh-head,

aroma: bright-sour-fruit alchl skunk-cabbage §fermented-orange barnyard §mnrl.

taste: ^co2 T1; ^sour, burning acidity, ^funky, co2 T2; grapefruit juice T3.

i get a mix of unripe pineapple and grapefruit seeds. burns my throat, but not sure if thats the high co2 or the acidity -probably the combination. not good by itself IMO, but might be good if paired with the right food, but i cant think of what that would be.  malt flavor is hiding way in the background, and the hops taste more like funky cheese than anything else.

Bottle. Clear deep golden with a fluffy staying off white head. Lots of small bubbles. Dry citric acidic aroma with some notes of honey and camomile. Also some wood and light dust. Citric acidic flavour with some honey, light spice, crispy, light hoppy, barnyard, leather, wet wood and slight vanilla.

A: This baby is a cloudy peachish orange in color with a steay flow of bubbles almost like Champagne. 

S: Lemon with a funk 

T: Pucker up baby this one has kick. The most wonderful sourness of the best citrus your mind could imagine. Finishes dry, I will stop here because I can not describe this brew. 

M: Perfectly carbonated yet dry, like a $100 bottle of Champagne. 

D: Off the charts here, bartender give me another. This baby goes down so smooth I am yearning for more.

Bottle from realale.com. Pours a hazy light orange, a finger of fizzy offwhite head fades quickly to a ring. Aroma is mighty funky, like blue cheese, barnyard, hay and yeast. Some light fruits, a berrylike surness, like mountain cranberries. Flavour is tart, but not overpoweringly so. Nice, dry finish. Mouthfeel is medium to thin, sparkly and refreshing. Good stuff.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2014 Bottle shared by shawnm213- thanks, Shawn!  Pours a clear orange-gold, more yellow at the bottom, with a frothy white head.  Aroma of sour apple, white grapes, lemon, wood, leather, and straw.  Flavor of sour citrus fruits, nectar, funk- very acidic.  Medium bodied, with soft, gentle carbonation, for a nice effervescent mouthfeel.  Interesting beer, and maybe my lower rating is because I dont understand this style as well.  Ill revisit this. Re-Rate: I wasnt ready for this back in the day. 2009, that is. I appreciate it now.

Either I got a bad bottle of this., or I am really swimming against the tide. Ive enjoyed other lambics Ive had, but this was terrible (maybe its just the gueze style I dont like). This poured a champagne color with little head and some carbonation. Unfortunately, both the nose and taste were a rancid mixture of very sour apples and vinegar. Early on, I kept thinking maybe the sour would be followed by a sweet sensation, a la Flemish Sours, but instead, it just kept getting more sour and acidic. Ended up cleaning the drain.

Pours a cloudy lemon orange with a fluffy off white head about 2 fingers thick.  Nose starts with very tart citrus giving way to must and horse blanket, cat piss.  Flavor starts very tart with tons of juicy citrus, finishes medium dry.

Hazy Nectarine pour with  light frothy head.  Funky Gueze aroma with lemon zest, some oakiness, and a sharp lemon tartness.  Tartness is ballance a bit by a nice breadiness.  Flavor is sharp lemon sour, very tart with a touch of funk and a lovely crisp effervescent mouthfeel.  In your face gueze, not apologetic, just the way I like it.  Fantastic

Finally tracked down this bad mother of a beer.  Golden orange pour with some while pillowy head.  Aroma of sour citrus, funk, leather.  Sour flavor with a strong cheesy funk.  Sourness really opens up as it sits.  Strong, citrus sour and a bit of hay. Nice, delicate mouthfeel.  Tart, leathery finish. Pretty standout gueuze.

bottle - Pours cloudy orange with a fizzy body and a one finger head.  The aroma is full of wild yeast along with some nice fruity character.  The flavor includes malt and fruit tones reminiscent of white grapes but the wild yeast funkiness is dominant.  The funk kind of smacked me in the face for the first couple sips but became very enjoyable as I continued drinking.  Its a light to medium bodied brew with a bubbly palate.  Very good.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2009 Hazy amber pour with an effervescent body and small white head. Aroma is a funk fest- earth, nectar, citrus, horse blanket, lemon and acidic woodyness, and a slight bready yeast behind all the tartness. Flavor is an acidic sour-puss inciting funky citrus-nectar journey. This is a rude gueuze and Im in love with it. A slight acetic acid puckering, smacking tart blast comes through with every sip. Palate is medium bodied, slippery, billowy and pillowy in its effervescence. Quite amazing.  December 14th Re-rate.

Pours a cloudy apricot with a small white head. Aroma holds massive amounts of funk, barnyard, lemon zest, orange, horseblanket, and perhaps a bit of oaky woodiness as well. Flavor is great; very tart, with lots of funk, lemon, and other citrus. Got a hit to the tongue that reminded me of a more aggressive and less sweet yellow Sour Patch Kid; this beer is flat out rude. Palate attacks the tongue, but somehow I still want to drink more and more. Awesome gueuze.
All kinds of barnyard flavor and funky sourness go into the consummately smooth bottle.  Im gonna have to buy this stuff more regularly.

Bottle from Binnys. Pours murky golden orange with quickly fading spongy beige head. Nose is strong sour yeast and some citrus tart. Flavor is very sharp and sour, slightly lemon with hints of leather and musk. Being unfiltered adds a nice touch to this one. Very good.

Pours a beautiful, lively golden orange color with a nice white head. The aroma floors me. Its sour, funky, smoky with lemon, leather, white grapes and, forgive me but,... cleaning product. The flavor is very tart and complex. Grapefruit seed, leather, wood, grapes, lemon pepper are easily picked out. Despite everything going on here, its very smooth, refreshing, and drinkable. A classic beer no doubt.
SPRITZY DRY sour lemony wonderful just a few phrases that describe this wonderfull beer

Bottle. Pours a golden beer with some chillhaze and a large white head. The aroma is acidity, leather, wood and citrus. The flavor is acidity, citrus and grapefruit. The palate is dry and the carbonationlevel is low. Overall a champagnelike beer.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2010 Gold pour.  Very fruity aroma with some tart apples.  Dry and earthy aromas with some light toothpick smell.  Flavor is dry and sour and very nice.  sour apples, light vinegar.  Very nice.

Bottle.

Pours golden with some carbonation but no head.

Dry grape aroma.
Taste of sour candy.
Bottle. Fresh and fruity gueuze. Sour apples, citrus and some sweet funk. Not as complex as the Cantillons but very refreshing and easy to drink.

375 ml bottle at Greens on Ponce De Leon, and the last one at that! Yes, I am so happy they had this! Poured like a masterpiece! Nice fluffy head that is slowly fading away. Nice translucent dark orange color. Looks like a lovely beer to me. Ah, this beer has a lovely aroma. Sweet/sour fruit aroma coming through along with skunk and funk! Also, nice subtle brett smell. Even at a bit colder of a temperature this thing is still pungent as anything I have ever smelled. Hits the back of my nostrils..oh so pungent. Man the aroma just keeps developing, I am getting some charred wood, and leather as it warms up. Wow, taste is damn good. Nice sour taste at first, and then the thing really turns SOUR. Nice sour lemon and brett flavor. Also the sweet flavor mixes in quite well with the sour flavor. You get the best of both worlds. This beer just leaves a wonderful sweet fruit, sour, and brett taste in my mouth. Even after tasting it and licking my lips I get that sour flavor. Ah a little charred wood and leather in the flavor as well. Very smooth beer. Damn, I wish Greens had more of this. By far one of the most delicious beers I have tried thus far.
