12.7oz, corked & caged bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a very bright, gold with a thick, bubbly white head and solid lacing. aroma is pure, excellent, brett funk with big citrus notes of sour lemon, granny smith apple, sour white grape, with notes of barnyard, hay, burlap, dry leather, and wet wood. flavor is excellent and wonderfully tart with big, funky brett notes, sour apple skins, lemon zest, and a touch of sweet apricot with milder dry, grassy, barnyard, light malts, and earth leaving a dry, tart finish. palate is medium bodied, very dry and crisp, with a solid mouth puckering sourness. overall, a damn nice gueuze that was a great introduction to the style.

Bottle from K&L in Redwood City.  Pours a slightly hazy brilliant golden color with a large white head and good lacing.  Aroma is what youd want from a great gueuze: citrus/lemon tartness and funk, maybe a touch of sweet malt as well.  Flavor is funky tartness and lemon with some sweet pale malt poking through.  Extremely well-balanced and good.  Palate is sharp and acidic with soft carbonation and medium body.  Very drinkable, not at all overly sour.  This may be the best gueuze Ive ever had.

Bouteille verte de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez Altair. Arôme: Odeur de citron et de pommes sûrettes. Apparence: La couleur est blonde. Présence dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de pommes vertes et de citron avec une pointe de pêches. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement citronné. (Rating #2697)

Beer nr 100! Bottle, 37,5 cl. A beautiful, clear, light golden beer with bubbles rising beautifully and a medium creamy lacing white head that lasts till the end. The aroma is sour with some fruity notes, smelling very good in the nose. The taste is a good, complex mix of nice sourness, with some fruitiness, a little hop and a light sweet touch in the end. Dry aftertaste, very refreshing  and very good gueuze, one of the best certainly! The perfect beer to be nr 100 to be rated.
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 Hazy pale orange with scant white head.  Aroma of citrus and must.  Sour complex taste with apples, lemons, and sweat.  Nicely dry throughout.

Bottle. Hazy orange with a white head. The aroma was really special, hard to describe. A little yeast was there, and some citrus, but  also like a well-used horse blanket? Vinegar perhaps? A very peculiar smell.

The flavor contained a lot of green apples, citrus and a certain sweetness. The solvent was pretty dry. Sourness was great, a lot of carbonation. I like this one!

Bottle 0,375L (from  Huis van de Geuze)
Pours slightly hazy, golden with a relatively large and lasting, also lacing, white head. Very dry, complex and rather delicious aroma of sour apples, citric fruits, pretty strong bretty notes of barnyard& wood and some peachy sweetness. Starts with a feeling of carbons and citrus. Continues with a fruit sweetness (peach) and apple. Lovely sourness starts to grasp the palate and flavor. More citrus, funk, raw apples and leather. Very nice palate is well-carbonated and lively ending up sticky, acidic bone-dry. Marvelous beer!

Source:375 mL bottle purchased at Greens in Atlanta. 
Glass:Lindemans Lambic glass. 
Appearance:Hazy gold pour with a two finger, bubbly white head.  
Aroma:Sour apples and grapes with oak and funk. 
Flavor:Tart green apple, lemon and limes.  Sweet and earthy funk finish. 
Palate:Light body with bubbly carbonation.
Overall:Not sure how this is a top 100 beer, as I have been more impressed with some of the other gueuze out there.  Still a good beer.

(Bottle at Ørsted Ølbar on 2009-09-17) Golden and lightly hazy. Small white head. Sourness, wood, fruitiness and lightly sweetness in aroma. Dry, medium bodied palate with medium carbonation. Wood, sourness, malts, fruitiness, lightly vomit, bitterness and some citrcness in taste. Sour aftertaste. A really great gueuze.

First dip into gueuze here.  Pours a pale hazy orange with thick creamy white head, lots of lacing and head retention.  Aroma obvious of tartness, earthy character, citrus, and an expected funk.  Flavor matches well and makes for a really enjoyable alternative.  I will definitely be experimenting a bit more in this area, this was pretty dang good.

Pouts a hazy dark orange color with a thin white head.  Aroma is funk, citrus, a little bit of band-aid, but not terrible.  Flavor is beautiful, bright and tart with a great almost lemon kick.  Palate is dry without being overwhelming and the tart notes in this beer hit the tongue perfectly.  Fantastic Gueuze.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2009 (bottle) pours a hazy golden-orange colour with a massive pillowy head and great lacing. aroma is beautifully citric with lots of perfume, some subdued funk and light pale malts. flavour is again dominated by citrus notes, with some hints of leather and a lovely dry, sweet-bready finish. light to medium body with lively carbonation. very well-balanced and refreshing!
Botle from Sprinkle.  Goulden color with nice carbination.  taste was sour, kinda leom and citrus flavor.  I like this funky beer taste  Nice earthy aftertaste

375 ml bottle from Sams Clybourne (Chicago, IL). Poured into a narrow tulip. Pours an almost layered dull gold that has some orange notes throughout, hazy and well carbonated, a big slightly offwhite head adorns the brew and dies down to a small layer, a little lacing. Aromas are pretty bretty, featuring horseblanket and barnyard funk above the citrusy sourness beneath. Vinegar, lemon and grapefruit, and some fairly acidic feel and sour peach. Initial is light, with good tart sourness up front, lemon and grapefruit with a touch sweeter side further in, moving into good bretty funk. Acid becomes a nice level, balancing well after a few sips, fruity citrus and peach move into light sweetness, fruits, with brett and funk complimenting well, juicy melange of fruit sticks out though and sticks in the finish and aftertaste with good acidity, sourness, tart, with light bitterness. Mouth coat is tart, but preaches a good sweet fruitiness as well. Really grows on me as faint rubber comes in towards the back end, light vinegar, faint cheesiness. Largely, fruit forward with sturdy sourness and matching brett to boot. Light bodied, but with enough oomph to bring the flavors forward more than other Gueuze Ive had. Very very nice beer.

(Bottle, Akkurat, Stockholm, 26 Aug 2009) Pale amber colour with frothy, off-white head. Acidic, tart and fruity nose with vinegar, grapefruit, horse blanket and funk. Tart, fruity taste with notes of grapefruit, lemon peel, funk, almonds and a harsh, acidic finish. Medium body, dry. The acidity isnt quite as wild as in some other traditional versions of the style, which gives this beer an excellent balance and a character of its own. Lovely beer!

Bottle shared with savvy1982... Thanks Kyle! Pours a hazy straw colour with a small head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is tart and fruity. Peach, wild yeast, medicine, band-aid, onion, hay and barnyard funk on the nose. The taste is quite balanced and delicate for a gueuze. Complex notes of barnyard funk, horse blanket, peach fuzz, penicillin, straw, citric acid, onion and a nice dry/bitter finish. Soft mouth feel. Damn tasty.

Bottle. Shared with hobbersr. Pours hazy amber/orange, fresh, lively carbonation, some solids. No lacing to speak of. Aroma is spicy and funky, with dried pineapple, apples, mild oak and brett. As the beer warms, dirty hay, barnyard, and dusty notes start to come to the fore. Palate is more spice and funk, really surprised by how spicy this gueuze is. Juicy palate, fresh peach and apricot peel, mouthcoating, very well balanced, finish is grapefruit, sweatsocks, and grapeskins/tannin. An excellent gueuze, not as piercingly sour as some, but extraordinarily balanced and complex.

So apparently this is available in our area but for some reason the only store I could find it at is the wonderful 6 and Save in New Kensington.  Been hunting this one for a while.  Scent is some hefty funk over a hint of spice.  Good.  Appearance is very nice with one finger of white head that sticks around over a murky, bubbly read liquid.  Taste is sour and bready, lemons, sour grapes, very light spice and a nice sour aftertaste.  I love this.  Palate is somewhere in the middle in body, pretty high in carbonation, sticky and lingering.  A really great gueuze.
Bottle. Golden yellow pour with significant white head. Sour in the nose that lasts.  Lots of funk nice gueuze, easy drink with nice carbonation.
Fairly complex and sour. Aroma is sour, tart, fruity, woody and a little winey. Flavor is citrus dominated with wood and tart cherry. Very puckering and prickly.
Pours a cloudy orange color with a nice amount of white head. Has a sour, woody, brett smell. Has a taste similar to the smell. Starts off tart and finishes sour.

Amber with a low head. Woody and sour aroma, some grape fruit too. The flavour is perfectly balanced for a geuze, not too sour, but complex insted: lemon, a little vinegear, stale, champagne. Highly drinkable and refreshing.

375ml caged and corked bottle served in a tumbler.  Cloudy golden orange pour with a thin, lasting off-white cap.  Slick lace.  The aroma included wood, light lemon, berries, and soured wheat.  Acidic and sour.  The flavor had acidic lemon, grapefruit,  moderately sour citrus, dry oak, and also a soft, fruity sweetness.  Very oaky with a nice funkiness.  Crisp and light-bodied.  Highly drinkable and quenching/refreshing.  I think this bottle was fairly young, so Ill have to re-rate an aged bottle that has had some time to develope.
Flaske: Superflot lys orange øl med et rigtig flot skumhoved. Duft af stald. God syrlighed i smagen, og ret tør selvom den stadig er forholdsvis ung. Meget drikbar og kompleks.

cork: x0206 .. drank late in the first quarter of 2009 .. . woooweee! huge crazy smell, from wood, malt vinegar, sourness, etc... . huge tartness to this brew.. . the lord works in mysterious ways! .. .  very refreshing and razor cut clean! .. . carpe diem! .. . beautifully balanced! no thing seems out of place! .. . thats what i call a beer!

Bottle pours hazy light amber color with white head.  Aroma is tart, acidic, funk, lemon, musty, and vinegar.  Tingly mouthfeel as there is a lot of carbonation true to the style.  Flavor follows the nose exactly and is very tart.  Very delicious.
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2009 Pours light cloudy orange with a thin white head. Tart grapefruit and funk nose and flavor. Decent oak finish.

Lieve colore ambra,schiuma abbondante,al naso è morbida e pepata.In bocca inizialmente acida e secca,per poi lasciare spazio ad una fruttata acidità di mele,limoni.Piacevolmente bevibile e rinfrescante! Eccellente
Bottle from Andreas Fält. Cloudy orange golden color with white head. Sour citrusaroma. Taste sour horseblanket yeast citrus grapefruit apple herbs.

Stone Sour Fest, San Diego 2009.

Slightly cloudy yellow color. The aroma is clearly sour and the taste has a big sour kick to it. Slightly vinegary but none the less good.

(37.5cl bottle, vintage 2005) Hazy, murky orange colour with a short and diminishing, slightly off-white frothy head. Sour and woody aroma with notes of brett. Sour flavour with a tinge of malty sweetness, light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Bone dry Lambic-character with shy hints of green apples and notes of citrus, accompanied by notes of barnyard; dry and sourish tart finish. Balanced Gueuze (07.VII.09).

375ml bottle @ In De Wildeman in Amsterdam, Netherlands. Pours golden orange with a loose off-white head. Aromas of cider vinegar, straw bails and light malts. The palate is sour and dry initially giving way to a delightful citrus fruitiness (apples, lemons, pineapple) and a just-right amount of sweetness. Medium bodied with a crisp champagne-style liveliness. Amazingly refreshing and drinkable. Top quality.

37.5 cl into snifter.  Cork says "Ref A X 2010" which I am guessing means best buy 2010. Descent white head that fades fast, nice orangish golden body.  I am not even going to delve into the details here, this thing is sour, puckering, funky, not over-carbonated (like many in the style), oaky, inviting, dry, and very balanced for a sour.  Overall: buy one. A bit of a weird almost chemically tang bite in the flavor for a second or two, but it disappears quick enough to not take away from the quality too much.

From the Vegas trip stash... 1st Gueuze I think. Poured out a hazy light orangish beer with a big thick white cap that gets it done. Initially it blew me away but soon after I realized that as much as I appreciate the aroma, there just was not any appeal personally. An odd musty barnyard smell, sour lemon and pretty much outright rank which I guess is good in this case, cold tongue sandwich, cherries, slight sweetness. The taste was more of the same with more sourness, lemon, apple, grass, lots of yeast, mild but good spices, misc. wood and the expected stiff funk. Super tart and sour! The mouth feel is very tart and drying with a spicy, musty, tart finish. Very interesting. Will I rush out for more? No chance.

(37.5cl bottle thanks to petematte46) Rating #100.

Pours a pale opaque yellow with great head and lacing. Nose is alcohol, sour cherry, and funky. Taste is bitter/sour and puckers the inside of my mouth. Finish is fantastic. Really appreciative of this one.

Flavour and aroma wise one of my favourite Gueuzes. Very funky with a balanced acidity, lemon, cheese, animals, hay and acidic apples. Mouthfeel is a bit watery but its forgiven as it actually adds to its drinkability. Lovely luxurious dry finish.

Bottle (recolte 2005): Orangey coloured, visible carbonation, cloudy, small - slowly collapsing - loose white head; solid nose: citric acid, horse blanket and a distinctive touch of wood; solid dry sourish flavour, a bit fizzy, medium bodied; lingering finish: citric acid, green apples, wood and lactic acid. Excellent, complex Gueuze, moreish..........

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2012 well a good bottle of this is better to drink than just about anything :/  but some batches are better than others.  bad batches good, good batches world class.   
 
bottle. REF C X 2010 whatever that means.  pours a dark orange with gold and brown hints depending on the circumference of the glass. bright citrusy, grapefruit, sour apple, funky basement, lactic acid sourness.  perfect.   awesome.  crisp, clean.   pretty acidic.   just about perfect. some batches have been better than others, in my experience, but this is surely the best batch Ive ever had.  what a beer.  

 
REF A X 2010.  these 2010 bottles have been kickass.   awesome balance.  super citrusy and dry.  perfect cowhide leathery funk.  right up my alley.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2011 375mL 2008. Pours a hazy copper with a very lively, soda-like white head that dissipate but leaves a good thin layer to protect this lambic. Tons of yeast floaties in there too. Aroma is apple cider vinegar, white grape, leather, some baby powder, and other funky notes. Taste up front is sparkling apple juice then moves to ultra sourness- insanely sour. Finish shows off with fruity notes of raspberries, strawberries, and blueberries. Very drinkable and fun to try. Im not a lambic expert but this seems well executed and I like it. 7/10/2009 7/4/9/5/17=4.2375mL FX2011. Huge white grapefruit and sharp citrus nose. Taste is perfection- similar to b2 RR Beatification with massive leathery, sharp citrus, big grapefruit explosion. Mouthwatering with lactic acidity. No acetic, no aceto. Pretty much perfect geuze that is overlooked far too often because it doesnt have the hype factor of Cantillon and 3 Fonteinen. Maybe Girardin should make more special edition stuff ;) 8/20/2011 9/4/9/5/18=4.5

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2011 Bright golden color, with a bit of amber, and a bit of lace. Aroma of green apples, apple cider, barnyard, citrus, and some biscuity maltiness. Very tangy, but with controlled sourness. Flavors of green apples, lemon, and some dusty funk. There is a lovely malt sweetness there too, floating behind thensour edge and crystalline dryness. Really great balance, and highly drinkable. One of the best bes anywhere.

Rating #700. Pours hazy copper color with white head. Funky barnyard, leather aromas. Tart lemon rind flavor with lots of sourness. Light to medium body with lively carbonation and a dry finish. Excellent.

Pours a delightful medium amber with a two finger off white head.  Nice funky aroma with some green grape and citrus.  Flavor is complex and refreshing, with grapefruit, green apple, funk, and some sourdough.  Very crisp and refreshing without being too sour.  This is a very fine effort.

Bottle. Deep golden with a small lasting egg white head. Aromas of wood, musty basement, apples, dirty dog and berries. Tart and dry flavour with notes of balsamic vinegar, wood, sour berries and lemons.

girardin black label gueuze
cloudy light gold, yellowish thick foam
very funky aroma, citrus, especially lemon peel
fairly high on the sour scale, but very little vinegar, mostly lemon and horsey funk
super dry and astringent, a bit thin, even for gueuze

Bottle shared by the powerful durhambeer - thanks, Bob! Very nice hazy orange pour with a much more lusty head than I expected from a gueuze. Splendid tart apple aroma, with dry must and wood. Some vinous notes for sure, as Bob suggested. The finish is sour in a particularly red grapefruit-y way for me. Delicious, complex, and surprisingly drinkable.
Bottle. Pours a bubbling golden orange with a white head. Brett, sweet tarts, lemon in aroma and taste. A pretty good Gueuze

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2012 Bottle. Huge head with excellent duration. Color is hazy golden. Aroma and taste are sour with lots of lactose acid, but still fairly mild and sweet in comparison to other gueze beers. Very enjoyable. Rerated at fonefan tasting.

Ill start this review with a disclaimer this beer probly deserves better marks and commentary then Im about to give but I hate this style so much I have little good to say about it. Hazy golden tan body with a thin skiff floating on top. Aroma is burnt rubber. This smells horrid its making my stomach jump each time I take a sniff. Insane sour taste with some burnt rubber but not as much as in the aroma. Did I just taste baby shit? Im loving the intense dry sour flavour of this beer but I cant get passed the rubber/moldy diaper flavour its making me cringe with each sip. Apple and lemon show up in the finish. I hate this style of beer, thanks Gully for sharing but me thinks this was wasted on me.

Notes from 4 ounce sample from bottle at Pizza Port Belgian Beer Fest in March 2009.  Pours a cloudy but rather bright yellow with thin layer of head.  Aroma is sweet with lemon but also has a good amount of funk.  Flavor of lemon and grapefruit -- tart not sweet.  There is a sharp funk present in the flavor as well.  Grapefruity sour finish.

Bottle. Golden colour with a white fast shrinking head. Aroma: Cheese, horse blanket, farmhouse, almost more funky then sour. Taste:  More sour, light cheese, light wheat, lemon, sour green apples, funk, yeast. Balanced. Very drinkable. I really like it.

Bottle.  Aroma has leather and musky yeast, citrus, and funk.  Hazy medium orange hue with an average sized off-white foamy head  that mostly diminished and left great lace.  Flavor is sour, sweet and finishes tart and fresh.  Palate is medium bodied and lively.  Very good and very sour but not too acidic.  Lovely.

[2027-20090303] 375mL bottle. Mild plastic aroma with yeast sour and sludge barrel notes. Clear, golden amber body with a quick foamy off-white head. Sour yeast (no sludge) flavour with some plastic and fresh leafiness. Medium body is quite sour. Lovely sourness.
(w/ jerc)

375ml bottle corked and caged courtesy of fishingnet.  Corked was a bit wedged in there, so I ended up using the corkscrew to get it out.  Pours a clear deep golden color with a slight orange hue to it.  Thin but lasting white head that forms a nice ring around the edge of my glass.  Nose is lemon, apple, vinegar, wood, with wet funky barnyard characteristics and on the dry side.  Taste is similar, tart and funky with some dry woody notes on the end and maybe a bit medicinal but not in a bad way.  Feels great on the tongue with well balanced carbonation and body.  I have shared a bottle of this one before in the past, but this is the first time that I have had a bottle to enjoy from start to finish.  Must buy some more of this fore sure.  Thanks Ben!

This may be my first "sour" experience that Ive actually enjoyed.  Very tart & citrusy with a huge pungent aroma.  Pours a cloudy copper with a quickly settling head.  Some apple/citrus in the nose.  Full mouthfeel that bites very hard at the edge and back.  Leaves a pleasant coating on the front of yer teeth.  Not so strong as to immediately turn ya off, though.  Very, very interesting.
POurs a murky gold. Nose is very tart acid, some citrus, lemon. Flavor is VERY tart acidic, vinegar. Some refreshing citrus notes. Funky as hell with slight yeast backbone. Amazing beer.
Bottle Pours out a hazy orange topped with a small white head. Aroma sourness, wood, and some sour apple. Tast of tons tart and sour. Lots of pucker. A tast one.

Orange-gold pour with a big, rocky, white head.  Loads of sour funk in the aroma with some hints of chardonnay, oak, green apple, lemon zest, grass, grain,  leather, and a little sweetness that i cant quite describe.  The acidity and sourness immediately hits the tongue first but then cherry, strawberry, and lemon hints start to develop.  The malt flavors are grassy, dry grains.  Again the flavor has a little sweetness to it that Im not sure how to describe.  Medium body with lots of carbonation that finishes very dry and clean.  This is definitely a well crafted gueuze and the complexity and quality reflect that.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2010 Bottle. Nice golden/orange color. Aroma is citrus and fresh with some funky and oakey notes. Taste is citrus,green apples,sour,tart and funky. What more can you demand? Really balanced and dry finish.

(Vintage x0109) Nice petite pop to the cork. About a 1/4 inch thick head with medium sized bubbles. Body is orange marmelaide colored, filled with floating stuff throughout the glass. Aromas of well worn shoe leather. Flavor explodes in your mouth. Tons of sourness (lactobacilis?) akin to unripe Kiwi with that underlaying shoe leather. Most definately a sipping beer to enjoy for several minutes. For anyone that really enjoys this type of beer, this is a classic. For anyone that likes "normal" beers and are affraid to try out of the ordinary things, youre going to freak after trying this one. :-)
bottle thanks to lumpy.  poured a hazy light gold with a white head that stays.  aroma of cherry, wool, and ash tray.  flavor was much the same.  light body and high carbonation.  this was very good.

Bottle thanks to Lumpy, Pours a cloudy gold with nice fizzy white head. Aroma is great, some farmhouse brett, tart, funky. Flavor is very tart and funky, strong. Mouthfeel is medium body with low-medium carbonation. Overall, VERY tasty shit!!!!!!!

boittle, thanks to lumpy, orangish color with thin foam, aroma of smokey cherry and white pepper, funkiness, flavors of musty dry storage, sour cherries,some chalk, bitter with a great body and dry finish

UPDATED: APR 20, 2011 Bottle shared by Andreasen11. 
It pours golden with a foamy off white head. 
Aroma is citrus mainly dominated by grape and hay with weak notes of vinegar. 
The flavour is extremely sour citrus with apple and woody notes and a tart finish. 
Re-rate from 8-3-7-3-15=3,6. 
Lovely aroma with dry citrus, humid cellar and wood. 
Flavour is sour, dominated by lemon and wood, with weak notes of fruit.

375 ml bottle- pours an orange golden with very good clarity and moderate head. Very delicate lacing. Nose- lemon, must, oak, hay. Taste- juicy sourness, dry green apple, lemon zest and dry oak finish. Medium carbonation, and actually has a smooth texture. Drinkable as all hell.
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2009 Bottle. Clear orange/golden colour with a small white head. Rich aroma and taste of yeast, fruits and citrus. Well balanced gueuze.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2009 [Bottle] shared by milkmandan. Pours gold with an effervescent white head. Aroma is chlorine, lots of funk, lots of barnyard character, minerally and sharp, and lots of lemon and orange peel. Flavor has a moderate to high sourness, and is funky, very minerally and gravelly, and dry. The mouthfeel is just a little watery though.

Bottle. Poured a hazy amber color with a large creamy white head that lasted. Good citrus and yeast aroma. Medium body. Moderate sour fruit flavor with a long citrus finish. Very good refreshing citrus brew. Holly crap this stuff is good.

Bottle shared.  Beer poured a cloudy orange with lots of carbonation.  Aroma is very funky - a little hard for me to describe with my slim lambic/sour knowledge.  Taste is also funky.  Some oak and plenty of tart fruit.  Body was light and nicely carbonated.  Finish was tart.  A very good lambic.

Bottle from Sams Clybourn. Unsure of the vintage, cork says x01m9 or something. Pours a wonderfully clear IPA gold with a fluffy/fizzy white head. Nose is sweet grain, clean acidity, very soft, minimal barnyard if at all, lemons, lactic. Taste is powerful. There is a very dry aspect to this with very green apples and very underripe cherries, tannic type bitterness. I also get a pleasant sweetness in the far reaches, as well as a level of grain. Its funny, I thought I knew what a gueuze should taste like having had a few, but this one to me is gueuze. I need to try the 3F vintage stuff now, I can only imagine it to be perfect... As this one warms, it just keeps getting better. slight skunk from the hops (in a good way), peaches and apricots. I think I get it now, after reading Wild Brews. Its not an acid bomb, its just a perfect beverage...

bottle from Kingom Liquor in Brandon, FL.  my experience with lambics is from european travels and Im not well versed on the style at this point.  that said -- hazy yellow pour with two fingers of bright white head and lots of lacing.  aroma is a mix of soured apple and citrus.  first thought on taste is its far more drinkable than most Ive had.  tart, bitter, sour -- but leaves you wanting more.  long dry vinegar and apple finish.  definitely a style Im looking forward to exploring more and definitely an exceptional beer.  K-8
Very sour aroma. Average, frothy head. Fair lacing.Clear orange body. Heavy bitter and sour flavor. Medium palate.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Powerfull sour aroma. Light bitter and exstremely sour flavor. Very gueuze-like!!!! ofcourse. Long finish. Creamy palate.

aroma : very well balanced citrussy, light vineagre, i like the abcense of funk and stable in this one.
flavor : very sour, very well balanced, between sour and more earthy flavors, tasty. refreshing.

Bottle @ Victory Bar...  Poured a hazy golden-orange with a white head.  Aroma or tart, fruity sugars and maybe a ginger note.  Insanely dry with a vinegar quality that made me pucker a bit.  Sweet. light fruits like apple and citrus with a champagne-esq quality in the finish.
Bottle at Carlsens kvarter. Aroma is sour, fruity, lemon. Flavor is also sour, fruity and hints of lemon. It isn´t as sour as I had expected. Very drinkable.
Hazy yellow/orange pour.  Very sour, tart apple, cherries, lots of funk, and finishes dry.  Good stuff.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 Cloudy orange brew with lovely little white bubbles.

Moulding citrus fruits and white grapefruit. Slight moulding cheese and lemons. Delicate and lovely. Some tight green apple and sorrell aromas make an appearance too.

Not overly sour, this beer. Tickly carbonation pushes vespers of grapefruit and mango over the tongue. Fermented fruit again with light woody notes.

Delicious with some potted crab on white toast.

Aug 10: Just pulled a bottle of this from around the same time, that I had in the cellar for a couple of years.   By comparing notes I seem to have detected more woody vanilla on the nose, maybe through a fading of the fresh fruit that was present before.  It seems that I sound this one to be far more creamy in texture also. And still freaking delicious.
bottle, bitter!!!, sweet, very strong taste,agressive, I still feel the bitterness of the beer two hours later, impressing geuze with an impressive palate!

Bottle from Lone Hill shared with DuffmanSW.  Pours a sparkling golden color with a thin white dissipating head.  Aroma is very funky and musty with a hint of skunk and some citrus and green apple.  Flavor is more tart green apple.  Lots of barnyard funkiness.  Not really complex but still very nice.  Finishes dry.  Light bodied with aggressive carbonation.
(37,50 cl bottle) Sour sweet geuze with a troubled blond color. Tastes very agressive but mellows down very quickly and evenly. A perfect geuze.

bottle, pours bright orange with light red hints, small white head, laces well.  Horseblanket and citrus nose.  Slightly sweet for only a second before turning extremely sour.  This doesnt have the vinegar of others, and thats a good thing.  Its a more subtle(although still really, really sour.)  Dry finish with a strong cottonmouth feeling on the tongue.  Still not my bag, but I have had worse gueuzes.
Bottle from Bierkoning. Amber hazy body with white head. Strong sour nose. Sour, sour and tart taste. Sweet as well. Totally not my thing. Plain awful.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2009 bottle thanks to ...  This one had a few years on it.  Pours a cloudy amber with a white head.  Nose was of vinegar and citrus fruit.  Taste was sour fruit.  Mouthfeel was mouth-puckering sour with some sweetness.  Wow!  Very nice.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Excellent gueuze.  Incredibly musty, sweaty, sour nose.  Flavor makes the taste buds and saliva glands explode, with some wonderful light carbonation that tickles the tongue.  Highly recommended.

12oz bottle. I was wildly disappointed in this beer since I love sours and I love guezes. This unfortunately was not good at all. Not sure why this is so highly regarded unless the bottle I had was bad (hard to tell with a gueze). Nose was highly sulfuric with tart lemon and pear. Taste is quite woody but horribly acidic. Like sucking down vomit. It scorches your throat going down, highly unpleasant. All complexities in the flavor get drowned out by the acidity which is a shame because there is some definite complexity there on the first sip. We barely got through the bottle, everyone hated it, Split with 5 people I probably had to drink 70% of it. Even the other guys in our tasting group who like sours and lambics thought this was atrocious. Very disappointing.

Bottle at TND:  Aroma of tart fruit and bubblegum.  Poured golden/amber/brown in color with a small white head that disappeared.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is heavily tart.  Tastes of tart fruit and some wood.  Medium body.  Dry, fizzy texture.  Lively carbonation.  Tart fruit and slight funk finish.
37,5 bottle. Lot of pressure when opening. Nice head that lasts quite long. A lot of wild carbonation at first. Citrus smell with tones of cream. Tastes is remarkably sweet. Oak hints.

Nice golden-orange color, looks similar to the other gueuzes Ive had. It smells citrusy and maybe some slight musty aromas. Tastes like pears and apples, and more citrus with a big sourness that is great. This is a very good beer but it lacks the funk I found in the cuvee rene which probably makes it a lot more approachable for those who are new to gueuze.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-13-2008 08:40:54

Pours a hazy golden orange with 2 finger fluffy white head. Lacing on the glass is excellent. Sour aroma with subtle hints of citrus. Big sour flavor with hints of lemon. Nicely balanced with some malt sweetness. Medium bodied with some nice carbonation. A wonderful gueze. One of my favs.

bottle shared by psprings...
a vibrant sunny pour... hazy orange gold with a large off white head which lasts as a ring until the glass is empty.

caramel comes on strong in the nose... followed up with a mild stoniness, grass, pineapple, lemon, a slight skunkiness/oily and lots of fresh leafy green herbs. 

the palate is quite tart... not overly since there is some mild malts in the background to keep a balance of sorts. theres notes of lemon rind, mineral/stone, lots of yeasty funk and some tannin-like bitterness. 

the body is unusual... at least uncommon. it is very dry and tart yet it has some oomph and substance which seems atypical... neat-o
8/4/8/5/18/4.3
Color is orange with a generous off-white head. Aroma is sour, with lemon and barnyard and slightly spicy.Flavor is tart with hints of oak and lemon. Very smooth and dry.

Sample enjoyed at Skyview tasting.  I could smell this stuff all night; wonderful sour aroma!  Funky yeast with lemon sour notes that finshed with a mild tartness. I hope I can get some of this in the future.

Thanks a ton TheCheeseMan! 8Pours a nicely carbonated orange amber with a one finger sticky white head. The nose is nicely tart, fruity, pineapple, yeasty, oaky. The flavor is very tart and acidic, lemongrass, acetic bite, lasting tartness, ripe fruit, spicy. The palate is nice and acidic, oaky tartness with a spicy fruity character and some residual tannins. Very nice for my 1300th.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2009 37,5cl bottle, with thanks to TheEpeeist for this excellent bonus.  Pours a hazy golden with a minimal fizzy white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is nice, but less intense than expected, with sour grapes, apples skins, musty funk, and light citrus.  Flavor is nicely sour, with more musty funk, sour apple and grape, and a nice lingering sourness.  Easy to see why this is a Top 100 beer, thanks again Chris!

This pours out with a slightly hazy orange body that practically glows in the glass.  A light white head forms and then fades to a mist resting on top, and at the sides of the glass, soapy bubbles remain.  The aroma is striking.  It is incredibly sour with layers of rotten apples, unripe pears, cheese rind, and pepper.  Nice tart flavor is puckering.  Lemons, oak, acidic, and a slight bitterness in the finish.  Perfect body with a lingering aftertaste.  Pretty much amazing.

Dark clear coppery orange that left big dark sediment stuck to the bottom of the bottle and only a little slips in.  A few fingers of foamy puffy white head form.  Big musty barnyard aroma, lemon acidity and taste is tart, strong sour acidity, funky battery acid and a biting light cherry woodiness.  Love this stuff.

Thanks to weearerockband for sharing this one. Pours a hazy golden orange with a smaller bubbly white head.  Aroma was musty, funky, bready, floral, citrus and perfume.  Flavor a match of teh same with a nice intense tartness.
Bottle: In San Diego a part of lambic & sour ale trastings, extreme bitternes, champaign like very dry.

375 ml bottle at Stumbling Monk - thanks bvc for this eye opener; pours muddy yellow with huge fluffy white head; unlike anything i have had before; tons of funky cheese that made me pull back at first; the sourness is pretty low in the flavors, just a ton of funk in the aromas; chewy, smooth and honestly, quite impressive despite the almost shocking aromas; it is a bold new world now...haha

75cl from brewer.  Pours medium golden color.  Decent head of 1cm.  Smells a bit acidic, lemon, tart, basement.  This is one of the more acidic guezes I´ve had but it is nice and complex.  Acidity hits you right away with lemon, apple, some spices come in, malts come in later and it finishes quite dry.  The taste of this changes as my bottle has been open and my palate exposed more to it, but difficult to describe.  Not something I´d drink all the time, but quite nice every once in a while.

375ml bottle served in a Duvel tulip. Pours a lightly hazed gold color topped by an average head. Smells of lemon, leather, funk, herbal, tart. Immediately notice the tartness upon tasting but it mellows into a lightly acidic lemony wood flavor. Also notes of cork, aspirin, and a touch of wheat. Medium dryness for the style. Quite drinkable though maybe not quite as complex as I had hoped.

0.375ml - Textbook lambic.  Acidic whomp of wild, crazy, variable note.  White head lingers over a glowing orange.  I rate the palate up even though it tends to be one dimensional, but I think that’s the point with the lambics.

Bottle. Pours a bright coppery orange color with a small white head that goes down pretty quickly to some small bubbles. The aroma is sour and woody, some light fruity notes also. The taste is excellent; a fizzy and light palate with some sour and tart, but not acidic, flavors. A zestfulness, some rich wood and a light sweet flavor also. Complex and tasty. Not harsh, but full flavored. I’m not going to drink this everyday, but this is an excellent, maybe the best example of a Gueuze.
Slightly cloudy, orange appearance. Aroma of pine. Apple, pear, and other natural fruit sugars balanced by a pleasing tart finish. A great example of this style.
Sour. Very complex, vinous, earthy. I love this, it doesn’t concentrate on obliterating your tastebuds like some examples of the style. I think I officially love gueuze now.

Pours incredibly cloudy, with the carbonation of champagne. The head dissipates quickly. Citrus fruits - lemon, lime and grapefruit - maybe some other tart fruits, with a spectacular balance of sweet and bitter. Some funk on the nose, but not in the flavor. This is wonderful stuff. Makes your mouth water in anticipation of the next sip.

Thanks to ajm for the sample.  There’s a reason that this was my first (and possibly last) Gueuze I’ve tried.  Pours a hazy copper color from the bottle with a trim white head.  Smells of cheap rose-based perfume and unripe fruit.  Tastes of strawberries, apple, and faint peach -- none of which approach ripeness.  Hard for me to tell the difference between this and a sour beer.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2008 04 bottle from Bottleworks. insanely quick cork pop, more than any champagne ive had. Weak copper appearance with a quickly disappearing head. Smells of champagne yeast, old fermented cider and fruit. Puckering tart ... but very well balanced. Wonderful ... cannot wait for more.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2009 Bottle from Lone Hill.  Nice raunchy aroma of sour grapes, yeast and an undertow of bleu cheese.  Flavors nicely unripened strawberry, tart apple, sour grass if there is such a thing.  Very nice.

Popped the cork and it bounced off the ceiling. Aroma is lemon and grass. Color is a cloudy gold with a sizable, fluffy white head that  diminishes but leaves nice lacing. Taste is lemon/lime citrus fruit plus moderate acidity and bitterness making this tasty and drinkable. Little to no funk in the aroma or flavor. Expensive but damn good.

This is the shit! From the lush sound of the cork briskly leaving the bottle to the last remainds of geast in the bottom of the glas this beer is pure pleasure. 

It has the acidity and the taste explosion of a world class gueze. Not a single flavor stands out, since it’s all perfect balanced. 

A jewel for lovers of gueze.
Pours a hazy orange with an off white head. Aroma has hints of lemons and vinegar. Highly carbonated with a light feel. Taste is slightly bitter and sour with citrus taste.

Bottle.  Pours a light light orange with a small white head, lots of carbonation.  Aroma of lots of tart, sour funk, sweettart candies, light banana.  Aroma of nice sweet tartness.  Not a lot of funk in this beer, just sour/sweet tartness.  Very nice gueuze, very drinkable.

Bottle. Aroma of barnyard, lemon, cherry, peach, maybe some sour apple. Flavor quite tart and sour (solidly but not abrasively so), slightly but not overwhelmingly funky. Tart grapes in the finish. Enveloping tickling tartness, yet stellar drinkability at once. Great stuff.

Bottle. Nose is deep and invigorating. Bretty barnyard aromas complimented by cherry, lemon, and a light spiciness. Cloudy bright orange with a patchy head. Flavor is a delicious balance of fruit and funk. Peaches, lemon, grapefruit, and deep acidic notes. Palate is thick for a gueuze, which really lets the complexity show. Fantastic.

Pours hazy bronze with a 1 cm tall white head.  Pleasant aroma of bitter crabapples, yeast, and musk.  Wicked bitter bite.  Very sour and acidic, with a mostly apple flavor and some metal.  This bitterness continues throughout, but at the very end the beer takes a mellow, sweeter turn.  A buttery, biscuit-like flavor burns thorugh.  Sometimes it leans into a cheese flavor, like maybe an emmentaler.  Delicious sipper of a beer.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2011 Hazy orange-gold with a short lived white head, moderate lacing. The nose is as cohesive as it comes. The only complaint is that its not incredibly strong, but put your nose to the glass: tart yet sweet fruits, like a braeburn apple, dry dusty frontier, urea, sweet belgian malt reminiscent of honey, cobwebs and old newspaper, cheese... they just go round and roundThe flavor is definitely sweeter than expected, even un-sour for a gueuze: tart, dry, leathery, and musty, yet also sweet and slightly malty. The palate is perfectly dry and refreshing, long-lasting in tart apple and sweet malt that cling perfectly. I drank this most recently in a stretch of about ten queuze and sours, this still won out rather easily. Refined and unique, Girardin Black is immediately noticeable in the same way that Westvleteren 12 and Struise Pannepot sail above their respective competitors.Ive had so many vintages, but recently tried the 99 again. Its heaven out of a 75cl, currently beats almost all the contenders (Blauw, Roze, Pinot DAunis, Millennium, Lente...)

Thanks to Dim for this one
Bottle poured into my tulip glass produced the required two fingers of white billowy head that lasted a while. The head then trailed of to a nice covering of lace. The body on this was a hazy orange 

The aromas from the glass were nice and funky. Sour apples come to mind as I whiff it again the acidity on this is very present in the nose do I dare taste it?

WOW Im glad I like sours this one is quite intense. I let my teens have a sip and they thought it was some sour head candy drink LOL. It reminds me of a crab apple or a transparent apple pie I am a sucker for a good sour apple pie. Some grapefruit citrus as well in here flavor wise. The mouthfeel is crisp and dry good carbonation very refreshing 

Drinkability is a strange question for a sour I finished the bottle, but Do you want to do more than one sour at a sitting? I enjoyed the brew and would gladly drink it again. Truly a great brew and deserves to be tried by every sour fan
UPDATED: SEP 16, 2009 Pours out hazy golden color. Smells great. Taste is tart and funky. Yeasty with a dry sour finish. Very drinkable .

Bottle at Hamilton’s for "Boobies and Beer".  Thanks to the guy, whose name I didn’t get, for pouring me a taster of this for no good reason at all.  I owe you big time.  I sat there for a couple of minutes just smelling.  I couldn’t bring myself to drink it immediately because it simply smelled wonderful.  I would sniff and smile.  My mouth was watering with the anticipation, but I just couldn’t help myself.  When I finally did  get around to drinking it, I was not disappointed at all.  It was definitely tart/sour, but not shockingly so.  The fruit flavor burst and tingled like fireworks, and left with puckering dry mouth.  I think I might be in trouble with this one, at $XX.XX bucks a bottle.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden orange with tall off-white head. The aroma is spicy and very earthy with a good lactic sourish hint and some dank cellar and white cheese. The flavor is quite sour, with a quite assertive spicy yeast quality. Earth and leather tones are throughout, but a little bit of a floral hint sneaks out once in a while. It finishes very dry, with an unexpected orange-blossom note. Delicious.

Bottle courtesy of dchmela.  Wowsers, this is good.  Deep golden hazy pour with orange tint.  Yeasty sour nose, some great leather and horseblanket as well as some strawberries and notes of acetic acid.  Lovely dusty aroma.  Not overly sour on the palate, but definitely tingles and has a great little bite on the back and sides of the tongue.  Playful and fun, and oh-so-delicious.

Bottle opens with a wonderful pop and strong whiff of sour tart cheesy gueze!  Dark golden/orange pour with sparse large bubbles and a white sudsy head.  Strong dusty, yeast aroma that stings the nostrils.  So super tart and sour.  Great cheesy finish.  Mild acidity, doesn’t bother the throat at all.   Medium/light body with light but larger fizzy carbonation.

Bottle at Barley and Hops Tavern. Nearly flawless Gueuze, holds it’s head nicely in a flute, with dominant sour nose which gets better as the temperature rises. Very complex ranging from grassy to lemonade each sip. Palate fatigue starts to kick in half-way through the bottle due to the tartness, which is good, because you can taste the subtleties when your brain shuts down the sour sensation somewhat.
37.5-cl bottle at Delirium, Brussels. Deliciously mineral, sour and yet balanced with a depth that was lacking in the white label Girardin (tasted side by side).
Strong apple aroma with a nice head. The flavor is an extremely tart apple. The flavor lingers, and even intensifies, after each sip is finished.
Cloudy yellow with white head.  The beer was very interesting to taste.  It has tastes of sour lemon with a touch of mustiness (old cardboard).  Not overly sour but not really my kind of beer.

Stone Brewing class on Sour Ales taught by Tomme Arthur of Port Brewing/Lost Abbey. (I lost my tasting notes so this is the best of my recollection.) An excellent gueze with a strong sourness but lots of complexity an development. Smells and tastes of citrus but also a sweet bitterness. Strong and very dry. I really liked this one!
38cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, easy to drink sour brew, very complex, balanced, clear, small head, good brew, the best of the Girardin-range

An all around great sour beer!!! head size is small and light brown. The head longevity is mostly diminishing. The body clarity is murky with some small to medium particles inside the burnt amber hue of the body. 
It has a slight sour taste initially but then at the finish of the beer the sour taste becomes exceptionally strong. 
The beer is light on the palate and the texture is dry. The carbonation is lively and the finish feel is very dry!!

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2009 Pours with a small white head covering a yellow body with plenty of particles. aroma is sour, fruity with leather melons and citrus. Taste is sour all the way through with a bit of sweetness towards the finish. Dry mouthfeel with lively bubbles.  have since had an aged bottle thanks to lumpy. Aroma turns to more cobwebs/library with great complexity. Taste is still very citrus sour... A very good beer, but I actually prefer it with only about 1 year of age...

375 ml purchased in Belgium April 2007. The cork blew when I took off the cage-fortunately no injuries reported. Gold, filtered with a small white head. Nose of bitterness, funk, tons of aroma-nice.  Taste of astringency, bitterness, tartness, pucker-nish just so nice and right.  Wonderfully drinkable and refreshing-wish I would have loaded up on this one. Great beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottiglia da 37.5cl comprata da "A Tutta Birra" a Milano; sarà la terza gueuze che assaggio in tutta la mia vita (non per quantità, intendo come produttore) e mi sorprende perché la trovo piuttosto diversa e mi suggerisce un discreto raggio di possibilità all’interno dello stile. Questa è decisamente vinosa, non molto acida, piuttosto corposa, con una punta d’amarognolo inusitata che si stempera in un dolciastro che lascia proprio sentori decisi di botte. Se dovessi consigliare una gueuze ad un neofita amante del vino, questa sarebbe la mia scelta; è un prodotto di alto livello ma comunque molto facile da bere, direi l’ideale per un pomeriggio d’estate o per un aperitivo. O anche per il dopopranzo, un vizietto come quello che mi sto concedendo io.

bottle thanks to bhops.  nice fruity tart smell and a murky gold pour with no head.  easy on the palate and the sour/tartness is actually quite controlled.  it’s definitely not overpowering and it’s not underpowered.  this is a great balanced gueuze.
UPDATED: JUL 25, 2008 Oh my.  Pours hazy gold, aroma is sour fruit and musty/yeasty.  Flaovr is fruity, not too sour... medium mouthfeel.  This is an incredible beer.

375 ml bottle from a trade with mcbackus. pours hazy brown with a very fizzy white head that is gone quickly. aromas are typical gueuze with cidery apples standing out. flavours are complex and sour. insanely drinkable and very well balanced. i great example of a wondeful style. its really to bad i have no way of getting any good gueuze without trading for them. thx mcbackus for this amazing brew!
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2009 Thanks to Solan for this one!   Hazy orange pour fluffy off white head.  Tart aroma very lemony.  Nice and tart with a crisp clean finish!

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2009 Bottle gift to aid my lambic education from Mes. Cloudy orange colour. A delight to freshen the palate in the middle of big session. Not too sweet, not too tart, not too dry. Beltissimo.

Clean copper pour with bubbly white head and no lace. Medium malt and sour on the nose. A very clean sour ale it was like a palate cleaner. Very full and aggressive carbonation. Very nice sour beer that leaves your mouth feeling clean and fresh.

courtesy of Toni Flükiger - cloudy dark orange colour with a solid beige foam;complex aroma of cheese, dust and rhubarb; medium-bodied, juicy palate with a solid acidity, a long and fizzy acidic finish, quite dry with more notes of rhubarb, vinegar and apple

pours a brillant amber color with abundant carbonation and the best head retention I’ve ever seen in a lambic.  left lots of lacing on the glass.  aroma was apple cider viniger, cellar notes, funk, and horseblanket.  flavor was much of the same, but very round.  light astringent mouthfeel.  Finish has some lemon intermixed with the horseblanket and acidic notes.  somewhere inbetween a drie fountainen and a Cantillon.  Damn near perfect.

Trade thanks to CaptainCougar.  Pours cloudy orange with a small white head.  Sour and yeasty nose.  First taste was off the hook sour.  But i couldn’t stop, I kept going back for more.  Each mouthful brought on a new fruit, yet pulled the moisture from my palate.

Appearance: Muddy orange. Fizzy. Quite a lot of head, shortlived.
Aroma: Sour, some fruit. Apricot. Lemon.
Taste: Very sour and quenching. Unfinished wine.
Info: 375ml bottle, 2/4-2007, 165/300
Sorry, not my cup of tea...
Dark golden to orange in color with a white foamy head.  Sweet yeasty, tart, sour, and funky in the smell.  Taste is smooth, great sour taste, tart from front to back of the mouth.  Great beer.
Botella. Hazy orange colour, short fizy head. Nice mouldy tart an fruity aroma. Lovely lively mouthfeel. Very nice tart, dry fruity, bit salty, citrus flavour with some yeast.

Bottle thanks to Drewbeerme, Ive been sitting on this bottle for quite some time, maybe a year.  Hazy orange amber with medium white head.  Aroma is funky, tart, lemony, slight earthy.  Medium sour, more funky, tart, medium earthy, slight cherry, all very light and drinkable but at the same time sour and fruity.  Medium bodied with slight pucker.  What an amazing beer.

traded for this one with Hogtown Harry.  Hazy golden color lively carbonation nose is farmhouse, kinda earthy  notes, and some definate lactic notes. flavor follows suit, lactic sour but excedinly drinkable some earthy notes as well in there. Very dry finish but very very good!!
From a bottle poured a slightly hazy straw color with a good amount of head.  Nice tart flavor with a good tart lingering finish.

oro non molta schiuma ma piuttosto persistente arimi tipici ma non aggressivi in bocca mediamente acida leggero citrico piuttosto amara veramente buona ma non esaltante da assggiare forse un po più vecchia

Burnt sugar sour crème brûlée nose.  Hazy amber color with soapy medium head. Biting malt vinegar sourness, some bitter lemon peel/pith bitterness.  There is some faint caramel malt sweetness lurking deep in the background.  Huge carbonation, medium body that ends up finishing with a thin body and a satisfying warm tart burn.  Style is an acquired taste, and this is a fantastic example.

37.5cl bottle-pours a big foamy white head and amber color with effervescence.  Aroma is dry yeast, sour, some medium malt.  Taste is dry yeast, sour/vinegar, some medium malt.  Nicely done, but not my taste.  Occasional.  Thanks to decaturstevo for sharing.

Couleur cuivrée, orangée. Donne un peu de mousse blanche au service, mais laisse une dentelle riche. Légèrement voilée.
Parfum de pomme, de levures et de champignons frais, On sent bien le caractère surette de la bière.
Le goût est légèrement sucré, amer et suret ensuite, une vraie cascade de différents registres de saveurs. 
Le palais est rond, bien mousseux et frais.
Je lai bue bien froide, après avoir couper lherbe et je vous donne ma parole que cette bière rafraîchit et désaltère mieux que nimporte quelle Lager ou Pilsner!
Fantastique, cest différent de la GRANDE majorité des bières, à essayer!

Bottle.  Pours perfect - huey orange  with tons of floaters, its white head retains throughout session. Nose is farmhouse funk.    Mouth is eye openingly ripe, dry, fruity (lemon) and sharp.  Spritzer carbonation brings everything together.  Acts like a Flemish Sour.  Wonderful.

Really nice aroma on this beer.  Im only just getting into sours and I think they are starting to grow on me.  This is a great example.  Sour apple aroma, as well as a barnyard funkiness.  Murky golden pour with chunks evident.  Not the sour puckering flavor of some in this style, but that is definitely a good thing.  Very good in fact.  May be my favorite sour to date.

Small sample at OSLO and Guerdes tasting on Friday, 5-23-08. Labeled as "Gueuze Girardin 1882." Pours a hazy gold with a small amount of beige head. Sharp, salty, lemon, and sour apple aroma. Dry, quite sour flavor. Very cool, different sort of taste that reminds me of tonic water (I mean that as a compliment). Bitter finish. Fizzy in the palate.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2015 Bottle. Pours a great body - hazy orange with small white head, and nice active lacing. The aroma is barn funk, yeast, aged Gouda, dank sour lemon zest and some tart character.  The mouthfeel is close to perfect when this gueuze hits its sweet spot with the right amount of age; notes of tart fruits, funky lemon, barnyard funk, rustic character, faint sour wheat, citrus, 1999 bottle +0.4. Incredible. Lots of musky wood.

Nice tart aroma, with a bit of underlying funk.  Pours a clear light amber, with a large quickly fading white head.  Nice tart flavor, hints of green apples and lemons, light on the palate and very dry.  Overall, a very good gueuze.
37,5 cl bottle. Hazy golden/amber color, white head. Aroma is sour. Flavor is sour, wood, some sweetnes from malt. Vinous. Balanced. Very nice!

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 Sampled at OSLO/Guerdes Memorial Day tasting. Pours a semi-hazy golden amber gueuze with a fizzy white head that has nice retention and a thick white ring. Aroma of sour barnyard funk, yeast, grapefruit, wet blanket and some white pepper. Taste is spritzy tart citrus zest, yeast, a touch of grapefruit, some floral character and a touch of herbs. Finish is just as sour as its flavor with a very dry citrus and light skonk character. One of the funkiest gueuzes Ive tried.
Bottle. Pours golden brown. A slot of sour funkiness in this one.  Belgian yeast, and spoiled fruit.  Nice tingling mouth cleansing mouth feel.  A solid number.

Ah, the golden goddess. Aroma of band-aids soaking in something sterile and medicinal along with some woody brine. Mouthfeel is tremendous. My tongue is not worthy of this. Bracing rubber and grapefruit tang near the end of a beautifully intoxicating session on my tastebuds. Truly, this is a world classic. I liked the 3 Fonteinen, but this is way out front of that. Desert Island beer!

Pours a beautiful, glowing gold with a foamy, white head. Strong soured fruit aroma of Belgian yeast and citrus. Taste is a similar soured fruit citrus at first. This settles very smoothly into a sweet tart, bready finish. Tastes like it underwent a secondary with some champagne yeast. Nice carbonation kick. Very complex palate, especially as it warms.

Golden color with a med-large head.  Aroma is tremendous - funky and sour with some nice barrel effects and citrusy goodness.  Flavor was a bit heavy on the citrus at first, but settled nicely into a funky-sour masterpiece - citrus, earth, and wood.  Nice mouthfeel with a good pucker factor.  A really good gueuze that I need more of.

Delicious gueuze and all its cracked up to be. Thanks, mcbackus! Aroma was big and nice. Strong funk, barnyard floor and wet blanket. Pour was a nice bubbly orange with a pillowy 2 finger off white head. Taste was nice and mouth puckering. Strong wood, earth and funk with a hint of cheese and vinegar. Complex and absolutely delicious. Heaven in a bottle.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours golden with a medium white head. Aroma of sour fruit, yeast, wood. Well carbonated. Flavor of sour and tart fruits with a bit of yeast. Great balance. Nice mouthfeel. Very good.
I love this beer. Slightly sour, barn yardy with lots of funk. Very Hazy, bolnde slightly Orange colour. Perfect beer for Early mornings on a hot summer day. Extremely refreshing!

Dont have pets so the "cat pee smell" I cant truly associate with.  This beer is a hazy gold with a small white ring of a head.    Aroma is extremely sour with hints of grapefruit and oak.  Taste is extremely puckering...you can feel it in the jaw and throat.  Interesting but I probably wouldnt purchase again...especially at the $$$.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2008 I fail to understand the true appeal of the lambic. These beers are so incredibly expensive and  heavily aged--lets get some barley wines with 2 years of age on them by default. 
This one was very sweet and intensely, brutally, overwhelmingly acidic. Exactly like drinking Sprite with vinegar. Much grapiness in the flavors also, like sour cherry champagne that is foot-in-mouth bitter. I really like this beer however, and since Impy Stout and Barley Wine are the only styles I judge by style and not flavor, I will have to reluctantly rate this very high.

bottle thanks to tom- pours cloudy real cloudy, amber,big creamy, white offwhite head,nose isnt as big as some of the other gueze ive had, tastes sour strawberry, sour cherry, lemon rind, complex but i think maybe a bit too sour for my taste to have on its own.

Corked and caged.  Classic gueuze nose, slightly metallic yeast.  Sour with slight wood.  Dark golden pour with a dense, rocky, tiny-bubbled, noise beige head and champagne-like clinging to the undersides of the glass.  Laces. with legs.  Taste is strongly sour and medially sweet, slight citrus (along the lines of grapefruit) along with faint muscat, wood, and puckering tartness.  Slight dish-soapy champagne tone (the flavor, not a negative).  Medium body, smooth and malty other than the initial burst of sparkle.  Dry and water-sucking.  Mouth and throat are left dry and sated for some time after drinking.  Touch of lemon cleaner and floral notes with the bend of leather.   Complexity of the sour wood makes this a winner.  Not over the top and offensive - though not tame - and one of the most refreshing (drinkable!  quenching!) gueuzes around.  Superb.

Very hazy amber pour with lots of carbonation and beautiful lacing.  Topped off with a thick long lasting white head - perfect pour!  Sour aroma with a hint of roast and malt.  Very complex - some citrus tones as wells as spices.  A little bit of vinegar but overall very pleasant.  Very sour taste but there is a very slight sweetness to it.  Peppery tones with grain and malt on the finish.  Very good!

From a 330mL Bottle.  Pours a transparent, honey gold color with a thin layer of fizzy white head.  Aromas of sour lemon, musty horseblanket, and cheesy funk.  Hints of oaky vanilla.  Tart peach skins and fermented grapefruits.  Light bodied, mildly carbonated mouthfeel with moderate acidity.  A moderate lactic acidity greets the palate up front, along with hints of lemon juice and a bright point reyes bleu funk.  Light white pepper spice and touches of aged oak.  Could use a bit more carbonation to lighten up the palate and help heighten the brighter flavors of the beer.  The musky flavors are complex and satisfying, but would be further heightened with some brighter balance.  Lingering finish of cheese rind and lemon pith.

4-5-08 bottle shared at tasting 
Clearish amber color with a thin okay head.  This is the first beer I have actually picked up on the "cat pee" smell.  Flavor is sour tart apples and has a dusty finish.  Drinkable and has just an average mouthfeel for me.

Bottle. Hazy golden orange with a little sediment and yeast, small white head crests this beauty. A thrilling funk on the nose: zesty sour lemon, acidic tart, leathery barnhouse brett funk. Nicely effervescent in the mouth. Tart upfront, curling around to puckering strong almost lime tang. As this warmed drying leather stabs mingled with the tart. This is superb, wonderfully drying and tartly refreshing. A little more upfront sour than the Boon Oude Geuze Mariage Parfait. Tremendous!

bottle at the white horse with issy and a plate of rock oysters, and hell i can recommend that combination.its one of my most drunk lambics and i love nothing more than watching the sun set on a cool summer day with a bottle of this light fresh tarty little beauty. gorgeous body, citric and tataric acid with sweet leather yummy.
Bottle purchased at Beverages for Less in Santee. Thank you Fredie for carrying one of the best lambic gueze I have tasted. Excellent sour but sweet too. Awesome.

A- Pours a peach color with little to no head, very clear.

S- Smell is very sour, i get strong apple cider tones, definitely lots of funk, I dont know if I am prepared for the taste.

T- Taste is much better than I was expecting. Intensely sour, completmeted with subtle sweet fruit tones, not as much apple as I expected from the nose.

M- Medium viscosity and very crisp, the carbonation is hard to judge because of the crisp bite of the sourness.

D- This is a sipper for sure because it is so intensely sour. While saying that, I think while this would take a long time to drink a lot of, I could sip on it all night.

2 year old bottle. Pours a murky orange-brown with excitable but collapsing white head.  Nose is major sour funkiness, leathery, citric, sherbety.  Smooth if somewhat thin body, starting fragrant and flowery with faint sweetness before a muscular sourness prevails, ending quite smoothly.  One of the more wild guezes Ive tried.

Bottle 75 cl. Pours a semi-cloudy yellow/orange with a tiny and fading white head. The aroma is dry, bitter, sour and lots of farmhouse notes. The flavor starts out a bit sweet and then gets sour and bitter. A funky gueuze, but not as good as some of the 3 Fonteinen gueuzes.

Smaller corked bottle. Pours a perfectly clear deep gold with lively carbonation and a thin diminishing head. Aroma is initially cork, then some farmhouse funkiness, and followed by a ton of lactic sourness. Flavor is extremely sour and acidic, wierd sour-sweetness on the tip of the tongue kind of like sour patch kids. Some woody and earthy notes in the middle, and finishes bone dry with lots of sourness. Very nice overall.
UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 cloudy colden coloured body with a white head a woody fruity aroma a sourig sweet taste with a sourig bitter finich

Bottle shared with Carlus12. Nose is funky, cheese, hay, apples and cider. Pors a murky yellow beer. Taste is complex, minerals, apples, sour. Tatse is actually quite discilined and not as wild as some Lambics. Tasty.

barnyard aromas galore....leathery mouthfeel that I love......and damn I think this is a great initiation to someone(like my girlfriend) who loves flanders sours and needs to step it up at bit.......great beer!

Bottle shared at tasting courtesy of Dewbrewer, I believe.  Thank you!
Pours orangish colored with a wispy white head.  Smell is lighty funky sour barnyard.  Taste is balanced sweet and sourness.  Begins very lightly sweet and then finishes tart and dry.  Bubbly, fizzy active carbonation and a nice moutfeel that I havent gotten in some guezes.  This was really nice and easily one of my favorites of the style

Aroma:  Funky, barnyardy, musty and woody scents just jump out of the glass.  Fruitiness and straw notes are also present, offset by a little vinegar note.  Awesome.

Appearance:  Clear, light gold, with long standing white head.

Flavor:  Mirrors aroma, just as complex, you pull different flavor components out with every sip.  Absolutely unbelievable.

Palate:  Bone-dry, with an almost salty finish.  Mouth-puckering as it should be, with some tannins adding to this.

Overall:  Absolute perfection.  One of the best beers Ive had, crazy complex and world class.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2015 Re-rate 9/20/15: Draught at De Cam Volkscafé in Gooik. Great stuff, extremely refreshing. 8/4/9/3/18=4.2 
Re-rate 4/1/12: Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks Lee. Cloudy orange. Aroma full of barnyard, cobwebs, some lemon, oak and sweaty hints. Sour flavor with lovely oakiness. Wonderful. 9/3/8/4/17=4.1

Re-rate 7/3/11: Bottle sample at the 1st Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks Amir. Clear golden. Aroma of barnyard, lemon and some oak. Sour barnyard flavor. Medium-bodied. Wonderful. 9/3/9/4/18=4.3

(3/2/08) Bottle sample at Zythos Bier Festival 2008 in Sint Niklaas. 2005 bottle. Cloudy golden color. Great barnyard and citrus aroma. Nice sour, rather soft yet not too soft flavor, with some wood. Some bitterness and notes of citrus (grapefruit and some lemon) in the finish. Medium-bodied. Great and with very high drinkability. 8/3/8/4/16=3.9

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours a wonderful, pale orange with a small white film head. Aroma is tart, lots of sourish apple, some caramel, barnyard and funkiness. Low to medium carbonation. Exceptionally rounded flavour! Lots of sour apples, not as dry as other gueuzes, very fruity and champagne-like.
Bottle via Beerlando.  Cloudy, golden color.  Smell of sour apples, champagne, lemons and some cherries.  Taste of tart, sour apples, champagne and very acidic.  Love this style!  Great lambic.

Cask at the White Horse with tashi. Hazy orange, typical gueuze appearance. Wonderfully dry aroma of tart apples and a slight cheesiness. Very enticing. Flavourwise, less dry, more sweet and the sourness is not overdone. Its tart but not excessively so. tashi described it as "a good beginners gueuze" and Id agree with that.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle at SlutFest 2011 on 04/23/2011. Slightly hazy golden body with a small frothy white head. Tart fruit and apple aroma. Funky fruit and apples. Medium light body with high carbonation. 8/3/9/4/17 4.1

On 03/14/2008. 2006 Bottle. Cloudy golden body with a medium fizzy white head. Sour earthy and apple aroma. Sour apple, light earthy and hints of grapefruit flavor. Light body with high carbonation. 8/2/8/4/17 - 3.9

[sampled at Hopleaf, Chicago] Strongly acidic, almost metallic aroma. Musty and sour. Very cloudy yellow color with some tight white foam. Tart, acidic flavors; some mild green apple character. Almost cider-like. Very mouth drying.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2008 375ml bottle.   Gold-orange color with small carbonation and a creamy off-white head.   Honey, lemon, wet wood, a floral aroma.   Sour and acidic, with a little musty woodiness.   Starts with a little sweetness, and then dry and tart.   Has enough malt body to balance the tartness, and that is really the kicker for me.   Light  body and champagne-like carbonation.   The balance and complexity are amazing.   I didnt really like gueuze before this, but the balance and drinkability of this beer has completely turned me around.

ZBF2008: as Girardin gueuze ongefiltered black label. Pours slight hazy orange, little lacing head. Aroma is light acidc with a mild woody note. Flavour is dry acidic to mild citric. Ends dry and acidic to woody.
Poured cloudy yellow with a bright white head and nice lace. Aroma is musty and sour. Flavor is lemon, sour, yeasty, apple-cider notes. Finish is dry and acidic--very refreshing.

Pours a hazy golden color with suspended particulates and small white airy head. Nose is tart, fruity,cirtusy and green apples. Initial taste is salty which explodes in sour acidity and freshly peel oranges that makes your mouth water. Barnyard funk, green apples, and champagne all arrive to the mid palate. Finishing with a sharp bitter astrigency, apple cider and wood notes. Mouthfeel is soft and smooth, light to medium body. Great head retention and splash lacing of the glass. Palate duration is good. Very tasty but was looking for depth and complexity.
Bottle at ZBF, Sint-Niklaas, Belgium: Gueuze with an great gueuze bite, hazy orange and subtile sourness in the back.

Fantastic flavor, ideal colour, strong taste, sterke nadronk
mijn absolute favoriet in geuzes

bottle.  pours a hazy honey with a thinnish white head that fizzes away quickly, but remains as a film.  my! how tastes change!  just six months ago, this wouldve been described the same, but rated rather harshly.  and now, its just amazing.  sharp lemon and orange zest in the nose, with background hints of sweaty funk, oak, and honey malts.  lemony flavor, with the malt playing a much larger role, some vegetably barnyard and woodiness, rounded off with a few brighter and more colorful fruits, like orange again, and maybe some very subtle hints of sour cherries and even strawberries.  sharp but not puckering sour finish, nice and dry, and with a nice light and pleasant sweetness.  fairly light of body, oh so quenching, each sip beckons another.  i was surprised by, and like, how malty this gueuze is.  i was expecting a bit more complexity, but its definitely the right beer for the right time at the moment.  very, very good.

Bottle courtesy of purfock: Poured a orangey color lambic with a huge foamy head with excellent retention and some good lacing. Aroma of green apple and tart is really great. Taste is a complex mix between some green apple, some sour and tart notes with some light funky barnyard notes. Full body with great carbonation. I appreciated that the level of acidity is manageable and doesnt totally overrun the complexities.

Tasted 2008-02-28. Bottle of unknown date. Pours almost clear, dark yellow with white head. Aroma: Barnyard, sour apples, citrus. Flavours: Very sour, acidic, citrussy and just a tad bitter in the end. Very dry mouthfeel. More balanced than your ordinary gueuze - I like it!

Hazy amber with a fleeting white head. Strong aroma is everything i like about this style; musty earth, hay barnyard, cheesy, mold, dandelion. Light, lively mouthfeel. Taste is first tart sour with wheat flavors and oak, lemon, hay, barnyard. very complex and refreshing drink here, love it. 3297
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: A top beer among the geuzes....! This one is extremely balanced. It has the perfect sourness balanced with a great malty body and slight sweetnes..... Well, it is still a geuze with the nuances of  horsestable, hay and vomit.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle, courtesy Tony at Oldsmar Tap House. Pours a cloudy yellow golden color, with a smooth watery head, and vibrant sheets of lacing. Very barnyard aroma, with salty meat and wheat. Tart ripe fruit flavors, vinegar, citrus, warm bread. Slight tartness to the watery body, bitter finish. Quite good.

Green corked and caged bottle poured a clear orange with a small lasting ivory head. Aromas of leather, vinous, light barnyard, oak and light citrus. Palate was light bodied crisp and tart. Flavors of leather, oak, citrus and light barnyard with a crisp dry lingering tart finish.
Very good sour complex gueuze. Fruity, cheesy, sweat, playin cards, woody.  Beware of gushing!!

C&C 375ml bottle from slob - thanks Bert! Clear gold with a thin white head. Tart, lightly funky nose, a very light woodiness, apricot and mild cat piss. Sour/tart flavor, somewhat acidic, dry and dusty, Granny Smith apple, wood.. SO much going on here... some sour white grape, a pop of vinegar, gets drier.. jeez.. very good stuff. Finish is dry, lightly fruity, dust. I love this beer... white grapefruit peeks in at the end. Lovely!
Bottled thanks to Engelsman. Hazy orange coloured with a rather large off-white head. Very well balanced and very nice complexity. Citrus, smoke, fruit. Very nice tartness.

Pours a nice golden amberish color that has a decent whitish head that rises and falls fairly quickly. Nose is bringing the funk. Minor antiseptic tones are mixed with a more dominatingly sweet character. Flavor is great. Nice sour tang. Wonderful level of funk. Well done. Very smooth feel. This is so easy to drink. Does it come in gallons??

Bottle, acquired in a trade with Tertons. Hazy light orange in color with a small off white head.  Aroma is funky as hell with barnyard, stinky cheese, as well as sour lemons.  Taste is moderately sour with alot of sour fruit, oak, earth, and quite funky with barnyard and sweaty socks.  Hints of black pepper.  Finishes with lingering sourness. Very nice, thanks alot Nelson.

From bottle : Pours a hazy orange color with a small white head that disipates quickly.  Nose is citrus and barnyardy.   Taste is very tart, some citrus and metallic hints, and acidy.  Starts a little sweet then goes to bitter at the end, with the tartness.  Medium body but a rough abbrasive palate.  There really isnt any aftertaste.  Very nice though.

Pours a hazed yellow brown gold with a decent head.  Big ass tart lambic!  Dry.  Really bites the back of the nose.  Very socky!!  Very small bubbles with a nice fluidity to it.  Big dry tartness.  Oaky tannic, leaves the mouth rough!  Very acidic and lemony.  very very dry acidic finish.  This makes 3 Fontenein Oude Gueze from earlier in the night look tame.

Explosive bottle at cgarvieuk coolbeans party. Golden cloudy with a big fluffy white head. Fusty hops and gueuze, lively nose, mouth is very dry, gueuzey, some sourness, cotton wool. Fresh, very balanced. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Bottled. Effervescent pour that produces a rocky white head and a sparkling gold color with lots of carbonation. Immediate aroma of tart citric notes with apple and oak. Wild yeasts and their sourness are noticeable here too. Earthy flavors of wet soil, breadish yeast, green apple and vinous acetic acid are nicely mixed together. Finishes very dry and carbonated with a puckering finish. Extremely balanced palate. This is my favorite go-to gueuze that always satisfies.

Clear yellow-orange color with a modest white head that sticks around surprisingly long for such an acidic style.

Aroma is sour/tart citruses like lemon, lime, and orange. Very funky and wild.

Pretty sharp vinegar taste with influence from the sweeter citrus notes. Finish is puckering and funky.

Bone dry and refreshing, with great carbonation. One of the easier to drink gueuzes Ive had.
Bottle at home with Tom ... Golden orange ...sharp tart cider nose  ... sharp tart fruit ...  prob a good geuze but not my thing.
Pretty cloudy light tan pour with a small 1 finger white head.  Aroma is sour, tart, light fruits.  Taste matches the aroma with a tartness that makes you pucker.  Nice experience with a sour beer.

One of the finest crafted Belgian brews Ive tried. The quality is evident upon opening the bottle. That said, the aroma and taste were unexpected. The aroma of this Girardin beer is yeast and sour apples. I have not liked the 2 or 3 sours Ive tried. But this isnt a sour. It is dry and acidic and has an apple tartness, but it doesnt devolve into the vinegar flavor that I associate with sours. As this warmed, I liked it more, so much so in fact that I give it a very high rating. I noticed some grapefruit and pungent cheeses, too. Let this one warm to cellar temperature if you have stored it in a refrigerator. The tartness mellows and the complex flavors emerge with warmth.

Green corked bottle 375 ml   
I ve waited for milestone, surviving gloomy Monday with horrible pain at my back  Good enough excuse why not today, waiting is over.
Appearance:  Some sparkle in this sea Baltic amber, small island of zesty foam. 3+ Nose : Aroma sweeter than any hardcore limbic lover might expect. Hint of tart red apple, klops pear and red gooseberry. Soft sensory travel .8- Flavor/Palate : Kiss of fresh lemon with grinded apple weaved fruity sugars. Acidicity slowly sipping onto your palate. Ruby grapefruit with lime finishing. play. Refreshing vessel well made no doubt but this isnt the best.

bottle thanks to my santa......pours an orange brown with a fluffy white head that quickly dissipates....enticing aroma of funky citrus notes (mainly lemon)and a musty barnyardiness just the way i like it....flavors of the same vein with the bitterness evolveing to a decent sense of sweetness even. but jever just so slightly but still some acidity intermixed with the latter.....im with the masses on this one. very nice.

Bottle shared; thanks to Axilla. Poured hazy golden copper color with a thin white head. Aroma of citrus and earthy funk. The flavor was maybe a little to fresh due to the lack of tart that I enjoy. Flavors of peach, lemon, musty funk and a tad sweet. I would love to rate this again with a bottle that is a little more aged.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 350 ml. bottle from PhillyBeer2112.  Pour is a slightly cloudy orange, with an off white head which fades quickly.  Aroma is very engaging, Brett, barnyard funk, floral, citrus - just tons going on in the nose.  Taste is equally engaging, bone dry earthy funk with the Brett, rounded out with some nice lemon citrus and a woody - sour finish.  The palate is light, though this makes the flavors in this beer pronounced, yet soft and delicate.  Masterpiece.  Thanks for this one Dan, it was great.

Bottle picked up at the Hop Duvel, Gent, early December 07. Shared this in Belgian Beer Tasting evening with Loz, Casey and Traci 04-01-08  Didnt take any notes as I was convinced that Id had this beer and rated it before (which I had) so whilst some of this is unearthed from travel diary the rest is from memory. Poured hazy dull orange colour with white rapidly receding head, in fact the head on my beer had all but gone by the time Casey passed me my glass. Aroma a bit musty and that nice funky sourness also a touch woody. lovely dry snappy bite wonderful tartness, refreshing with some gentle lemon zinginess zapping away. A truly excellent beer that I loved.

Bottle, with Fin, Loz and Traci at our Belgian Beer Tasting (Part II). Bright copper, persistent skim of white head. Soft wool and peach aroma, and a little bit of classy old lady perfume.
