UPDATED: AUG 8, 2008 Bottle from 2004 Hazy apricot amber colored with a tall white head. Horseblanket sour aroma, with a sour apple note.Sour citrusy flavor that really excites the taste buds. Great lambic-gueuze!

UPDATED: APR 28, 2008 375 ml bottle.  Golden apricot pour with a fizzy head.  Aromas were very tart fruit.  Flavors kept the extreme tartness.  Almost exactly like carbonated grapefruit juice.  Very Yummy

Opening of the corked bottle, nice overflow of carbonation, excellent. Poured a hazy amber-orange color with a nice head (lots of carbonation), a short lived lacing with each sip. The aroma was typical for the style, lots of funk, some citrusey and apple-like tart aromas. The flavor was similar, funky, tart-like, etc.... The blended concept was well-done here, as the tartness was very nicely smoothed out and softened. The after after after taste was somewhat cheesy. Sure, thats not probably beer tech talk, but Im stickin with it. Mouthfeel was carbonated and somewhat light to moderate.

Bottle: Darker amber pour fizzy off white head. Aroma is quite sour, some funky notes. Flavor, very tart and sour. Like a full bag of sour patch kids without a drink of water. Some apple and lemon. Really nice finish, the after taste just blossoms in the mouth. This is fantastic. Rating #200 in the books.

Bottle at Københavns Øldage 2006, Stand 29 (Belgisk Bryg), they had it hidden we got it because we asked for something special. Stand 3 (My Beer) had it sold out. Strong sour smell and flavour, wood, fruits...just as we wanted it. It cleans nicely, so we could taste another strong stout after.
Pours orange with a thin ring of white bubbles.  Smells of horses, sweat, barnyards, some grassy elements.  Taste is moderately sour with nice peachy hints.

Bottle Cork popped as soon as I untwisted the cage and gushed half of the bottle also made a major mess - Pours hazy amber with not much head.  Aroma is straight barnyard, some bad cheese,  sour.   Flavor is quite similar, there is some subtle oak there to mellow it but it is sharply sour.  Palate is medium bodied, quite astringent, and tough to hold in the mouth.   Lots of flavor there.  just not much of it I found favorable.

Hazy golden in color with a small white head. Aroma of vomit(albeit nice vomit, barnyard funk,mold,mildew,fruity and musty. Flavor is sour,acidic, sharp at time with mellow a woodiness. Finishes very dry,mouthpuckering as your lips will want more.

Great tasting gueze indeed.  Pours a darkish straw with mild sized head.   Nose is of huge funk with easy vinegar and a nice barnyardiness.  Flavor is similar but with a little more kapow added in.   Very mellow, which I liked in it.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden-orange with a large frothy white head leaving cloudy lace. The aroma is pretty unreal - so woody and oaky with lots of brett funk, barnyard that I wouldnt have imagined with my previous gueuze experiences. Definitely on par with the likes of Cantillon and Hanssens and in many ways surpassing in complexity. Juicy citric flavour is mouth puckering at times.

Sampled at Le Zageman in Brussels on May 9, 2006.

Wow. A huge blast of Brett on this one. To me, tasted much stronger than the Drie Font or the Cantillon. Nice head and a fair amount of carbonation. Very little citrus or hops to my palate.
I would be interested to do a side-by-side comparison of Gueze to see if this was indeed that much stronger, or if it was just my taste for the day.

Highly carbonated for a gueuze, about a third of the bottle ended up on my face and shirt:( hazy orange with a generous white head. wonderful aromas! lemony, sour apple, cave aged cheese, used book store, earthy funk. One of the best and most approachable gueuzes Ive had to date. The sweet/ sour balance and complex fruitiness make this a great gueuze for someone new to the style.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2007 Damn this is good...thanks slob.  Pours a amazing honey with a manic white head.  Aroma is sour funk, lemons, yeast and cheese.  Flavor is similar...incredibly well balanced...actually tastes quite a bit like jolly pumpkin calabaza blanca...but better.  Mouthfeel is light and dynamic.  I think this is my first official gueze...and Ill definitely be looking for more.
Awesome taste, very sour, perhaps a little dry but the foam is good, the colour is unfiltered alike. I like this one much.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2008 Aroma is lemony, seriously yeasty, apples skins, a bit of baby sick, Amazing. Taste is similar though not as sour as expect, not balanced by anymeans, but going that way. Possibly the easiest drinking gueuze iv ever had, defo one to get again. RERATE: Up from 4.6 - 4.9. Gueuze is the finest beverage ever made! RERATE: 750 at Blackfriars while working. The complexity and body of this beast is outstanding, yet the drinkability is crazy. The whole 750 was gone in about 10 mins.

As far as my experience with gueuze, which is not much, this one seems very well balanced.  Not so pungent or skunky.  Aroma has a hint of rapes and more fruits come through as the beer first hits your mouth.  Rather sour mouth couting.  Finishes and leaves a nice aftertaste.

Bottle uncorks with an explosion of foam, and a nice aroma of funky apple cider spreads around the room. Colour is amber (aka morning piss) and the head dissipates quickly. On closer examination, the beer smells like Roskilde Festival Sunday morning, but in a good way. First sip is sour and funky, with buttermilk and apples. From here on out, it just keeps getting better. This beer is about as dry as you can get.

Slightly hazy golden straw color, with slight head and quickly fading lace. Huge nose of wet horse blanket with a plesant dusty malt.  Grips your mouth and awakens your taste buds, nicely carbonated and very balanced.   Good acidtiy and clean, lingering finish.

Superb.
This pretty much looks like a standard pilsener. Quite big lasting head and all.
Huge aroma of grapefruit, flowers, yeasts, horseblanket and many other scents - very complex.
Very fresh and fruity taste with a huge funk factor - and not as sour as I had actually imagined.
Zesty with lots of pang.
Pours a hazy orange-amber color with a fruity/citrusy aroma.  Taste is sour-very sour and dry on the palate.  If you like sour lambics, this is one youll love.

Thx to SoLan. Hazy orange body with a huge head. Aroma is tart, sour apples, barnyard action, lemons. Finishes dry. Dangerously drinkable. Knowing I wont have this again any time soon... its taking a lot of will power to drink it as slowly as I am. Damn this stuff is good. My review didnt do it justice.. but wow... just find it and drink it.

I had this one at the Steel Garden which is part of Bethlehem Brew Works. This is incredible as far as sourness and acidity. I sense hints of citrus and peaches and the palate is perfect. The carbonation is there but isnt overdone. It is a pretty dry beer overall. With the sourness factor, you either love this one or hate it.

Bottled 02.2004 - Beautifully golden, orange with a low but creamy white head that lasts; Incredible nose, deep and super complex, the full geuze package of lemon/citrus, very fresh green apples under it notes of cigar box (ceder+tobaco), hay, horse (uuuhhhhhhhh fantastic!!!!!); The body has a super balance, acidy fresh with a very, very little and nice, soft sweetness to it; The finish is fantastic as well. It is perfectly dry (not super dry), with very little tannin that brings a mouth-feel that makes you want to chew the beer. All this with a lemon/grapefruit, later cedar touch, that lasts forever. This is for sure my favorite geuze, if not my favorite beer of all. This is a masterpiece!!!!

Knightly Spirits, Orlando, Fl. - 12.7 fl oz bottle. Pours a murky, nectarine colored orange wtih a long lasting fluffy, creamy white head. Aroma reminds me of the hard, flat bubble gum you used to get in baseball cards. Hint of vinegar as well. Very sour. Flavor has the requisite sourness, some sweet tart candy, peaches, dry white wine. Mouth puckering, but in a good way. Leaves you thristing for more. Carbonated mouthfeel - but not too fizzy.

Bottle shared with tupalev, jerc, blankboy & HogTownHarry - courtesy of tupalev. Hazy sunset-gold colour with just the faintest hint of a white head. Aroma is sour & funktastic - notes of stinky cheese, lemon, yeast & wet dog - sounds like crap, i know, but it was damn good! Flavour is fantastic as well - concentrated citrus notes, lots of lemon and grapefruit, with a dusty yeastiness coming in behind. Killer!

Cork popped and rapid foam streamed out of the bottle.  Quickly poured into a tumbler.  Horseblanket with hazy cider appearance.  Thin, constant head. Sour, bitter taste -- like sour patch kid without the sweet turn.  Citrus rinds.  Fizzy with a lasting sour finish. Refreshing

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2008 Smaller corked bottle.  Pours a perfectly clear deep gold with lively carbonation and a thin diminishing head.  Aroma is initially cork, then some farmhouse funkiness, and followed by a ton of lactic sourness.  Flavor is extremely sour and acidic, wierd sour-sweetness on the tip of the tongue kind of like sour patch kids. Some woody and earthy notes in the middle, and finishes bone dry with lots of sourness.  Very nice overall.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2006 Aroma: sour, lime, citrus, strawberries, really musty, grapes, leather, leaves.
Appearance: turbid orange yellow grey brownish. Yellowy white head (short).
Flavor: sour, vaguely bitter, very berryish acidity (as of black currant), some sweetness (?), roasted.
Palate: smooth & harsh, corrosive, sharp, slightly slimy, cool.
The aroma has a musty, horse blanket, and barnyard elements.  The color is golden with a fizzy white head.  The flavor is sour and tart with a slight honey touch.  The finish is acidic.

Classic example.  The horse blanket is moderatly high, though not at all overwelming.  Tart but not too sour. Very rich beer with complex shipwreck(wet wood) and lactic notes. One of my favorite lambics.

Bottle, thanks to a trade I did at Christmas with CaptainCougar, shared with Blankboy, Hogtown Harry, Jerc, and GregClow.  First impression:  Funky!  Incredibly musty aroma, wet hayfield, barnyard, yeast, dust, wow.  First sip is just as startling with that real earthy barnyard like taste.  Each sip reveals a little more as you adjust, with lots of yeast, lemon, and citrus taste pinging off the back of your throat.  As Jerc said, this beer has character and is on another level compared to the Guezes I have had up to this point.  Stunning stunning stuff, I could gladly sit down with another bottle of this all to myself any time.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- courtesy of tupalev. Pours a hazy orange with a spare white head and some floaties. Aroma is funky, sour, musty, cheesy and other stuff that shouldnt smell good but it does -- It really, really does. The flavour is sour and crazy mouth-puckering concentrated CITRUS! Like chewing on citrus rind. Its good though, if you like that kind of thing. I definitely couldnt drink a whole bottle of this to myself but shared amongst friends its a really nice treat.

Like licking a horseblanket in a room full of pies after drinking a glass of unsweetened lemonade.  Dry and refreshing.  Effervescent.  Perfectly medium bodied.  Whats not to like about licking a horseblanket?  Mmmmmm.

great geuze!! nice horseblanket and lemon in the nose. tasted not as sour as expected, lemon, grapes and a lot of good classical lambic notes. finishes long and sourrish. smooth body. and  oh the cork almost made a hole in a concrete wall :)

I wanted not to like it. I really did. When it comes right down to it, this beer is the ultimate example of why I hate most other sour beers and lambics - they lack character. Throwing a bunch of brett into something does not make it a decent beer. This, has character.

A murky cidery appearance with a miniscule white head. Complex yeasty must in the aroma, acidic damp golden retriever, hay/straw. Mouth puckeringly sour first impression is offensive in its onslaught, but persistence is rewarded as it wanes with each brave sip. Sour-tart, fruity notes, akin to chewing a mouthfull of lemon seeds at times. Lingering lemon-grapefruit is surprisingly strong, gripping at the back of the throat. Average palate is pleasantly effervescent. Grew on me more and more with each sip, but I am not sure I would want a bottle to myself - Decisively better than Coors Winterfest. :)

"Why would we have smelled wet sheep exactly?" Harry: "Well it they are wet, and warm, and close..."

Bottle (375ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jer and tupalev - tupalevs bottle.  Oh, dear, what a wonderful gueuze.  Poured hazy orange with a smallish white head.  Aroma of serious funk - sour lemon and other citrus, yeast, cheese, wet sheep - gets even more sour and peppery as it warms - my nose hairs were curling up.  Taste follows the aroma, very sour lemon, yeast tang galore, with the rich lemon and grapefruit its very juicy and easy to drink.  Mouthfeel is thick, acidic, lively and bitter - nearly perfect.  Best gueuze Ive ever had.  Thanks for this one, Jeff!

Bottle. pours a beautiful  orange-amber with a small white head that dissipates rather quickly. good carbonation. Typical gueuze aromas--barnyard, sour, funk, and a bit of vinegar. more funk in the taste, vinegar, and I even think i am catching a taste of olives (or strong olive oil) on the palate. A superb gueuze that I wish i had more of.

A beautiful looking beer, with lots of carbonation and a nice head and lacing.  Tart, sour, tangy.  I think this is my first gueuze, so its hard for me to peg the flavors, theyre just so different.  Bready, tangy, very sour.  Full of interesting flavors and definitely worth a try.

"Eaglefan keeps getting me to try these lambics. This one did surprise me a little. Poured a hazy orange color with a pretty head. Aroma was different and only thing i could make out for sure were apples. Flavor was just funky like the rest of the style, nice and tart but didnt twist my mouth around as much. "

375ml bottle. Poured slightly cloudy, deep honey gold with an enormous bubbly white head that diminished to a thin coating over the course of the first half of the glass. The nose is OUTSTANDING, very yeasty (horse blanket, a little funky sweat), shades of champagne, with noticeable sourness. Absolutely wonderful aroma. I could smell this all day. Flavor is massively sour (no vinegar that I can detect) with more funky yeast character and champagne. Tingly spices, maybe ginger-spicy a little bit?, definitely some wood. Faint cherry note. Bubbly on the palate. Dry finish with plenty of lingering sourness. Wow, what a beer.
Bottle at Wildeman, Amsterdam. Great nose, on this great beer. Very sour, esp on finish, but smooth too, with a flavour that is balanced, drinkable, with the right amount of sweetness too. Superb.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 Bottle. Dirty gold colour thickish white head.  Farmyardy lemon aroma, some sourness. In mouth fine, with more sour lemon and funkyness. Finish has more of the same. Bit of an aquired taste. Not as extreme as same. Lemony  acids balance the funkyness. Fine and quite interesting. Not sure Id want more than one of these a week though. 3.6/5.0.  Re-rate Christmas Day 2008.  First beer of the day and what a way to start.  So drinkable it is untrue.  The farmyard, bretty aroma, the lemon flavours, the mouthfeel is soft and just right with a little fullness from the carbonation.  Refreshing.  Would have this as my first beer of the day, in the middle and at the end.  Almost as good as the bottle at the Waterhuis in Gent pre-Zythos 2008 that is the best Ive ever had.

Bottle: Pours a pale copper color with a fizzy white head that sounds like a Cola when settling. If you didnt know anything about this beer you could tell it was going to be sour by just looking at it through the bottle. The muddy sediment on the bottom of the cork was not appealing. I did enjoy the citrus/apple aroma but found the flavor powerfully sour. To me this beer was too acidic and overrated!

I think I was ruined by an old friend of mine.  He says hes got some stuff he wants to bring by, and one of them was this incredible, liquid heaven in a green bottle. This is simply one of the greatest beers Ive ever had, and look forward to the Cantillon someday.  Thanks aspidites!!

The beer after removing the wire basket and cork from the green 375ml green bottle sets in my glass a beclouded amber color with a voluminous creamy light tan head that lingers long, leaving a thick covering of lace to surround the glass. Nose has a distinct somewhat sweet wet moldy straw aroma, underpinned by a staunch tartness, musty, but still appealing to me; start is first a bit sweet, followed by a massive sourness, with the body light to moderate in feel. Finish has a tongue biting acidity, with the sourness clinging to the palate like Jack Benny to a dime. What a magnificent brew, one Ive wanted to sample for many years, trust me it was certainly worth the wait.

Bottle in gueuze tasting. To my taste, this is the best example of the style currently available that Ive had so far. Powerful barnyard/horseblanket, citrus/apple encircled by a dominant hay aroma that welcomes you. In a blink of an eye, you know that youre in front of something serious. Attack of sharp dustiness but less sourness then the Cantillon gueuze 96. Taste holds for a long period of time in a strong full body that lead to astringency.

Bottle. Poured a hazy amber color with a large creamy white head that lasted. Good citrus and yeast aroma. 
Medium body. Moderate sour fruit flavor with a long citrus finish. Very good refreshing citrus brew.

Pale copper with disappearing head. Strong sour grapefruit flavor, with some lychee. Minor hay notes, a bit of weak hop bitterness that adds needed balance. Liquidy, astringent. Futile search for complexity. Eat a lychee and suck on a lemon and youll get the idea. Not very good, but very strong and worth trying.

Dusty deep gold.  Nose lightly dark, a bit sour, fruity and tart, kind of smells like vaguely moldy citrus and, in yet another one of those "I never thought Id say this" moments, I mean that in a good way.  Flavor very dry, quick sharp bite of sourness, good farmyard depth to it.  Some sour fruitiness, very dusty and musty.  Not quite as flavorful as expected, I do enjoy the fact its not Cantillon-esque with overpowering sourness, but its a bit more subtle than Id like.  Crisp and incredibly dry at the end.  Gueueze-wise, really quite incredibly drinkable.  I wouldnt have thought a gueuze could be a session beer, but this is close.

Cloudy, yellowish orange.  Really nice aroma of corn, lemon, cherry and white wine, plus smoke and dust, plus some metallic aroma I cant quite place.  Sour, as one might expect. Flavors of citrus tempered with flint and dust, plus lemonaid and smoke. Really drinkable. Big thanks to Jcapriotti for the trade!

UPDATED: APR 5, 2006 I secured a couple of bottles of this from From the Vine in Columbus, Ohio.  And after this, I dont think I like lambic all that well.  Not that its bad or gross, I just dont think it does it for me.  Anyhowpopped this sucker open and it exploded lambic everywhere.  Fortunately I was near the sink and saved my floorfor the most part.  Once it stopped, and I was able to get it in a glass, I discovered that it was hazy orange and golden with a nice white head.  The aroma was very interesting with sour fruit (cherries), and light barnyard notes.  Full and crisp really.  The taste was nothing if not sour!  Not as sour as La Folie, but pretty darn sour.  I also managed to note some finishing tartness, and horse blanket (I think I actually get that description now).  Definitely funky.  Mouth feel was nice.  Smooth, medium body and finish.  Interesting, as with most lambics Ive tried, but this stuff is just not for me.

Bottle: What was left of this one after it exploded all over Indiana_Reds kitchen was delightful.  Somebody stop the carbonation quickly.  I thought I was at the NBA Finals with Magic Johnson . . .  Anyway, it has aromas of dried, sweet apricots, apple cider and plastic.  The taste is extremely tart which I like.  This is the Sour Patch kids of the beer world.  I loved the feel -- it is thin and immediately dissipates after drinking which seems appropriate for this style.  Thanks Indiana_Red!

Bottle Blew its cork and erupted tan foam all over my kitchen.  The remaining   of the 375ML bottle had very nice cidery aromas of apples, pears ets.  Cloudy, orange light tan color.and a short lived lively head. Flavor was the expected dry sour flavor common to the style.  Im afraid a bit too much sediment was in with the last couple ounces in my sampling.  A nice tart and, yes, quenching brew.  Thanks to Degarth for slipping this top 50 ber in my box today.

A big thanks to Walt for this one. Lively looking ale, hazy and foamy. Clean, sharp, funky horse blanket and yeast aroma with some sour apple. Very quenching and sour. Horsey flavors with some minerals and what reminds me of nopalito(cactus). Very well balanced. Not overly tart or acidic with nice body and carbonation. Excellent.

bottle. pours an orangish golden color. overflowed when i uncorked. huge sour, horseblanket aroma with subtle sweetness hidden in there some where. taste is very bitter and sour with a strong funkiness in it as well. very good but a definate sipper.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2013 Bottle at home. Pours a clear golden with a small white head. Smells of grain and hints of vinegar. Dry and sweet with a medium sourness. Aromas of grain with appleas and vinegar and hints of sweat. Also aromas of funghi barnyard. Medium to light bodied. High carbonation. 

Original rating from Dec 2005: Pours a slightly hazy amber with a disappearing white head. Very sour with aromas of vinegar, headache and a hint of apple. Very bitter finish... an upside.

One fourth of the bottle was lost in shipping.  It appears to have just squeezed out around the cork.  The remainder appears unharmed.  Beautiful aroma of nectarine, green apple, almond, cherrywood.  Appears a hazy unfiltered golden yellow color, with a strong yellow head that dissipates.  Flavor is electric, intensely sour, with aprictot and lemon flavors predominant.  Palate is medium, effervescent, and appropriate.  While not my favorite style of beer, this is a fine example of a geuze, and equal to the sum of its parts.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2007 Dark orange nearly opaque, with a short lived champagne like head.  This is an intense gueuze that attacks the palate and the throat with good, but strange spontaneously fermented weirdness; it actually made me cough a few times.  Powerful eye watering aroma that includes wheat, yeast, and juniper. Powerful flavor.  Sour, light citrus, herbs, and more yeast. Strange slimy sediment that doesnt harm the flavor.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2007 Nose has lots of grassy/musty notes and is very concentrated, there is also a big overripe sour oranges aroma. Hazy orange in color with a beautiful creamy white head.  Flavor is quite sour in the fore then musty with hints of the cork it was capped and then lots of sweet citrus fruits plus apple and pear.  The finish is again musty and funky, but dry and slightly acidic. It walks through such an amazingly distinct range of flavors that even if you dont like what you taste it is hard not to be impressed. That amount of distinct flavor ranges in a beer is rare. I started drinking it too cold and the flavors become more intense and varied as it warms. Worthy of the praise.

12/16/05: Bottle. Sour nose with some hay and must.  Golden orange body outlined with yellow coloring.  Very active, with an explosive pour.  Flavors include green apple, feta cheese, grapefruit and Muscat grape.  Dry finish.  Quite lovely.

Gift from Secret Santa. Arrived frozen and leaking a little. Drank the next day. Very cloudy orange. Still poured with a big bubbly head and had a lasting lacing. Aroma of vinnegar and cheese.  Deeper aroma of sour citrus. At the tip of the tongue the flavour is citrus. The back of the tongue and finish are shocked with a sour blast.  Successive sips are more balanced front to back. Occassional twinges in the eyes from the sourness. Mouthdrying. Very interesting. I think it survived the shock. Thanks Santa.
Soooo delicious I have to call ClarkVV and tell him how much I was enjoying this oh so beatiful Lambic.  I love lambics so much I cant even describe it.

12oz bottle from goldtwins shared with JoshuaH.  Explosive out the bottle with a hazy orange color and a foamy white head that recedes down to leave a small film. Nose is barnyard, grass and hay, the nose itself is sour and citrus fruity. Taste is sour and fizzy up front, light notes of orange and lemon, quite sour and grassy, very earthy. Finishes with a pucker face in the end and a light filmy palate.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 orangish color thick beautiful white head some nice lacing.  Some horse blanket scent a bunch of sour fruits lightly salty aroma some leather maybe some apple.. definately yeasty.  Pal is super fizzy aggressive and coated.  Flavor is a touch bitter almost over carbonated some strong bitter apples and hints of pear very bitter.  Decent stuff.
*UPDATE 2010
Definite horse blanket in the aroma, very earthy very sour lots of fruits (AR: +1) Still as sour as I always remembered, but not as overpowering as i thought last time I rated it.  much more mellow than I expected but very complex and enjoyable.

I was suprised that the bottle opened so uneventfully.  No explosion, no foam, just a nice pop.  Bright orange color, no head.  I have this pretty cold, so Im sure the aroma will get stronger as the temp goes up.  Currently it is pretty mild as far as gueuzes go.  Plenty of complexity in the strongly acidic flavor.  Lots of citric and bitter fruit with a dry palate that scrapes the roof of your mouth.  I coughed after the first gulp.    Now that I have gotten started its pretty easy to consume in big gulps.  Tasty.

( botlle 37.5 cl; 4 months over time) Gold-yellow colour, bit cloudy. Overwhelming aroma/ Soft taste in the beginning, strong at the end, heavy carbonation. Finish is saur but still fruity, but very enjoyable which lasts long. A Grand-cru under the Gueuzes.

Pours cloudy gold, with a large, white head. Aromas are loads of lemon and yeast, with some mustiness too. Flavor is sour lemon, with yeast, and apples in there as well. Thanks to Mullman for this bottle.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2009 Orange golden beer with a small white head. Lemon and grapefruit dominates the aroma with notes of wood, leather and green meadow. Dry and tart, refreshing juicy flavour with a long lasting grapefruit peel tartness and bitterness. Exceptionally drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2007 Clear orange golden pour with a thick bubbly white head. As soon as I stick my nose in the glass a wave of musty cheese hits me, followed by wafting acidity and fruits. After I swallow the first sip Im amazed by this beers class and elegance. This is a fine and delicate tightly woven tapestry dedicated to must, cheese, acidity and fruits coated by dust and cobwebs. This work of art instills strong emotions in me, happyness, peace, I also feel extremely relaxed. This is an unforgettable experience, a true masterpiece.
Bottle. White head. Light orange, lemon armoma, agressive lemon flavor, thin palate.

Beer #100. Orange colour. White head that disappears quickly. Apples and lemon in the aroma. Some barnyard aroma aswell. Very tart flavour. Some apple taste too. Dry and crisp finish. This is a great beer.
Honey colour. Aroma of flowers, lemons, pears. Main flavour is sour, other flavours are bitter and sweet.

Wonderful aroma, bold mixed fruit with that flowery, wet hay, barnyard brettanomyces funk.  Clear golden amber with a dense white head.  Flavor actually has more going on than the aroma, complex fruitiness - pears, apples, lemons, berries, a very floral/perfumy flavor, high acidity.  Medium body with high carbonation, finishes crisp and dry.  A very intense gueuze with strong flavors and high acidity that remains crisp and refreshing.

Deep golden and with a big white head. Very complex, vinous aroma of apples and lemons and wood. Vanilla is there too. Dry mouthfeel, fizzy, dry refreshing finish. One of those beers that are a delight to drink, but a headache to describe. Truly a world classic.

From secret Santa.  Poured a golden/orange color body with a fizzy white head.  Aroma was lemons and granny smith apples.  Very tart flavor with apples, grapes, pears, and a little citrus.  A touch of yeast in the finish.  A very nice gueuze.

Orange Coloring with White Head. Very Sour/Tart Fruit and Spice Aroma. Continues to be Very Tart, with Citrus Fruit and Beligian Spices Overlaying..Very Dry Ending.  Hard to compare sour and tart to other like-beers, but Overall Very Easy to Drink..Not as Potent as Some Gueuze Brews. Easy to Enjoy and Quite Lovely.

37.5 cL bottle.  Crystal clear golden pour into my Champagne flute... more hazy on subsequent pours.  Bubbles rose constantly, and a small layer of white head was maintained throughout the drink.  Pungent aroma shot out of the bottle after the cork was pulled.  Sour apples, wet leaves, aromatic cheese, lime, vinegar, and grapes... to name a few... hit the nose with force.  Effervescent across the palate.  Tart and sour throughout, with a high dose of acidity noted especially at the top of the throat.  Sour apples, old flowers, lime, and a hint of leather came through in the flavor.  Quite sweet for the style, but it worked very well.  Dry vinous finish.  Very complex, and surprisingly refreshing!

Huge white head goes quickly but lasts.    Very strong apple aroma.  Hazy honey color. Tartiness starts immediately and opens up as it goes across your palate.  Beautiful example of a lambic.   It does have a crazy bitter note at the front of the palate.  Lemongrass with a touch of  insectiside salty bitter is the only way I can describe the note.

Thanks Dr. Bill- Pours an slightly dark orange/gold color with a slight cloudiness, virtually no head or lacing.  The aroma has a strong bite with an almost flowery like undertone.  The flavor is very tart and sour, just the way I love it!  Nice dry vinous bite to the end!!

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2011 Ive waited awhile to enjoy this one.  I popped the cork and was immediately met by the aroma.  A deliciously sour, cheesy, hay, vinegar, and upscale leather wafted from the bottle.  The flavor starts with a hugely salty and sour lime body that morphs to a mushroom jack cheese and leather glove.  It has a lingering lemongrass flavor.  When drinking this, youre met by a huge fizzyness that is like Pop Rocks exploding in your mouth.  So tart that it wrinkles ones face.  After drinking, its time to reflect how beautiful in appearance this beer is.  It radiates light like its creating the light.  The body is a shiny copper/bronze and has a thin, nearly non-existent white head.  For a gueuze, this is good stuff.  I wish it more leathery.  Granted, theres a lot in there, but its my world!  I want more! 8, 4, 8, 4, 17 = 4.1

This keeps getting better and better.

Glowing orange, sparkling with no head, but a white lacing. Aroma is sour, very cidery, some fruit, but not sure. Can smell a musky barn and tartness. Flavor is quite tart moreso sour. Very very dry finish. Makes you pucker up. A good spin the bottle beer for that factor alone. Still burnt vacuum. Crazy style, barn, cheese, funky, just not at all right. "It is like Guuu huh laaaaaaaaaaaaa, makes the mucas in your throat go crazy like you just drank orange juice and you got all that mucas." -Andrew Thomas. Makes you flap your gums like Mr. Ed.
Sour and funky nose, with huge notes of cheese and that special barnyard flavor. Hazy orange brew, with a small white head. Lemony flavor, huge sourness, salty, cheesy and very refreshing.
UPDATED: JAN 18, 2006 Finish is dominated by oak, wood and some leather. It is quite round and not too bitter. A very balanced and pleasant Gueuze. Great refreshment!

Hazy pale orange, thin white cottony head. Yeasty, salty slight rubbery nose. Sour, salty unripe fruits flavour. Some notes of lemon and grapefruit. Refreshing with a red berry palate. Long aftertaste. This is good stuff!!!

I enjoy this all too much.  The aroma is absolutely great, probably my favorite in a gueze; it makes me drool.  Out front is the leathe, followed by damp soil, acetic smells, and even a touch of lemon.  Flavor is great, but not too acidic to be enjoyed.  I will have to work this into my regular rotation!

Bottled. The cork came out with a bang, but luckily the beer stayed in. It pours a light copper colour with a big, bubbly head. The aromas are a wonderful mixture of oak, hay, vinegar and grapefruit. Quite a acidic and tart taste. Very dry. Oaky, grapefruity notes. Ends with a long, dry and grapefruity finish. Really excellent, though I realize that I like the lemony tartness of a berliner weisse better. Many thanks go out to bierkoning for the bottle.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2008 A Mes rate:First off I was stunned I have not rated this as it is a regular for me. This particular one was tasted at the fantastic Bison bar in Brussels. My god this is how it should be done. I can imagine it being brewed in a dusty old barn by an aged boffin with equipment that has stood the test of time and is held together with patches and cobwebs then ferried around in barrels pulled by a faithful old horse. It is simply amazing stuff. Full of funk and farmyard charateristics with lemon peel and other citric notes. Wonderful hazy golden body with a great head that lasts as long as your glass still contains liquid and some attractive chunky lace. Smoother than a lot of other lambics. Plenty of tart and sourness about it though. Sweet to begin with then waves of delicious tart and sour stuff come through with sandlewood, oak and leather later. Wonderful dry finish that leaves you craving for more. Mouthfeel is just about unsurpassed by anything. For me it really does not get much better than this.

Not fully cogniscent of what it is Im drinking...way too many odd things going on on every sensory level.   I do know that Im drinking a quality drink...but its a little like walking late into a foreign language sci-fi film with special effects going off all over the screen and strangely costumed characters flying around speaking a weirdly  futuristic foreign language...Im not quite sure Im going to figure this one out.  It is, however, VERY SOUR!  That much I get.

Murky yellow red-orange.  Tall rocky white head.  Earthen mustiness, acidic tartness in the aroma.  Large tartness matched by a funkiness reminiscent of molding leaves.  Crisp astringent finish.  Mouthfeel is dry and filmy.
This is my first Lambic and the bitter/sour flavors caught me off guard. That said, i can see how this is an acquired taste that I will be acquiring...

The aroma is of unripe pears, sour cherries, and tamarind.  The head is bulbous and looks like egg whites -- it distinctly holds its shape.  Flavors are sour, like the flesh of a kaffir lime.  Lots of citrus zest and a heavy dose of funk.  The mouth hits hard at first, but effervesces and evaporates smoothly for a very clean and pleasant finish.  Definitely a palatte cleanser!

Brilliant clarity and mellow orange in color with a sudsy, foamy head.  Im loving the aroma: hay, chamomile, freshly squeezed lime juice, lemon zest, burlap sacks, and a subtle spicing undercurrent of coriander and oregano.  First rush of flavor is like sinking the teeth into the juiciest sour grape known to man.  Souring and puckering while highlighting a yeasty funkiness.  Rhubarb, granny smith apples and light figs come to mind, cloistered amidst an effervescent persona and a light-to-medium body.  Baguette crust, a little salty and sour mash round out its complexity.  Encases the palate and then cleanses it.

Hazy orange/copper. Thick, bubbly, off-white head. Strong wild yeast aroma with some sweet undertones. Sour yeast, pine, and citrus flavors. Clean and very dry finish. Pleasant lingering aftertaste accentuates the sour yeast. Body is medium but the flavor fills your mouth. Excellent gueuze.

copper orange pour with a white head. tart sweet aroma that has some sour, great barnyard aroma. sweat sour taste  with some chalky mouthfeel, sour tart candy flavor, so amazingly complex. some bready flavors underneath strong pluym and peach notes with a lingering woody flavor in the finish. fantastic

Ive been searching for this one for a year and a half now, and thanks to Beeryum Ive got the opportunity to try it.  the bottle opened with a healthy "crack!" and poured a clear orangey-amber color with lots of fizz up the body.  the head is rocky and white, crackling as its poured.  the aroma is musty, yeasty, barnyard, and sour.  very high carbonation, flavor is sour, dry, tart, but _very_ clean and _nothing_ aggressive.  a little acidic, but not in the dry finish.  disappearing aftertaste.  this is the cleanest gueuze Ive had, and now I have an understanding - its a top 50 beer because its so unoffensive for an excellent gueuze.  I prefer this style to be a bit more daring and wilder, but it makes sense why the majority finds this most appealing.  big thanks to Beeryum for sending me two of these!!

Interesting it reads to store the bottle on its side. Pour is a amber honey gold. Excellent looking indeed. Aroma is dirty socks to start with, but comes to accent the bitter/sour notes. Very sour but interesting. Almost along the lines of a sour flemmish ale. acidic and grapefruit coverings. excellent introduction for me. Kind of expensive but, hey, what the hell...
Bottle. Nose is pure geuze in the best of ways. Taste-sour and acidic with the nice citrus notes. There is nothing that I can say about this beer that hasnt already been said. Wonderful.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 golden hue w/ lively carbonation.  tart, pungent and expressive, this brew is very delicious.  it pours golden hue with lively carbonation.

37.5 cl bottle, bbe March 06. Dark amber/apricot colour, almost untransparently hazy, relatively small (for a lambic actually quite large) big-bubbled off-white head leaving a thick lace after a while. Complex aroma of lactic acid, sherry, dry wood and a sweetish perfume-like note. Juicy, peachy, mouth-filling yet very dry taste, sour and woody with unassertive but clearly present hop bitterness. Surprisingly warming and pleasantly fizzy palate. My favourite oude gueuze.

375 ml bottle, thanks to slob for ths beauty as a bonus!  Pours light orange with a slight haze and a moderate off-white head that slowly diminished to a ring around the rim.  Aroma is complex and mysterious - sour fruits, dry and vinous, sweat and funk, oak and wet wool.  Flavor is also complex and changes as it warms, tart and dry overall, but with tiny hints of sweetness at moments, champage-like with young oak and tannic notes, also an astringent funk and quince in the finish.  Light to medium body with very fine and delicate carbonation.  After a visit to Belgium my tastes are maturing and Im able to enjoy these wild-fermentation wonders.  Again many thanks to Bert for sending this my way.

Dark orange color with a medium head.  Aroma of sour wheat and honey.  More of both of them in the taste with an added citrus zing of orange.  Overall it was more subdued than most gueuzes Ive tried.  Nice.

Cloudy orange and bronze with a small white head.  Aromas are fruity, sour and musty - as expected with soft cheese and citrus bite.  Nothing aggressive. Flavours are citrus fruit acidicy with cheesy feet mustiness.  Hints of peaches and a good dry finish.  Suitably farmhouse in flavour but not off-putting.  Good gueuze.

Bought this at State Line in Elkton, MD, and saved it for #1999.  This is my first top 50 beer in awhile.  Pours turbid orange/dark straw with big, white head.  Aroma of sour fruit, hopcit, female piss.  Tastes sour-fruity, with a multi-layered hopcit, sour fruit, and malt at mid-palate and at the finish.  Gets dryer and more tart as it warms.  This one is complex and well balanced.  Having said that, I do not consider it a top 50 brew, but the bar has been set high for this one, young Skywalker.

An outstanding gueuze, with crisp taste reminding of fresh hay in the fields. Very refreshing on a hot summer day. One of the best real gueuzes in my view. Girardin brewery, situated in the countryside, produces its own ingredients (except hops and the fruits used for kriek, framboise), as it is also a farm. The black label is the unfiltered (i.e. authentic) gueuze, the white label is the filtered version (i.e. less acidic and more commercial). Beginners should try several gueuzes to fully appreciate this exceptional beer.

Lihgt hazy orange amber color with faint green shine and with a snow white head. This beer has a refreshing aroma with hints of sour apples, rubarbe, citrus fruits, agrum and wet wood. The taste is very crisp and has a fenomenal balance. In the taste you can notice touche of renette applels, Cox orange, rubarbe-jam, grapefruit, Greek yoghurt and again wet birch-wood and tarte-tattin that brings the roundness in this great beer. In the afthertaste this beer leaves me the impression of the very berst artisanale Normandian Ciders.

Bottle---in a chimay glass---Pours an orange hue with  minimal white head with minimal to no lacing.  Aromas stinky feet, barnyard funk and I love those  because those are my favorites.  Flavors of sour goodness, on the back of the toungue and makes my mouth water mad crazy.  Flavors are delicious.  Sour, pugnant, slightt slight citrus note,  even the taste of it makes my toungue  salivate.  Very sour, with a dry finish, not at all sweet with a nice aftertaste.  I want more after each sip.  Mouthfeel is fizzy and carbonated, but not over the top.

Bottled.
Hazy orange coloured with an off white head.
Acidic aroma of barnyard with fruity notes.
Acidic flavour of wood with fruity notes.
Well balanced hoppy finish with notes of wood.

Bottle thanks to BierBauch.  Hazy golden color with a medium head that went away quickly.  Aroma of wood and citrus, some green apples, musty cobwebs and lemon.  Flavor is a real citrus bitter treat, pineapple and lemon as well as subtle oak in the aftertaste.  Palate is what I would expect, bitter but refined.  Quite the tastey drink.

This dark golden lambic poured with a modest white head that dissipated rather quickly. It smells like gueuze and it tastes like gueuze. In fact, it is a fine example of what gueuze is meant to be. The flavor is sour, yet fruity, with considerable carbonation. Thankfully, I had enough foresight to purchase several bottles.

Sampled at In De Wildeman in Amsterdam, Holland.

Golden.

Smells traditional and quite fragrent. Grapefruit, lemon, oak, cherries and lambic funk.

Strong, dry and superb. Grapefruit in the backround throughout which leads to orange and then a strong, lingering and spicy finish. This was a lovely tasting Gueuze. Superb.
Bottle. Hazy amber with a nice off-white head. Sour, yeasty, complex aroma. Good gueze flavor - sour, acidic, light fruit, dank, complex. HIgh carbonation. Finishes dry.
cloudy orange color.  SOur FuNkY aroma. Very "Im a freakin Gueuze, damn it" flavor. No off flavors whatsoever, just sour, tart, balanced goodness, maybe some lemononyness.  Awesome, i want more.

Normally Im not a big fan of gueuze, but this one really turned my head. Nice hazy orange colour with a very small off head. Aroma has some sourness, but is balanced with a low key sweetness. Sharp sour apple flavor, but in a very complex way as it has hints of dust, carbweb.

37,5cl Golden and slightly cloudy. Some yeast sediment clings to the inside of the bottle. Light layer of foam. Complex aromas. Wood, earth, sour, barnyardish, fruit, pepper, spices, dandylion flowers, grassy. Champagne like body. Sour, dry flavors. Herbal, tart interesting. Super dry finish. Classic example.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottle: Hazy golden, slight pink hue, large frothy white head, very strong carbonation, wonderful lacing. &nbsp Strong sour/woody aroma... oh lordy! &nbsp Smooth tartness on first sip. &nbsp Fairly dry, and very woody. &nbsp Very clean, smooth albeit spritzy, with a lingering tartness. &nbsp This stuff is simply outstanding!

Finally I am rating another Gueuze.
Trying to widen my tastes a little bit.Looks damn nice with an apricot color anda fine layer of creamy bubbles.
Nose is very nice as it is like a sour candy,peaches or something like that.Here goes.It is sour but I let my initial taste go and I like it.The sourness overrides the real fruity taste but I like this thing and now I will start to buy more of these.

Thanks to Enniskillen for this beer.

Pours a cloudy golden with a fizzy off-white head.  Wonderful aroma of sweet and sour apples and pears... extremely refreshing and complex.  Taste is very tart, with touches of apples and spice, leaving a dry sour finish.  A bit of toffee shows through eventually.  The taste didnt strike me as being as complex as the aroma, but a very good drink.
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2006 Bottle.  Sour vinegar and musty aroma.  Dark tan color with quick collapsing head.   Sour flavor initially with tart-tannic finish.   One of the best gueuze.

Bottle. Bitter, acidic, moldy, yeasty aroma. Unclear golden colour, big unstable head. Citrus acidic flavour, a little astringengy. Aftertaste has a hint of fruit, a tiny bit of sweetness. Refreshing on a spring day.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2008               Liquid sex! Amazing balance of Lemon acidity, sourness and malt. Liquid crystal on the palate with great mouthfeel. Wondrous nose and amazing finish. World class brew.

I say... Nice Beer as I sit here rating away. 
 Poured a lovely golden mid summer sunset and thin high altitude clouds as a cap. The Aroma is white grapes, whole pressed Granny Smith apple, peel, stems, seeds and all. Its rather woody, damp and spoiled, moldy and compounded with wet hay. I love it! Its so grassy and acidic, its uniquely clean yet filthy with compost. There is such a fascinating allure to this style for me. Huge lemongrass suggestions vinegar like yet notes of sweetness pop in every now and again. I would say that this particular Gueuze is oakyer than most slightly mellowed, I think. The entier tasting experience is Dry as the fires in Hell. 
I will have to sample another of the Gueuze style tonight for contrast!

i wont lie.  the commercial description here is not particularly helpful.anyway, this bottle is a gift from my friend juha in finland.  pours a hazy soft orange with a huge bubblegum aroma.  some yeast and citrus as well, with a monster head of nearly atom-sized bubbles.  highly carbonated.  the aroma and flavor do not mesh at all;  the dry tartness completely contradicts the sweet aroma.  despite this, the acid and sourness never take over completely, and it stays gorgeously drinkable  throughout.  evaporatively dry, as well.  easily the best gueuze i have had so far!

(on bottle) Never have I smelled anything so close to a urinal; without being a urinal. Pheww. Very lively out of the bottle, not exploding though. Nice,  hazy abricot color and a small, white, lasting head. The taste is very intense. At first a sour/citricv and almost stingy feeling to the palate. then comes a smal malty flavour, but soon the distinct taste of greapefruit-peel and stones, takes over. a mix between those worked very well, to me. End very fresh and after a few sips, you won´t stop drinking this stuff.

33 ml. bottle. Extremely cloudy yellow-orange, with retaining thin head around the rim, and lace. Aroma of cider and bleach. Initial taste of rounded softened apple juice sourness. Cannot be drunk quickly, only sipped. Sour vinegar and acid tongue freezing, that was tolerable. Medium in texture on the mouth. Thanks Clarkevv.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2006 Bottle:  Tart sour aroma with almost an apple cider aroma and light vinegar.  Pours a mostly transparent yellowish-orange with some floaties.  Quickly diminishing fizzy white head.  A light sour apple flavor up front that becomes a stronger and more tart in the finish.  Vinegar flavor is noticeable in the finish.  Sour aftertaste is short-lived.  Lots of small black sediment near the bottom of the bottle.  Seems to get a little more tart as I drink.  This is good, but not top 50 good.

Courtesy of wohlfs. Was pleasantly surprised by this one. Pours a golden orange color with little head. Huge tart aroma and flavor. Very dry mouthfeel but in a good way. Long sour/tart aftertaste. Well done.

Poured hazy yellowish orange with a small white head...smell is all across the board...funk, brett, lemons, dirt, peaches...taste is right there with it...not as sour as Id anticipated but sweet, hay, grass, sour...fantastic!!!!

Pours a murky peach. Thin head, great retention. Soft, full aroma of dry and sour cherries. Huge sour taste up front, mellows out and becomes more fruity and dry. Clean, dry feel throughout. Frothy, bubbley mouthfeel. Tangy all over. Finish could be longer.

Hazy golden with big fast disapearing white head.  Big aroma of  Brett acording to Engelsman. I don´t  know how to describe it but I like it. Big complex taste, citrus and sourness. Soft palate despite the complex soutness. Great beer .

Bottle.  Pours a hazy medium amber color.  Nice white head fades to a ring somewhat quickly.  No lacing.  Initially skunky Eurolager aroma slowly evolves into a funky acetic barny and tart aroma. Acetic flavors, drying and tart.  Carbonated nicely, spritely and refreshing.  Nice

Bottled, filtered, 375ml, Aged 2yrs; 
Clear as a bell, orangy, large head. Deliberately aged Geueze which still retains the sharp Bitter Lemon characteristic, but is slightly freindlier on the sourness. Pleasant deep bas flavour, malted biscuit with the side of tongue aromatic flavours complementing. A cracking beer.

Okay, I HAVE to say this first. The two people who rated this beer before me have absolutely no idea what a gueuze is supposed to be. Ignore their comments.

The beer: Pours with a lemony, slightly hazy color with a small lacy head. Smells of lemon, grapefruit, fresh hay, leather, a hint of tarragon. Wonderful.
The taste is a mixture of a very funky, earthy bottom note reminiscent of burnt mushrooms and an explosion at the top of yellow citrus fruit. The finish is amazingly clean. 

Not quite as funky as 3 Fountains, but much cleaner.

Pours slightly hazy orange-gold with thin wispy white head.  Tart, grapefruit like aroma.  Extremely tart and citrusy in flavor.  Little to no sweetness.  Ive tried other Lambics (Kriek and Framboise).  This was my first Gueuze and not what I was expecting at all.  As far as Lambics go, this is probably pretty good, but I prefer some sweetness.

Extreme disappointment does not come close to my analysis of this beer. I did not like this one at all. The aroma that escaped upon pouring reminded me of skunk, not "skunky" in the conventional sense, but the stench one occasionally encounters on extended car trips and someone has hit a skunk. Taste was somewhat better, though still much too sour, somthing like a berliner weisse but with more character. I was not able to finish the bottle. I really hope this was a one time occurance, maybe I got a bad batch, though I doubt I will ever purchase this one again.
350 ml bottle from ClarkVV. Thanks. Clear orange in color with a nice thin white head. Sweet and sour like aroma. Citrusy aroma. Palate is smooth. Refreshing beer and very drinkable.

350 ml bottle via ClarkVV. Thanks! Clearish orange, thin white head. Sweet and sour aroma and flavor that to me is similar to grapefruit. Extremely smooth palate. Explosive flavors. A little jolly rancher type character. Refreshing and drinkable.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Didnt think Id ever get to try this one.  Kudos to my friend Claude who swapped me this one for a bottle of Speedway.  Very foamy and overflowed from the bottle a bit.  Not too much wasted.  Poured an orange gold color with a small white foamy head, with nice lacing.  The only surprise about the aroma is how good the vinegar, barnyard, leather, blankety and woodiness smells were.  The best of any lambic Ive tried.  Taste is extremely tart, very citrusy, and very good and funky, like my moms old handbag was soaked in it.  The sour/tart overtones stay throughout the bottle, and the finish is nice and smooth.   We found ourselves smacking our lips big time at the end.  Great stuff.

small corked bottle into a flute....This is spritzy and sour with very nice sweet malty undertones and a little bit of the funk.  Looks very nice in the tall skinny glass and goes down suprisingly smooth.
yeasty sweet sour aroma, sour apple like taste that finishes in a sudden dryness. Very refreshing, altough Im still not a big fan(yet ) of the style

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2006 Bottled. Pours a murky off orange with an ivory head.  Aromas of oranges, lemon, grass, straw and mustiness.  Musty and sour with some straw notes as well as fruit (strawberries, lemon).  Dry and fizzy mouthfeel.  Has become one of my favorite Gueuzes.

Easily the best gueuze Ive had. The beer pours a beautiful pinkish amber verging on copper with a moderate, but dense, white head. The aroma is very fruity -- underripe peaches and apricots, horse blanket musty. The flavor is definitely sour, it comes across as salty by somehow activating those sensors on the tongue, but the saltiness turns into a puckering tartness on the back of the tongue. The tartness doesnt overwhelm the rest of the beer, though as gree peach/apricot fruit mingles with a slight bit of sweetened toast malt. All of these flavors meld wonderfully into a complex and tasty lambic. Easier to drink than I expected, actually.
Bottle. Musty, woody, yeast aroma. Slightly subdued with an odd touch to it. A hint of sweetness with lots of sourness and a full tannic body.

Average sized creamy off-white head, clear amber body... nice looking. Sweet yeast overall aroma. Like my socks, lemons, musty blue cheese, and hints of sweetness. Tart lemons with dry cobweb finish. It is quite balanced... tart as expected, but it has a lot of flavor and subtle sweet hints to back it up.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2005 Poured a hazy, medium orange color with a huge, huge white head. Aromas of citrus, lemons, yeast and leather. Sour and tart. Acetic. Lightly sweet as well. This took me by surprise and was a nice change to some of the mediocre beers the past couple of days.

Bottle: Slightly hazy bright orange/amber color with a small white head.  This color has more of a bright orange color to it then Ive seen in other gueuze.  Wow, the aroma is really nice - sour lemon, unripened orange, grapefruit, wet straw, old leather, blue cheese, sweaty sock, old wood, cobwebs, dusty barnyard, fresh apple.  Taste is tart, but not overwhelmingly so.  Sour, sticky lemon and grapefruit hit my tongue initially, followed by a tart wheat, wet wood, sweet & sour cherry, honey for a brief second, and apples.  Sucking bubbles of air into my mouth really brings out the sour cherries and some moldy cheese notes.  This beer seems to effortlessly, though in a suble way, make the switch from sour to sweet and back again as jimmack04 has noted.    The more I drink, the more sweet and complex it seems to get. Finish lasts for a long time, also alternating sweet & sour, with notes of peach, apple, honey coated grains, dry wood, lemon rind. Light, spritzy carbonation, creamy feel thats just real slightly watery.  Excellent stuff!

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2007 Pours hazy golden colored with a frothy white head. Sourish aroma, grapefruit and wood, full and extremely well balanced. Tart and dry flavor with lots of grapefruit notes and a nice dry woody finish. A really nice gueuze, nice balanced and very very tasty.

Bottle thanks to Flemdawg. Golden color with a small white head. Unbelievable funky aroma! Sour lemon, wet leather,
straw, moldy cheese. Flavor is sour, but not overly so. Probably the most
perfectly balanced gueuze Ive had.
Seems to go from tart to mildly sweet and back to tart once again with a bit of mustiness. Excellent!

Thanx, Jimmack and Joeec. I am not fond of Gueuze, so My rating will be low. Poured yellowish, murky and unappealing. Tasted Like rotten lemons. Sour and not very good. But I tried it, opened my limits if you will. This is a sour world I am not ready for.

this gueze poured a murky yellow with a white head.the flavor and aroma were bolth very sour,with hints of lemon.the first taste made my eyes burn and my face pucker.i am still venturing into the gueze world so its hard for me to give a fair rating.but i personally like a touch of fruit in my lambics.
light cloudy, orangish brown appearance....subtly sour aroma, with spice notes and some hops....flavor is similar to smell with sour notes, spices, and a touch of lemon

Hazy light orange body, thin/medium off-white head.  Sour aroma with cheese rind and musty barnyard odors.  Surprisingly subdued sourness in the body; still complete with musty earthiness, cheese rind, and wood but surprisingly smooth.  I expected an acidic sharpness but this somehow balances the sourness with the mustiness and earth.  A touch grassy as well.  Everything here seems to be in perfect balance, and this is the unusual beer that, despite its high overall rating, is highly accessible to people who dont frequent the style.  Thanks Larry (goldtwins) for the bottle!

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2010 Surprisingly dark golden yellow pour, moderately hazy, almost orangey. Amazingly balanced aroma. Huge sweet malt kiss complements the character loaded brettanomyces that come out horsey, cheesy and sweaty. Funky and clean at the same time, but above all elegant and farmy. Apparently sweet which have me anticipating a dessert gueuze. Notes of vanilla, cask wood, sand, earth. Indeed very sweet for a gueuze, this is not really what I was anticipating, but I can appreciate greatness when I taste it and this is just as good as Cuvée René with incredible nostalgic character. Pie crust and bread. Not very acid at all, just a balancing tartness. Honeyed maltiness gets overwhelmed by wood juice, powdery glue-like flavors. I dont really feels the taste was as good as the incredible aroma, but it does grow on me as it warms. It just has this terrific sandy dry-out effect that asks to be let on the table taking some air and breathing like fine wines. Gentle astringency, fitting low carbonation. Medium-full bodied and smooth on the tongue. One of the best in its kind and worthy of every bit of praise it gathers. Complex beyond imagination all while being insanely drinkable. Thanks again Per.  A further sampling confirms to me that the real girardin gueuze outclasses cuvée rené by a fair margin as my favorite gueuze. Highly drinkable yet very assertive. It just does everything as I want it and for now stands as the best Ive had, though some of those rare drie fonteinen look like they could stand up to its level.  It throws me on the floor every time, up you go. 5, perfect.

Sweet yet tart aroma with an expansive maltiness.  Very clean and lightly phenolic.  Insistent but polite.  Opaque orange-tan body with decent white head that recedes to cover.  Assertive sourness shows plenty of woody character. Malty but dry.  Soft texture in the mouth.  Medium-light body has very low carbonation. Bottle enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere.  Thanks, Per!

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2012 New rating: At pretasting to USA comes to Skövde, 12-10-19. Spmewhat hazy golden beer with à small offwhite head. Rubber aroma, hay, leather, barnyard, citrus, floral, yeasty, grapefruit, sourish, leather, grapes, lemongrass, hay. Rubber flavor, yeasty notes, grapefruit, sour, citrus, leather, lemongrass, really sour, floral, dandelions, sourish, hay, dry bitter, rosebuds, spicy notes, grapes, apples.
Old rating: 3.7. Cloudy yellow/apricot color with a white head. Has a sour/sourish aroma, yeasty, with different fruits and of course quite alot of grapefruit. Fruity flavor and sour in a balanaced way.

Amber with white head. Big hay/barnyard aroma with sour grapes, berries and cane sugar. Sweet candy, grapes, barnyard in flavour. So tart yet so balanced. Also some apple and honey notes. Smooth medium feel. Great gueuze

I rarely plan these things, but this time I took a look in the cellar - what else could I choose for rating 1882?  This Lambic is FUNKIFIED!  Yeah - aroma is a killer on this one!  Barnyard, weed patch, citrus lemon peel, generally "outdoorsy".  Glowing golden, hazy, medium head, great lacing.  Taste is very smooth bodied and full of tartness, sweet up front, bubbly middle, sour, woody (oak), baby greens, dandelions, pepper - all of these flavors blend deliciously.  Midway through, I decided to pair this with some gorgonzola - yum - the combo first brought out more sweetness in the beer and then as the cheese warmed it was more of a sour/tart flavor.  Excellent lambic.  (Thanks Goldtwins!!)

Thanks to brandon for passing this off along to me sometime back in a trade. This beer poured a fairly clear gold color with a thin soapy white head, which actually was more of a film and an active degree of carbonation. This is one of those beers that you could rate ten times and still have new things to say about it..so here goes. The aroma is funky cheese at its finest. Barnyard, leather, lemon, vinegar, citrusy esters, cheese and tartness. Sour nose, but a nice hint of sweetness. The taste is TART!!!! A sour super complex carbonated time bomb that just explodes in your mouth. You had better pucker up because this acidic, lemony, leathery, barnyardy, cheesy flavor is going to whoop you! Where did all of this carbonation come from..I saw some in the glass prior to tasting, but it just explodes in your mouth! This is definitely a total sipping beer! Good luck taking anything longer than a gulp of this. This left a good strong coating on the mid-portion of the tongue and wow did the tartness of this brew get concentrated in the finish as it warmed. Full bodied, very complex and sour but not horribly dry finish. Beware of that last sip because WOW is it a tart doosy!

Poured a cloudy medium orangish color with a small white head, no lacing, potent aroma of sourness, hay, pepper and other barnyard follies.  Of the few guezes i have had the flavors in this one blended together the best, from sourness to sweetness to spicyness this one had it all. Eminently drinkable and one of my new favorites.

WOAH!  Vinegar (almost smells like urine) and soury fermented fruit, vinious, and yet sweet.  Golden orange color but lacking in the head and lacing dept.  Soury and sweet in the mouth w/ the vinious vinegar and fruit.  This beer had great effervescence and a crisp light body.

Pours a clear, distilled color peach: lovely. Head is very short, just a thin white doily.  Smell is strong, tart, like a wine vinegar. Very true to the style but not extraordinary. Taste is strong and acidic.  Thin mouthfeel.  Tongue gets blasted with very sour grapefruit, vinegar/stomach acid tastes.  Also on palate are some rough bitters. If it werent for the apple vinegar/sour cherries, this beer would be very difficult to handle because of its harsh acids. Works too much on the back tongue and doesnt provide the sweet/sour contrast that makes this style so enjoyable.  Maybe I need more experience with this style, but I cant see this being a top 50 beer.
Pale orange hazy colour. Medium sized, thick head. Acidic aroma of grapefruit zest and rhubarb. Sourish but refreshing flavour of oak and unripe apples.

Orange gold color. Small sized white foamy head, with nice lacing. Aroma is vinegar, barnyard, leather, must, cheese (?) and citrus. A light to medium bodied Gueuze. VERY tart, must barnyard and citrusy. Way funky. Very barnyardish and old musty leather. Yet it very smooth for all that tartness/sourness. The tartness seems to increase as you get down to the bottom of the glass. BEWARE the last sip… Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is tart!!!

375 ml bottle 

Pours clear orange with an aroma  just like the flavor - kiwi/strawberry.  I wish the aroma were as prominent as the bold taste.  The pleasant surprise was the amount of sweetness maintained - while still being crisp.  No vinegar notes or other funkiness to dilute the goodness.

Wow. Wine scents blast you in the face. Extremely tart. this was so tart that it was difficult to swallow. Lots of vinous qualities and tastes. Intense, but im not appreciating the style right now. The drinkability factor was pretty low.

Im still trying to understand the style.  This poured a clear golden-amber color with the merest of white heads.  The aroma is intensely sour with hints of vinegar.  Its medium bodied, and the flavor is of sour fruits and vinegar.  Its got a lingering sour finish.  Interesting to try.

I am sure that this is an incredible brew, but I just cant get into it. Tastes like liquid sweet tarts to me. Definitly got one hell of a pucker after each sip. If you like this type of beer, then i am sure you will absolutly love this. But, in my case, i really respect this beer but just cant get into it.

Not as sour as Id have expected, which was a relief.  Lots of complexity, though - all sorts of weird musty odors and flavors.  Yeasty, to be sure.  My bottle was a gusher when I opened it (even though it had been laying still on its side in a wine fridge for 6 months).  Some woodiness in the flavor profile - not sure its worth it, but then again Im not a huge lambic fan.
UPDATED: FEB 18, 2005 Copenhagen beer marathon 2004, Hazy golden color, medium acid sour aroma and taste, medium body, sour finish.

super sour aroma with hints of sweaty feet, light cloudy bronze with a tiny head, musty sourness quickly builds to a pucker, the bitter and fruity apex of sourness tastes like one of those atomic warhead candies, lots of woodiness throughout as well, somehow though being as sour as it is it still begs another sip

37.5cl bottle.  Fantastically complex fruity, sour aroma, with intertwining notes of leather, hay, musk, freshly cut wood, peppery spices, white wine, old flowers, grapefruit and lemon.  Hazy light golden amber color, swirls of yeast, with a fine, slight head.  Flavor profile is gratifyingly tart and sour,  yeasty, spicy, lightly malty and sweet, hints of pear and apple fruitiness, with a juicy citric finish, faintly acetic and hoppy.  Effervescence is light on the palate, carrying the flavors beautifully, body is light to medium.  Flavor integration and development are artfully accomplished.  Incredible.  Big thanks to slob.

The aroma is sour apples and vinegar. The appearance is orange with a small head. The flavor is an assortment of cheese, tart apples, vinegar, and lemons. The aftertaste is fantastic with a nice dusty sour finish. This one is quite sour and funky and something you have to sip on slowly.  Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2006 Bottle.  Thanks to Ben (btg) for the awesome trade. This one took me two samples before I could get down a rating.  What to tihnk? It starts out with so much green apple, I begin to doubt the complexity already.  From here it goes malty and yet tart, with tons of peppery, puckering, bittersweet yeast flavor.  Body is extra-full, like the Speedway of gueuzes.  This beer knows what it wants to showcase (A drinkability that is paradoxically, complimentary to the full body). But then Im still getting the apples, some musty old wool sucks that are wet from sweating in them.  Light citrus and green apples, with just huge tart yeast appeal.  It never gives up, I can still taste this stuff to perpetuity.  The thing is, this seems 180 degrees from Cuvee Rene, which is what I "grew up on", so I just cant get used to this stuff.  Its less sourness, less yeast barnyardiness and cheese, but I will admit to the body being better, with more full, round, actual sweet flavor.  Yes, its the sweet malt you can actually hang on to in this one, whereas with Rene, you have a pure tart finish.  I must admit to some bias against this one, when it comes to the overall score.

375 mL bottle brought back from Gent.   Beautiful, clear golden color with a tint of orange.  Nice head that lasts throughout and carbonation running up through it constantly.  Sour aroma with wonderful yeasty smell.  Delicious sweet & sour flavors play off of eachother along with that barnyard quality.  There is a cheese quality that is so balanced with the flavor profile it is amazing.  There are some citrus flavors, including orange.  It is tart but that is what sets it apart as a traditional gueuze.  It makes your mouth water!  Thank goodness for the yeast around Brussels.

First beer on election night 2004:
Crystal clear copper coloured body with a thin, big-bubbled white head. Aroma of barnyard, sour grapes, yeast, acid, some metal and a nice fresh fruit quality. Light-bodied; VERY tart lambic flavour up front with that pleasant wheat and apple taste, followed by a puckering tart acidity. Follow that with a dry grape and yeast taste and round it out with a sweet finish of caster sugar. Light bodied overall and the aftertaste doesnt stay too long. A damn good beer and a great bottle to try. I sampled this split (37,5 cL) bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia on 02-November-2004.

I was lucky to get a third of this bottle as it almost exploded in my hands :-) It pours golden/dark straw with a short lived white head. The lambic aroma is... Wonderfull. So amazingly complex that i just keeps sniffing it for the longest time before i taste it. Then the taste: acidic and sour, with a well rounded sweetnes to offset it. The balance is very very good. The black label is a wonderfull geuze.

My bottle didnt even come close to exploding as it did for some of the other raters here. But the aroma certainly did. All the wonderful lambic aroma you expect and more; cheese, mildew, apple, funk. I was most impressed with the balance and weight of the body of this gueuze, all on top of the complexity to be expected in the style. I was too busy enjoying this brew to take more thorough notes, but fortunately I have more.

Explosive pour as many noted. Fortunately I had the glass ready to avoid losing much. Dense orangey amber appearance, lively head formation. Strong vinegar aroma, cheesiness mildly pungent, fragrant, fresh roses, and a fair fruitiness, grapes, oranges. Tart, acidic flavor, but again pleasantly fruity and refreshing. Grapefruit, orange and raspberry, mildly spicy. I usually love lambics for their sourness and acidity, this has that in abundance but also does an excellent job of balance with the sweet fruitiness. Thanks to rauchbier for this one.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 Clear golden body with a peach tint, fairly mild carbonation, and a modest white head. Subtle but complex musty nose of sour fruit, barnyard, wood stain, oak, overripe pineapple, a phantom raspberry note, light grassiness and some brine. Lightly acetic flavor has characteristics of grapefruit, white wine, cider, citrus zest, brett and oak.  Crisp sourness but not overly acidic. Nearly dry finish but the pleasing flavor lingers very nicely. Fantastic beer.

Aroma:  honey, oranges/citrus fruits, nectar, floral, slight mint, spicy-tartness, almost a woody scent, ivory soap

Appearance:  golden orange, no lacing, very small head

Flavor:  some mint, sweet nectar, flowers--tulips?, honey, and salt 

Palate:  very light taste, slight cream and mint aftertastes 

Overall:  alright, needs a bigger bite--this is a very smooth, light gueuze; slightly slippery--doesn?t take anything/leave anything on your tongue

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2013 aug 2011.  theres something magical about buying this at a store a few blocks away and have it be as illuminating as ever.  cx2010 with a year on it, wow.  rich, ester-heavy, musty and vibrant with salivating undertones of maple-honey and mulled grains. yes. 



my score is for a number of different bottles at a number of different ages.  the notes below are for only one or two vintages (probably 2-4 years old), but Ive come to see Girardin Gueuze as the pinnacle of gueuze blending.


extremely strong nose, crawling through the air after the cork is pulled, filling the room with a leathery and estery aroma. semi-sweet apple and driftwood nose.  semi-thick body, not overwhelming you with sourness like Cantillon. less acidic than other gueuze but magically vibrant and sharp when you get a stellar batch, the probabilities of which seem up in the air. oily palate late without coating.
(Bottle)  Pours an orangish yellow body with a spare white head.  Tart aroma of white grapes, Granny Smith apples, and yeast.  Tart flavor.   Excellent Gueuze!

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2009 My store has had this for a while. I didnt realize what was stting on the shelf for a long time. I wished I had tried it earlier. Small, thin head tops the brew. The color is a deep amber with a little bit of cloudiness. Aroma is hay, lemons and a little vinegar. As you drink it also smells of apples and slight mustiness. The taste was a mouth puckering sourness that pops out at first and lets you know that this is a geueze. Tastes of sour apples and cherries. Also has some lime and a little bit of a cheese like a stilton? The finish is also a little bit salty. The mouthfeel of this is oily, but in a pleasant way. This gem deserves its high ranking. A true masterpiece of the style.

Hazy Yellow & Orange color.  Foamy perfect head. Apple, cookie dough, citrus, lemon, earthy, like nothing Ive ever smelled. Very sour and tart, lemon, tea, salt. Very complex almost like a grassy taste. This beer took my attention away from everything like no beer ever has. I think this is the closest to heaven you will come to in a bottle.

Pours a hazy gold, highly effervescent in the glass but not much head formation.  Aroma of musty cobwebs, pungent and sour but in no way offensive.  This is awesome!  The first sip is mouth-puckering sour, with notes of ripened fruit, grass, and sour candy.  Notes of funky cheese and yet more sourness in the dry, tart finish.  An absolute pleasure to drink and one of my favorites of all time.

10/7/04.  Poured out of 375 mL bottle, obtained in a trade with DavidP on RateBeer 10/2/04.  Deep golden amber color like hazy hay.  Nice dusty but blotchy lacing.  Very thinly lingering white head.  Awesome shimmer and sparkle on the lacing, but Id love it if the head were larger and more lasting.  Big funk and straw/grass flavors.  Also some honey/nectar with a touch of sweetness, but an overall dry character.  Almost like a moldy cheese (but not quite bleu cheese-- I dont know).  Dry cheesy funk with a smooth, slick, and then sharp mouthfeel.  Almost spicy pungency in the back of the throat.  Very nice, oily texture and then blotches of strong brett and candied lemon citrus sparkling all over the tongue.  Very complex and delicious.  With Drie Fonteinen, one of the best geuzes Ive yet had the pleasure to try.

This is like walking into a damn manure pyle.  Lots of undergrowth, and vegetal horseblanket funk.  Sweat, even.  The flavor is there just under the surface once you can get past the vinegar and super sour flavors, there is a great balanced acidity and some interesting mineral qualities.  The funk is right here for you.  Finishes spicy and fruity and of course sour.

I can smell the funk on this before the cork is even out!...whooof! There it is, twisted citrus, a bed of straw, mysterious mustiness, ...gotta give it up to gueuze, there aint nothin like it! sparkling minerals, brilliant lemons, funky orange...appearance: amber/peach color, no head ...
Taste: oooh, oooh, sourness itself, serious puckeration, but still refreshing and swift down the throat. Medium body, long, long slick, dry finish, leaves a serious coating in the mouth. This has got to be one of the better tasting gueuzes Ive ever had, though it still gives my senses a tumble, I remain powerless before its elusive character.
Halfway in, the sour attack on the tongue is not as harsh, and it slips ever easier down, feeling even thicker on the palate. I pass the night with a few of these, no problem. Pretty snappy gueuze they got goin on...

My first gueuze leaves me at somewhat of a loss on how to describe it. Poured a burnt orange, somewhat cloudy with almost no head but good lacing. Aroma - well, you could smell it as soon as the cork was out.  Horseblanket dominated the aroma. Flavor was tart, starting as sour apple and ending somewhere just south of pickle juice territory. In a word, funky!!

Pours a slightly hazy deep gold with a small white head.  Sparkling like champagne.  Aroma of crisp apples, lemon, and spice.  I was suprised by no barnyard smell.  Then it began to warm and Mr Ed showed up  but not nearly as strong as some other expamples. Tangy flavor cotinues with apples and spice and little bitter on the long finish but not a hop bitter and then lemon on top of that.  Medium bodied.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2004 This stuff is just simply amazing. Im not even going to go through a list of all of the flavors thats in here and my description cannot possibly do this stuff justice. Just phenominal.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2005 Pours a cloudy orange hue with a small frothy white head.  Aromas of apples, vinegar, ginger/spices and a little lemon. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied. Flavors are of lemon, oak and honey.

.375L bottle.  Clear orange body with a puffy white head.  This stuff has a very intense smell - my nose tingled when getting the first whiff after opening the bottle.  The aroma is quite sharp, I get moldy hay tempered by pickled herring, grapefruit rind, and lo and behold some caramel sweetness.  Big tart flavor, starts with the sweet flesh of a lemony grapefruit, bitter flower petals, and sweet "deepness" I cant put my finger on that happens towards the end.  Finishes with rhubarb, white sugar, and dry hay.  You gotta seek this stuff out, it has an intense, complex aroma and taste without being overwhelming.   Magnificent!

Cloudy glowing copper color with a small off-white head. Nice lemon, grass, vinegar and barnyard funk aromas. Very tart lemon, floral, vinegar, grass and wood flavors. Very light crisp feel with a dry finish. Very good!

Cloudy, almost opaque, deep orange color with a small off-white head. The aroma seemed fresh and full of lemon, flowers, grass, old wood, slight vinegar, and some barnyad funkiness. The flavor was almost a perfect blend of slightly bitter herb/floral tones, citrus fruits (mainly lemon), and earthy/woody tones. Very refreshing crisp, light feel with a dry finish. Totally awesome gueuze. Thanks a lot Goldtwins!

Black label. Large head, off-white, lasted long.  Hazy yellow in appearance. Aroma is yeasty, barnyard, leather, malty with subtle notes of wood.  Flavor is lightly sweet, tart fruit, but not a sour as other gueuzes I have had in the past.  Just the right balance for my palate.  Some are too over the top sour, killing my tastebuds.  This one is right on!

8.25.04  37.5CL bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar.  This is my introduction to top tier gueuze.  Cork dislodges easily and without episode, beer does not gush.
