Pour is that of a hazy honey with little head and less visible carbonation.  Aroma is, honestly, stinky - barnyard, vinegar, rotting tomato and apple, honeysuckle, feet, woodshed.  The first sip is absolutely mindblowing.  Musty muddy barn - slop and old cheese and felled fruits and shit.  Harsh vinegar sourness.  Biting acidity insults on the finish.  A real teeth cleaner.  Aftertaste is all cheese, cheese, cheese.  Some spicey fresh green pepper (those banana peppers).  A lingering acidity does not eliminate some finishing sweetness - could this be a bad bottle?  As it turns out, I dont think Im ready for gueuze, or maybe today was not the day for it.  I can absolutely see the greatness in this brew, but its not an experience I could wrap myself around on a regular basis.  Tom, thanks a million for sharing this wild beer.

Slightly cloudy and golden brown in appearance this lambic has a minimal off white head.  Joyous aroma of sour apples, wet wood, vinegar, and cob webs greatly encourage the user to imbibe.  Flavor is mostly sour again but there is a very light apple sweetness, like biting a very sour apple that just has a touch of apple sweetness.  Extremely tart and refreshing, this is a top 50 beer that did measure up in my book.  Thank you very much Tom (CaptainCouger)!!!

Nice golden/orange color,small white head that faded quickly and left little behind.Musty fruity aroma with a sourness coming through quite well.Fruity flavor up front then the sour hits you.The after taste is a mildly sour fruit with a sourness that kind of hangs on the pallate but not nearly a bad as some others ive had.Well worth a try if you can get it and Thanks go to Wunderbier for sending this fine brew my way.
This beer is awesome... I kept it on its side for a week in the fridge and enjoyed it in my garden. Refreshing, tasty... this is perfection
Rich and complex gueze - very sour but not eyewatering (balanced nicely with some sweetness).

bright orange color, thin white, mostly lasting head. loaded with tart fruit, mustiness, breadiness and hot tar. flavor is quite tart, bit of a flat mouthfeel. its very very good, but doesnt stand up to the Oud Beersels gueuze.

Orange in color with a small diminishing head. Highly carbonated. Very tart and sour smell. Flavor is also very tart but not to the point of being turned off. Some horsehair Belgian flavor also. This beer leaves a coating in your mouth that lingers.

Pours a hazy orange gold with small head that fades. Aroma is tartness, mild barnyard, and some funky cheese. Flavor is initially a medium to strong tartness that quickly fades and makes way for cheese, light fruit, and funky yeastyness. Very nice use of solid tart flavors without making them an overpowering force.

12 oz bottle, snifter.  Light bread malt (L); horseblanket, barnyard, leather yeast (H);  grass hops (L); white wine and cask wood aromas.    Large, creamy, white head is well lasting and sits on a deep amber-gold body.  Moderately sweet, heavily acidic (sharp, sour, tart) flavor becomes a moderately  acidic (sour), lightly bitter finish.  Medium body, slick/creamy texture, average carbonation.  The bottom line is: a crisp and refreshing gueuze that shows great balance between sweet, sour, and funk.

This gueuze pours with an orange body topped by a thin fizzy head with little lacing.  The aroma is sout, tart and vinious with a slightly sweet note and a little barnyard.  The flavor is very sour and tart with a nice vinious note, a touch of barnyard and a touch of underlying sweetness.  Light bodied and smooth yet dry.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2004 Tastes like bacon...really good bacon. Rich and complex intensely sour. Notes of dust, old barn and cobwebs, muscats and old beer. As it warms the flavours become much sweeter and infinitely complex.
G-rat

Clear amber color with light film of head & thicker lacing. The aroma is fucking good with all the sweet/tart flavors of a traditional gueuze. Flavor has a delicious malt base with flavorful tart malts & a spicy herbal malt finish. Pure gueuze delicious. Youre the man Mads!

Amber gold appearance, creamy white head, and spotty and webbed lacing. Aromas are sour and funky fruits. Spicy tail. It does what a good gueuze should: offends. So damned smooth at the end though. Flavor is bitter and dusty. Cobwebby. Apples and grapes. Sour and barnyardy. Very mellow. Sharp bite of sourness in the palate as well as being dry. Coats the mouth pleasantly

375ml bottle looks like 10103 on cork  Amber/copper, slight head, sour cheese, mustywood, some horsiness and other suchness in the nose.  Solid acidity, but not overwhelming...a super nice blend with enough wild funk to make it very complex, yet it maintains a mellow drinkability that is matched only by Lou Pepe Gueuze in my experience.  The acidity is lemonade like to me, but a punch more, and without sweetness(artificial or otherwise).  It is beyond me to attempt to describe what this beer tastes like, but its one of the most enjoyable beers Ive had so far.

Small offwhite head, good retention, thin laceing. Hazy gold color with a neat orange glow. Thin film of lace lingering on top. Subdued nose of apples, wet lumber and leather. Med/light body, prickly carbonation. Mellow woody flavors, vinous notes, fruity. Sourness and acidity are just right, good yeast flavors. Everything works very well together, a nice blend. A top notch Gueuze IMHO. Smooooth and mellow, nice bite, tangy dry finish easy to drink. Wish the bottle was bigger! Thanks to captcougar for this one!

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 cloudy tang-tainted pineapple mimosa colored with a solid, tightly woven white head.  Deep intoxicating bretty, funky, sour cheese aroma with a touch of sweaty, bloody gauze (thats probably where the name gueuze came from) and zest of fermented tangerine peel.  very nice aroma indeed.  Flavors had some tamed brett wrapped tangerines, in fact very citrusy, slightly oaky with a dry feeling to it, but lacking the serious complexity that i was hoping for.  However, still a classy gueuze in all meanings of the word.

Bottled: Golden/orange coloured. Unclear. Huge off-white head. Very nice sourness, earth, wood and some subtle sweetness in the aroma. Is fresh and a little acidic. Dry very sharp sourness in the flavour. Really gets you drooling. Notes of wood, grape, fruit and some mild sweetness. Is fresh and citrusy and has a kind of fruitsourness in the end. This beer IMO has immensely many shades of flavour. Great complexity that makes this one of the best beers Ive had yet. Would choose this over most other beer.

Not bad at all.  Typical barnyard, woody, fruity aroma.  Flavor was very refreshing, tart but not overbearing. A bit thin on the mouthfeel....overall, a rather "light" take on the style, nice and easy.
Bottle.  Perhaps the best gueuze Ive ever had.  Ultra-smooth despite a tangy tart backdrop.  Fruity, cheese, wood flavors all mixed in.  Damn, this style is growing on me.

An extremely explosive beer - about half of it ran over when I opened it. The color is an unclear dark orange and it has a beutiful though collapsing orange head. The aroma is lovely of grapefruit but also with notes of wood. The flavor is very nicely sour with notes of grapefruit, wood, and lemon. The sourness draw the mouthwater.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2004 Very dark dark yellow appearance with a large thick white head. Musty, complex and fresh stable aroma with witha very sour background. Sour woody flavour with notes of hay and grapes. Very dry  and sour finish. An excellent gueuze.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2007 Cork Marking: 0103: Poured a bubbly pinkish, yellow, orange color with a small cream tan head and a little lacing on the glass.  Tart acidic, sour, horseblanket aroma.  Tart citrus (lemon peel and apples), oaky, and woody, with a crisp, dry finish. My bottle did not explode.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2004 Bottle. Exploded with beer all over the carpet, half the bottle was lost. Hazy amber/orange, poured with lots of sediment. Acidic/woody aroma, some citric elements. Attacks the tongue from the beginning, slowly becoming easier to drink as you get down the glass. Very complex, tart, wood, cork and a slight citric quality. The best lambic I have tried so far.

Rerate:
Palace Hotel, Poperinge, Belgium. Wonderful beer to match a wonderful day.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2005 Keith-WOW!  A gorgeous complex aroma with a decent light color.  Then there is the taste.... here is the wow.  Very sweat, tart, and complex.Lemon and grapefruit tang that sits well on the palate.  First taste is a shock to the taste-buds, but the second is heaven.

Lightly hazed golden color with a cap of minuscule bubbles. Light brett. with wood and light fruit (white currants and peaches). Hint of yogurt. Smooth comforting aroma. Palate is lightly oily with a touch of effervescence towards the end. Light malt, with a nice bitting fruit flavor (strawberries & nectarines). Light sour finish. Outstanding balance and drinkability.

First a big thanks to JeffC for the bottle: Hazy coppery hue with fizzy white head and excellent lace. The aroma has notes of lemongrass, sour apple, floral hops, and barnyard yeast esters. The taste displays the expected fruity sourness on top of a fine yeast character. Sublime spice and wood notes upon the finish.  The feel is lively, crisp, and finishes dry.  One heck of a Gueuze, recommended!

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 Bottle drank at Evening Star Brighton.  Sweet, fizzy, apply aroma to this hazy orange beer with virtually no head.  The taste seems dry and sweet at the same time with any sourness just hinted at rather than overpowering.  The flavours are beautifully balanced and makes for a delicious drink.  Score 3.9Subsequent rating scored 3.6. Average becomes 3.8

Pours a semi-hazy orange color with a small off-white head with really big bubbles.  Carbonation is light.  Aroma is barnyard to the extreme, wet hay, horse stables, and leather wrapped up in a small bottle.  Sourness exists but not overpowering.  Flavor is sour with the same barnyard notes represented here.  Body is medium and semi-dry.  This is a truely world-class beer.   I loved this.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2004 Pours a clouded reddish-orange. Aroma is very tart and woody. Some sour fruit, sweat and horse blanket notes. Taste is suitably tart but overall is VERY smooth. Very balanced gueuze (can that happen?). Its sour but not overdone and the mouthfeel while a bit acidic, is rather mild and pleasurable. Finish is a bit tart with more fruit and wood coming through. This is a damn fine beer and easily one of the best gueuzes Ive ever had and definitely one of the smoothest.

Slightly hazed orange body. Small white head that clusters in islands of large bubbles. The aroma is an absolute perfect barnyard aroma. Yeah yeah, barnyard does not smell good, NO, barnyard smells freaking awesome! This is what gueuze smells like. A perfect combination of sour tartness and acidity. Quite complex. Medium body and very refreshing. This is truly an excellent beer.

Thanks to jcalabre for sharing. Hazy orange-amber, tart fruit aroma. Tart/sourness is prominent but not offensive, nicely blended fruits with a hint of (pepper?). Almost a cider/champagne experience, but more complex and interesting.
Honey colored brew with lots of lively carbonation. Nose hints at peaches and apples while the flavor is reminiscent of Granny Smiths and grapes.. Tart with a slight funkiness.
Thanks to austinpowers for this one. Lots of pop when you open this bottle, hazy golden, w/ a clean finish, very enjoyable. Paired well with shrimp

Bottle, Oud Arsenaal Antwerpen. Drinking beer at 10 am, after a night out at the ZBF, and my notes were a little sparse for this one . Hazy amber, good white head and moderate condition.Subtle, well rounded lambic notes, extremely drinkable... and thats where I put my pen down and just enjoyed this excellent Gueuze, but the numbers speak for themselves.

And finally. The last two beers of the London Drinker festival . The Girardin and Oud Beersel gueuzes tasted side by side. Unfortunately, as these were beers number 29 and 30 of the day, I would be hard pressed to claim that my critical faculties were at their sharpest. I found the Girardin and the Beersel to be pretty closely matched and vying with the Drie Fonteinen for number one status. I think the Girardin just edged it. This was the black label version - the white label is often regarded as a different beer. The sharp lactic character was ideal for chivvying up the jaded palate from the days excesses. The Girardin is traditional and classy at the same time. It has the obvious cider tones that most other people mention and is not as harsh the Cantillon, say. Spicy citric tones too. Slips down a treat.
Deep yellow color with a very nice white head. The taste is slight sweet at first but then comes the complex bitter pattern of age and stables. Very nice gueuze.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2004 I'm still weeping over this one. My wonderfully kind-hearted beer amigo, radiomgb, invited me over for a night of guezes. This nectar, our first of the evening, saw fit to burst forth in an eruption of reddish froth leaving us with only half the bottle to enjoy. and enjoy we did - I am a novice in general when it comes to rating beer, and even more so when it comes to the complexities of a lambic. 

I was overwhelmed by the cider and balsamic vinegar battle being waged in my nose as I admired the rich amber colour. Lots of apples and citrus and grapes in the cidery taste with a wonderful puckering tartness too. Very dry - leaves you almost as soon as you swallow. A great beginning to the night and my gueuze experience. Thanks Jeff.

This was the perfect start to my gueuze night and it was my 500th rating.  Black label version.  Lost almost half of the bottle in the explosion after the cork was removed.  Orange-amber in colour.  Aroma of balsamic vinegar, and lots of fruit with apples and grapes, some cider and a great mustyness.  Flavour was nice and mellow, not quite as tart as the Cantillon Gueuze, nice sourness, mustyness, with some apples and grapes again.  Finish is very dry and tart.  Fantastic.

Best before date: 03-2002Light amber color; big head; persistent perlage. Soft nose, woody and acetic; white pepper; harmonious, really interesting. Good balance of tartness, sourness, maltiness; wood, magnesia, light residual sweetness. Thanks to Philippe (Bov) for this bottle.

Tart and musky. Soured grains and lactic acid. White wine and pepper. Old paper.  Great aroma. Creamy white small lacing head over light amber clear liquid - very active carb in sight. Effervescent carb in medium watery body. Like champagne. That's good gueuze ... tart and light sour fruit up front. It cleanses the tongue. Then there's a slightly acidic tang like sweet tarts candy - dry and bitter.  Musk, hay, wet canvas sour swirl through my sinuses before a very dry, lightly bitter finish. Lactic/acetic finish toward the aftertaste. Hard bitter after. So far the best gueuze I've had.

Beer 17 Belgium trip.  I ordered this in a restaurant, completely blind, as the menu simply said "gueuze."  Imagine my shock when this black labelled beauty came rolling out.  The waiter rather proudly told me this was a real beer of Brussels.  Light coppery appearance, good head.  Barnyard hay aroma.  Dry, tangy on the palate, pear, apples, some horseblanket.  Actually similar esters to the Mort Subite I had earlier, but quite dry and yummy.  The wife, incidentally, loved it.  This may have been even better than the numbers indicate.

750 ml bottle (black label) at Hopleaf, Chicago, December 2003.  One of the biggest disappointments (there were a few) of my past summer and fall off Ratebeer was that I couldn't attend the RB summer party.  I knew that this was likely to be there, and further I recall a post (Psychprof maybe?) bemoaning the unlikelihood of it ever getting imported to the USA on a regular basis.  So imagine my surprise and joy when I walked into my now-new-favorite bar (sorry Map Room) in my favorite city and found this beauty waiting for me.  It was $18 and my friend wasn't sharing, so I was actually kind happy when the bartender spilled about 40% of the bottle and gave it to me for half price; happy until I tasted it.  What nectar!  Sour-apple-horseblanket-pipesmoke-pepper greets you on the nose.  Much sweeter than I had expected, sweeter than virtually any gueuze I've had (except the unexceptional Lindemans) but changing slowly and effortlessly into a joyous sourness at the finish.  Toasty, cidery, earthy, perfectly effervescent, my new favorite gueuze and damn what else did I miss at the summer gathering?

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2004 Bottle, black label. Very well balanced aroma. Fruity, wood, cider/apple. Cloudy, orange coloured. Nice white and lasting head. Looks fine. Taste is well balanced again, some sourness and sweet ness, wood, fruits. I liked the smell better than its taste. Smooth, refreshing and dry palate. Very decent. There could be less pressure on the cork however... Very nice to end 2003!! 
Rerate 2004. Superb brew. It moves into my top10.

A truly amazing concoction. I can't imagine how hard it would be to create gueuze this good over and over and over. Crisp, amazing, moss/hay/cranberry/pepper and funk magnified, both in aroma and body. Subtle flavors that linger unobtrusively. Comparing this to other gueuzes (at least ones I've had) would be like comparing Marky Mark to Mozart...well, you get the idea.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2005 BAM! An enormous explosion when i removed the cork. Gueuze all over my room, luckily my computer and guitar were spared. Very strange, i had been very careful during transport... Anyway, the rating is based on the remnant. Cloudy orange coloured, no head. Very nice complex aroma, tart with cheese, some sourness and a bit fruity (but its different when your whole room smells like it...). Flavour is pretty sweet for a geuze (which i like). Smooth finish.

This Gueuze zi much milder than the Cantillon one, and has a much mre refined taste. It tastes sour -of course-, but I also tasted some fruityness, and some yeastyness. Excellent gueuze, nice body, ...

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2005 Black Label: Oh man. I take off the cork restrainer and the cork stays put but when I pop the cork beer instantly rockets towards the ceiling. I try jamming my thumb in the top but that doesnt do enough and beer is blasting towards the ceiling so i run towards the sink to save Pierre and Carolines studio the Gueuze treatment but eat shit on the way to the sink after slipping on the beer slicked tile floor.  Not to bad, I saved the majority of the beer.  Soft aroma, thats less intense the the Dire Fontinen but with some soft peach, hay and citric sourness. Moderately woody, with some apple flavors, peach, tart and sour, very dry.  The Soutness on this has to be experienced to be understood.  You swallow and then your mouth just puckers with an absolutely fantastic sourness.  Likely the most intense beer ive drank.  Flavors of cheese, citric fruit, sour green apples and the absolutely funky yeastyness thats beyond description. Absolutely Beautiful.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2006 (4/3/06, 500ml bottle, ~2 years old) Clear amber body with small off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, sour, cheese/horseblanket, some fruit, light oak.  Taste is medium sweet, sour, cheese/vinegar, some lemon, light wood.  Light body, quite refreshing.  Very enjoyable.  (9/4/8/4/16)

(8/19/03, 500ml bottle) Damn thing exploded/gushed as i opened it -- i lost roughly one-fourth of the bottle, all over my desk, file cabinet and carpet.  Hazy orange body with off-white head.  Aroma is sour, cheesy and vinegar as might be expected, but also very fruity (white grape, apricot, green apple) and vinous/wood -- its a wonderful smell, and it kept me going as I cleaned the spewage off of everything.  The taste is sour/tart, vinegar, acidic, light white grape.  Light/medium watery body. (10/4/7/3/15)

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2004 Sampled February, 2004; Hop Leaf, ChicagoThere is a pronounced and funky farm-house cheese aroma that wafts from my Gueuze tumbler as I pour this beer.  Coupled with this is a dry musty barnyard aroma, and of course a sour aroma as well.  The beer is brilliantly clear and a light amber-gold color.   It is topped by a creamy beige head that starts out quite big but falls to a persistent 1/8 inch head for most of my first glass.  The taste of the beer has a nice sour cidery character to it.  This is a sour beer, but it is not as mouth-puckeringly so like some Gueuzes.  Overall this is a nice light, refreshing, and spritzy beer, just like a good Gueuze should be.  The beer is also very dry, and finishes with a bit of woodiness.  This is dry, musty, and dusty, it reminds me of a wet Belgian hayfield in early spring.  This is an absolutely world class Lambic, that pairs wonderfully with my appetizer of mussels & French fries with a garlic aioli.  Though the beer is bone dry it develops a perceived sweetness when paired with my appetizer.  The food takes away nothing from the beer and the beer takes away nothing from the food, an absolutely stunning combination.
Sampled March, 2001Smells quite musty not that sour smelling, a bit of oakiness as well.  This beer is quite clear in appearance.  Tastes sour with an astringent oakiness to it as well.  Definitely going to have to try this one again.

Had this at 't Brugs Beertje in Brugs-Black label, dust-covered as though it had just been brought from the cellar.
Dark orange, some straw in the aroma and also a whiff of apple cider. Startlingly dry and acidic. Very complex with all sorts of aromatic flavors: hay, apples, and a lemon-juice sourness that lingers. Ends with grapefruit and sour apple flavors. Just the right balance of tartness and flavor to make this enjoyable from start to finish.

Black label bottle. Very like a good cider. Appearance like a cider, but more amber and much cleaner. Aroma is ciderish, but without the apples. Quite tart and woody. Refreshing with a journey that starts with a hesitant sweetness and finishes dry as the Sahara desert on a dry day. No astringent nasties, just a clean, dry finish. But I didn't get the reason for the raves. I think this is a well made beer, tasty and refreshing, but a little one dimensional in it's flavour profile. Gueuze and dry cider seem to have taste experiences in common, though a dry cider has a greater range of flavours and is more complex.

I am really glad that I had other gueuzes (Cantillon, Mort Subite, Beersel) before having this one, because I could see then the level of complexity and intensity of flavors on offer here.  Attractive white head over a cloudy yellow body. First aroma and flavors were the barnyard ones I expected, with some sour zing.  Layers of flavor revealed a lovely citric, very lemon flavor, and then as I got closer to the bottom it produced more grapefruit notes, with a bitter grapefruit finish.  Musty, chewy flavors carried on throughout.  The acidic effect was a bit too much on top of a lamb madras earlier in the evening.  What a gem of a beer to find in a pub. I really didn't need a whole bottle of this (a half bottle would be fine).  (at the Wharf, Oxford)

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 RateBeer Summer 2003:  Murky light orange color with a small head.  Sour aroma with a bit of horse-blanket and old wood.  Tart and sour.  This is the first gueuze that I truly enjoyed.

Summer Gathering 2003: Cloudy amber with little to no head. Very sour nose with hay/farmyard/lemons. Mind numbing, puckeringly tart and sour, like sucking on lemons & limes. Hint of sweet bready malt in back. Touches of mint in there--something slightly medicinal. Tannic hints; bitter, dry, and nutty at times. All that a lambic should be.

Very cloudy appearance with an aroma something like standing outside in the country after a spring rainstorm (it's more subtle than Belle Vue Selection).  A sip hits your tongue hard with tartness, inducing a pucker (it is quite effervescent), but then it eases off.  Quite good!

Girardin Gueuze 1882 has dark golden colour with thick off-white head.  It has big acidic nose with some floral, piney notes. It has some light piney, resiny flavour notes similar to Cantillon's gueuze, though nowhere as pronounced.  High carbonation rate and very dry and refreshing. It's an extremely drinkable, big gueuze with a complex woody character.
Perhaps Gueuze is not my style. Hazy yellow with vinegary, musty aroma. Has a sour, wood flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2007 Bottle... RBSG2003... This beer Rocks!... Murky, deep golden brew. Creamy, lasting white head.
Nice lacing. The nose is vinous and tart. Notes of leather and must. The flavor is wonderful! Pungent, earthy, leathery. Nice hop bitterness. Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Astringent, lightly bitter, acetic finish! Great Lambic!

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2003 This brew pours a very envigorated large head of small bubbles that was mostly diminishing.  Its body was a hazy light orange brown color.  The aroma was very bubbly and fruity.  It had a dry complex flavor and it was not much of a flavor I cared for.  It fruity citrusy flavor was dry from start to finish.
UPDATED: APR 14, 2007 Hazy, and haystack yellow.   Aroma of vinegar, musty wood, sour white wine, leather.  Interesting brew.  Sour flavor to match the aroma.  One very good Gueuze!

Hazy peach.  Dense, bone white foam.  Elegant, vinous  aroma of cedar, musty wood, white grape, straw, grass, bandage, chalk, and peach skin.  Subtle notes of passion fruit and perfume.  Firm, dry, and crisp on the palate.  Sublime dry, woody, lightly salty flavors paired with a leafy, herbal mixture.  Finishes firmly tangy with a touch of melon and musty wood.  This is a gem of a brew and an experience to relish.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 20, 2005 Black label. Small white head (foam). Dark golden body. Aroma; sweet, acidic (lambrusco, rosé-wine!?!), wet lumber, hay... complex. Taste;  starts slightly sweet,  mostly sour, grape-juice-like. Really good and gets better each time I have it.
Great dark orange appearance with a very good bitter and sour aroma, and a great sour flavour. Overall a great sour beer.

Enjoyed courtesy of Psychprof.  Light, delicate, aroma--a bit cidery some acetic acid.  Gorgeously attractive body, tart, but not overpoweringly so.  Not as dry and thin as several gueuzes I've had.  Tart and relatively clean in flavor, but still stays interesting from sip to sip.  I would love the opportunity to lay down a few of these and see what 15-20 years of age would do to them.  Excellent.  Thanks a ton for your hospitality, Psychprof!

Like many others here, the bottle foamed over upon uncorking.  Luckily the glass was nearby and less than an ounce was lost.  Medium cloudy bronze with a frothy head that leaves a light lace as it subsides.  Sour barnyard aroma.  Body is tart but not over powering with a lightly sweet flavor.  Very well rounded and the best gueuze I have had the pleasure of trying.

Hazy red/amber in appearnace.  Intense sourness with barnyard, musty nose.  Quite sour but perfectly balanced.  SLightly biting even yet enjoyable.  The finish is a hybrid bitter-sour character that leaves me wanting more...

I wish I had read a couple of the previous ratings - especially the ones that told about exploding bottles. Well as it turns this might turn out to be my most expensive beer so far as it cost me a new keyboard - but that did not really bother me that much (old keyboard), it is much worse that most beer of the beer escaped before i could drink it...
Well this is what I get from the 126.8 ml i had left: (Black label)
Aroma has cobwebs and blue bheese in it (in a good way). Murky orange which looked a lot better in the glas than on my wall. Complex sour tastenotes: Mainly earthy notes topped of with a lactic fruityness (grapes,strawbeerries) the whole beer is wonderfully round and wellbalanced and I sit back with a sour aftertaste that slowly fades away and wish I have had more of this brew.

BLACK LABEL (=unfiltered)!
Goden colour with slight orangey shine. For a gueuze, remarkably stable head, dirty-yellow. Nose of 'horseblanket', fresh flowers, sulphur, green apples and drying hay. Very dry is the immediate impression, yet carbonisation all over the place - together with the tannines, the onslaught on the front teeth is complete, no tartar left - if I weren't a dentist myself, mine would be out of work, now. The real taste is purely retronasal; citrus, pineapple, green apple, lime, lactic (no acetic). Yet there is a strain of sweetness - like in 'speculaas' grain-biscuits Belgain style. Mouthfeel is undistinguishable from the taste, as above. Close my eyes, and I'm in a horse stable, the animal still steaming from the exercise, closeby the summerharvest of still hot grain, apples, straw is being stored. Words of my vocabulary are not sufficient. Would I have smoked pot in my younger days, I might have found them.
Then, I have not.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2003 Ushered through the massive barn, the oak from the horse stalls and the leather from the saddles linger in the air, but I am pulled further. . directed down a spiral stone staircase into the cellar, I push aside a large cobweb and step onto the soft earthen floor; aromas unimagined consume my existence.  Clean and totally organized this cellar is unlike any I have come across: all of the cobwebs and dust are in perfect order, with a complexity never before seen.  I hope I find St. Peter in a barn like this.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2003 The most complex gueuze aroma I've ever experienced.  All sorts of stuff I couldn't ever name.  Cheese, dust, cobwebs, musty apples and leather.  The flavors are sour and dry.  Sour and dry, but not to the level of Hanssens Oude Gueuze.  Maybe the best gueuze I've had.  If only I had the ability appreciate it more...

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2005 Aroma has oak, citrus and honey. Sour, absolutely dry and oily. Oak, pineapple, citrus and hint of cherry in the flavor. Harsh yet smooth beer, complex and delicious. Its hard to find better beers.
Re-rate: half the contents of this large bottle gushed out before I could pour. What a waste! Bought 1 year ago at the brewery. Delicious aroma of honey, mandarin and lemon. Full bodied, almost milky with oak, melon, lemon, banana even. An explosion of flavors on your tongue. Earthy, a grapefruity bitterness, sugary even, plastic. Every sip is an exploration of flavors and aromas. Immensely complex. A great beer, the rating is fully deserved. I will store the 5 bottles Ive left for many more years.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2003 Rerate 24/10/03: Amber colour, little pale.  A lot of bubbles and a white head.  You can smell the aroma when you are filling your glass.  Sour aroma.  The flavour was quite flat.  Little sour, bitter and sweet, but no dominating flavour as a Cantillon.

Treble colour.  Very disgusting aroma.  I don' know why, but the aroma was really ... bad.  Bitter, sour, very good gueuze aroma.  Bitter-sweet palate.  Excellent Gueuze-lambic

Cloudy, deep yellow with hints of orange. Thin, lasting head and lace. Mouthwatering and insane aroma of green apples, cheese, horsebarn, grapes and others. Smooth, creamy feel, moderate carbonation, very complex and different flavors happening. A bit fruity/sweet at first, with hints of wheat and tons of oaky sourness/acidity but this is so soft and balanced where the sourness doesn't beat you over the head. Hints of cheese and yeast also add to the mix to round out the best gueuze I ever had. Thank you Psychprof.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2007 Update: 4.5 months later and I was ready for the overflow - the body here is fantastic! Rich and soooper cheesy! Shared one with Hey_K and Frank on 5/24/03. Delicious. Well, Ben Franklin was right...haste does indeed make waste. I unpacked this baby, set it in the fridge for 30 mins...but that wasn"t enough. It exploded all over me and my apartment. I rescued approx. 125 ml out of 375 ml, and now everything in my apartment smells like gueuze. Black label. Very cloudy, dark yellow. Aroma is exceptionally woody, even more so than Hanssens (!), yet ameliorated by subtle fruitiness (grapeskin, sour apple). Flavors are tart, of course, but with a lot of wood and understated funky cheese. Outstanding....but I want to resample when the wares arent dripping off of me.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
UPDATED: JUL 29, 2016 Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy/fizzy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy dark yellow to light amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately yeasty (barnyard, horseblanket), with notes of lemon pith, old oak (almost rotten smelling), camphor. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent.

This is a fairly fresh bottle, most likely, as it just arrived on shelves locally after a long absence. More astringent and bitter than most traditional gueuze, but still overall pretty enjoyable. Solid but not among the top tier.
Smells of sweet wet leaves - a little sulfury too. Hazy gold color and a lacy head. Yeasty, lemony with lactic tastes. Very astringent finish. Medium bodied. Unbelievable gueze!
UPDATED: JUN 23, 2005 Nice sour grape nose. Orange, golden with a little head. Yeasty. Fullmouth, nice acidic taste with a super dry finish. . MMhhh, maybe I do like geuze, wait...

A side by side champion up against the biggest names in gueuze, Girardin was a shining star. Brightness, fruity, very even profile, souring from start to finish, light medium effervescence, very easy, Bretty, drinkable but firm, refreshing and an aroma that wont quit. Basement aromas, straw, very light wood, grapefruit.
1999: Musty straw in the nose.  Overall sour taste with acidic and citrus tones.  A dry finish.

1999 VERSION:  excellent mustiness and cheesy goodness in the nose.  Flavors are in good order, pretty complex.  Dry sours mix well with sugary sweet fruits and some spices.  A few more years in the cellar may have yielded a big, big score!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2004 The aroma is almost perfect. I'm a gueuze freak and I was enjoying it for so long that my wife knocked me at the back of my head plunging my nose in the foam. And then she asked me if I would drink it the normal way or through the nose. Nice orange golden coloured and with a head if you want or without if you prefer it that way. Very good oak, tartness, wheat and hops. The perfect amount of sourness and a finish that gives you a burning sensation.

woah public toilet smell with berries, greenery + extra sox. like drinking a really nice salad dressing. really sour but also beautifully smooth and rich and the head sticks oh my god and yes its a good beer indeed.

beautiful texture. lots of manure in the aroma and a bit of chunder with carrots in it. amazingly smooth and with a fantastically dry finish. not sweet. tastes like french dressing and looks like budvar. capers and lettuce
UPDATED: APR 12, 2004 Black label: Cheesy aroma. Not as oaky and woody as i prefer lambics to be. Quite sweet taste. A bit disappointing.

Ok, this time i had the black label version (unfiltered). To me it was better than the white label. Dryer, more sour, more tart, more complex, very high up there with my favourites, tremendous stuff, very interesting.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2011 As far as Im concerned, divinity in the shape of a gueuzeBright and shiny green apples rolling in the hayLemons and grapefruit gleefully yield the perfect gum-drying tartnessA gentle dryness and malt sweetness on the palate to leave you gasping for moreThe classiest of all gueuzes, imho...

Closely-related to Drie Fonteinen, a side-by-side comparison had to happen...This Girardin has more peppery brett, but in the end is more elegant and drinkable than 3F, which is pretty classy in itself...This one is also more akin to sparkling apple cider...Truly the classiest of them all...

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003   A great geuze indeed...just behind Cantillon on my list but deserving of praise nonetheless. Flavorful sour malt...I found Cantillon to be a tad smoother which made the difference here.

Im not quite sure that i have the capacity to explain whats going on in this beer, but Oakes wasnt kidding around when he said this might be the grand-daddy of all lambics. This just edges out Cantillion in the frantic Geuze taste off i had in Brussels.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2004 A very nice Geuze with a very nice, complex palate. The aroma is the typical sour geuze plus that of an old damp sofa in the attic. The first time I had it to oven-baked salmon and it was a very good combination.

Murky yellow brown with thin evaporating head. Very complex sour and sweet fruits, wood resin, fermented fish and old socks yeast. Strong yeasty and grapefruit sour, and a zingy somewhat artifical carbonated flavoured start. More sour and a passing reference to sweet middle and a long slighty bitter then sour finish. Very complex, rating suffers because one really needs to rate these beers along with other gueuzes and not the eclectic collection we tasted this evening.
Even though I am not a fan of this type of beer, it is definitely very complex. I almost felt as if I was being attacked by the flavor. It is bitter, and tart. Beautiful bottle with authentic corck!

Pale amber coloured. Extremely complex with balanced, tart acidity.
One of few beers that combines being both very flavourful and very refreshing.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2006 Golden-amber with chill haze.  Complex aroma of leather, pears, peaches, feet, dust, old wood and farmhouse cheshire.  Bracing acidity and extreme complexity of wood, cheese, acids, grapefruit, kumquat, pommelo and old saddle.  Insane complexity.  Brilliant balance.  Balls front intensity.  Fucking amazing.

Here you go Oakes.  Im glad Belgik made the manure comment because I didnt want to be the first.  Although this style certainly takes some getting used to, I think that the complexity of this beer needs to be recognized.  So much in the aroma, at first it comes as offensive, but quickly becomes more interesting.  Almost like biting into a lemon.  Has to be tried.  Dont let it intimidate you.

Aroma:  smells like the region it comes from, during the worst cold weather rainy season, sour, associations with a livestock barn, manure...
Flavor:  very intense, sour, enlivens saliva, slight bitter and tannic substance
Palate:  complex, rather short foam-in-mouth impression, long sour aftertaste
Appearance:  after having stood upright, limpid clear coppery hue (otherwise yeasty-haze); foams but little upon pooring and foam ebbs away quickly, leaving but few specks of dustlike yeast floating on top; swirling brings back sparkling-wine-like bubbles.
Overall:  a very ecological impression, definitely animal-like agricultural
associations, very complex, long in the mouth and with a long-lasting aftertaste.
Definitely different, authentic Bruegel and Hyronimous Bosch beer.
